digest.doctrine: Tax values and assessments prepared by local assessors can serve as guides but cannot be absolute substitutes for just compensation in expropriation proceedings, as these are often based on generalities and fail to account for individual property differences. Consequently, a valuation of private property taken for public use is invalid if it relies solely on the tax assessment value found in tax declarations without considering other essential factors like acquisition cost, current market data, and BIR zonal valuations,.
digest.facts: Arellano University filed a complaint against the City Government of Pasay for taking its 805-square-meter property and converting it into a public street (Menlo Street) without expropriation proceedings or payment of just compensation. The City admitted the taking but disputed the valuation, leading to an appraisal report by City officials that pegged the value at P200.00 per square meter based solely on the 1978 City Assessorâ€™s tax valuation as the time of taking,. The Regional Trial Court adopted this tax-based valuation with interest, but the Court of Appeals remanded the case for re-determination, ruling that the computation was based on incomplete data by relying only on the 1978 tax assessment without considering other factors like BIR zonal valuations and acquisition cost,.
digest.issue: Whether the determination of just compensation based solely on the tax assessment value provided by the City Assessor is valid.
digest.ruling: NO, the valuation based solely on tax assessment is not valid. Under the principle established in Export Processing Zone Authority v. Judge Dulay, tax values serve only as guides and cannot be absolute substitutes for just compensation, as the 'justness' of the amount is a judicial function requiring a consideration of the 'totality of circumstances' beyond mere tax declarations,. Here, the trial court and commissioners erred by relying exclusively on the 1978 tax assessment revision without considering other mandatory factors such as BIR zonal valuations, acquisition cost, and the property's potential uses. Hence, the case must be remanded for a proper determination of fair market value using complete data beyond mere tax assessments.
digest.dispositive:
ACCORDINGLY, the petition is PARTIALLY GRANTED. The December 28, 2020 Decision and the March 15, 2021 Resolution of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV No. 113233 are MODIFIED, in that: 
1) the award of exemplary damages is DELETED; and 
2) the interest on the value of the property at the time of taking shall likewise earn interest at the rate of 6% per annum from the date of finality of this Decision until full payment.

digest.doctrine: Banks are mandated by law to observe prudence and diligence higher than that of a good father of a family owing to the fiduciary nature of their business, and the possession of a certificate of time deposit serves as a key indication that payment has not yet been made since banks typically require its surrender upon redemption. Consequently, the bank is held liable for the value of the time deposits because the depositors retained the original certificates, and the bank failed to exercise the required diligence by relying on a demand draft allegedly signed by the depositor at a time when she was scientifically and officially proven to be out of the country.
digest.facts: Remedios and Angelita Antonino invested in time deposits with BDO San Lorenzo, receiving Time Deposit Certificates (TDCs) which stipulated surrender upon redemption, but upon attempting to withdraw the funds years later after the branch closed, BDO refused, claiming the funds were already redeemed in 2001 via a Demand Draft signed by Angelita. The Antoninos filed a suit for collection, presenting the original TDCs and proof from the Bureau of Immigration and Angelita's passport that she was in the United States when the alleged redemption occurred, while BDO relied on computer history data and the disputed Demand Draft. The Regional Trial Court ruled in favor of the Antoninos, ordering BDO to pay the principal plus damages. The Court of Appeals affirmed the decision in toto, ruling that the Antoninos evidence was superior and that BDO was remiss in its duty of diligence.
digest.issue: Whether the Antoninos are entitled to recover the proceeds of their time deposits despite the bank's claim of prior payment.
digest.ruling: YES, they are entitled to recover the proceeds. Under established jurisprudence, the burden of proof shifts to the defendant to establish its defense once the plaintiff proves their case, and possession of a time deposit certificate is substantial evidence that the deposit remains unpaid. Here, the Antoninos presented the original TDCs which the bank required to be surrendered upon redemption, while the bank's evidence of a signed Demand Draft was rebutted by official records proving Angelita was abroad on the alleged date of signing. Hence, the bank is liable for the deposits and damages for failing to exercise the highest degree of diligence required of banking institutions.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Petitions for Review on Certiorari are DENIED. The assailed Decision dated September 29, 2023 and the Resolution dated April 22, 2024 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. C.V No. 116100 are hereby AFFIRMED WITH MODIFICATION. Banco De Oro Universal Bank, Inc. is hereby ORDERED to PAY Remedios A. Antonino and Angelita A. Antonino the following: 1. USD 100,000.70 plus the agreed interest accrued per each time deposit/placement on their maturity dates until fully paid; 2. PHP 100,000.00 as moral damages; 3. PHP 300,000.00 as exemplary damages; 4. PHP 150,000.00 as attorneys fees; and 5. The costs of the suit. The total judgment award shall earn legal interest at the rate of 6% per annum, computed from the date of finality of this Decision until full payment.

digest.doctrine: An incumbent public official who continuously exercises the rights and duties of their office in the locality where they are elected cannot validly claim animus non-revertendi relative to such place and animus manendi in a different locality for the purpose of changing domicile. Consequently, the candidates representation of residency in a new locality while actively serving as mayor in another constitutes a deliberate false material representation, rendering the certificate of candidacy invalid for failure to meet the one-year residency requirement due to the lack of intent to abandon the old domicile.
digest.facts: Pax Ali, while serving as the incumbent Mayor of Datu Abdullah Sangki, Maguindanao, filed his certificate of candidacy for Governor of Sultan Kudarat, declaring that he had re-established his domicile in the latter province for one year and eight months prior to the election. Private respondents filed petitions to cancel his certificate, arguing that his incumbency as Mayor negated his claim of residency in Sultan Kudarat, to which Pax Ali countered that he had physically moved and subsequently resigned as Mayor to prove his intent to abandon his former residence. The Commission on Elections First Division cancelled his certificate of candidacy for false material representation regarding his residency qualification, and the Commission En Banc affirmed this decision, ruling that his continued discharge of duties as Mayor precluded him from validly acquiring a new domicile of choice in Sultan Kudarat.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the Commission on Elections committed grave abuse of discretion in cancelling the certificate of candidacy on the ground of false material representation regarding residency qualification.

2. Whether the rule on succession applies in filling the vacancy caused by the cancellation of the winning candidates certificate of candidacy.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the Commission did not commit grave abuse of discretion. Under the Local Government Code, an elective official must be a resident of the locality where they intend to be elected for at least one year, and domicile requires physical presence, intent to remain, and intent to abandon the old domicile. Here, the candidates continued incumbency as Mayor of another municipality negated the intent to abandon that domicile, meaning the new residency could only be reckoned from the date of resignation which fell short of the statutory requirement. Hence, the declaration of eligibility constituted a deliberate false material representation warranting the cancellation of the certificate of candidacy.

2. YES, the rule on succession applies. The Supreme Court abandoned the second placer rule, holding that it lacks legal basis and is repugnant to the will of the electorate, thereby mandating the application of the rules on succession under Section 44 of the Local Government Code. Here, the cancellation of the winning candidates certificate created a permanent vacancy in the gubernatorial office because he failed to qualify. Hence, the duly elected Vice-Governor shall succeed as Governor.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Petition is DISMISSED. The Resolution dated January 18, 2022 of the COMELEC First Division and the Resolution dated May 2, 2022 of the COMELEC En Banc in SPA No. 21-078 (DC) and SPA No. 21-114 (DC) are AFFIRMED. Petitioner Datu Pax Ali S. Mangudadatu is ORDERED to cease and desist from discharging the functions of the Office of the Governor of Sultan Kudarat and to surrender the same to the duly elected Vice-Governor of the province in the May 9, 2022 elections. The Vice-Governor shall serve the remaining duration of the term July 1, 2022 to June 30, 2025.

digest.doctrine: A company-designated physicians assessment must be final, conclusive, and definitive, clearly stating whether the seafarer is fit to work or the exact disability rating without any further condition or treatment to be valid under the law. Consequently, an assessment labeled as interim which prescribes further medical intervention fails to meet this standard, rendering the seafarer totally and permanently disabled by operation of law due to the employers failure to issue a valid final assessment within the mandated period.
digest.facts: Petitioner Hisanza, a seafarer hired by respondents, suffered a back injury while on board and was repatriated for medical treatment, which continued beyond the initial 120-day period. On the 190th day, the company-designated physician issued a 10th Progress Report giving an interim disability Grade 11 while prescribing continued physical therapy, yet the respondents used this to terminate treatment and deny full benefits, prompting petitioner to seek a second opinion declaring him unfit for work and to file a complaint for permanent total disability benefits. The Regional Arbitration Branch awarded only partial disability benefits based on the company physicians rating, and the National Labor Relations Commission affirmed this ruling. The Court of Appeals likewise dismissed the petition, ruling that the failure to refer to a third doctor made the company physicians assessment binding.
digest.issue: Whether the interim assessment issued by the company-designated physician constitutes a valid final assessment effectively barring the claim for total and permanent disability benefits
digest.ruling: NO, the interim assessment is not valid and the petitioner is entitled to total and permanent disability benefits. Under the POEA-SEC and established jurisprudence, the company-designated physician must issue a final, definitive, and conclusive assessment within the 120 or 240-day period, otherwise the disability becomes total and permanent by operation of law. Here, the assessment issued was explicitly labeled as an interim grade and recommended further physical therapy, proving it was not the definitive declaration required by law to settle the condition of the seafarer. Hence, the respondents failure to issue a valid final assessment transforms the disability into a total and permanent one, rendering the lack of a third-doctor referral moot.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the petition is PARTIALLY GRANTED. The December 14, 2021 Decision and the January 4, 2023 Resolution of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 168160 are REVERSED and SET ASIDE insofar as it awarded USD 7,465.00 in disability benefits and PHP 98,559.00 in sickness allowance to petitioner Adan De Guzman Hisanza. Judgment is hereby rendered ORDERING respondents Bright Maritime Corporation and Navios Shipmanagement, Inc. to solidarily PAY Adan De Guzman Hisanza a disability benefit of USD 60,000.00 or its Philippine peso equivalent, and 10% of said amount as attorneys fees. The monetary awards shall earn interest at the rate of 6% per annum from the date of finality of this Decision until full payment.

digest.doctrine:
Conviction based on circumstantial evidence requires that the proven circumstances constitute an unbroken chain leading to one fair and reasonable conclusion that points to the accused to the exclusion of all others as the guilty person. Consequently, the identification of the accused is unreliable and insufficient to support a conviction when it relies on an unauthenticated CCTV footage where the perpetrators face was not visible and a highly suggestive show-up identification conducted weeks after the crime.

A person under custodial investigation has the constitutional right to counsel, and any extrajudicial confession extracted without such assistance is inadmissible even if made to a private individual if the questioning was initiated or facilitated by law enforcement. Therefore, the alleged confession made by the detained accused to the private complainant during a police-arranged confrontation is inadmissible as evidence for violating the constitutional right to counsel and the ban on uncounseled custodial admissions.
digest.facts: Accused Akil was charged with carnapping after the private complainant, Belardo, reported his motorcycle stolen and identified Akil as the culprit based on CCTV footage showing a man in specific clothing. Eighteen days after the incident, police arrested Akil for a different offense and arranged a confrontation at the station where Belardo identified him via a show-up and claimed Akil confessed to the crime, with police presenting items allegedly seized from Akil that matched the CCTV footage. Akil pleaded not guilty, denying ownership of the items and the confession, but the Regional Trial Court convicted him based on the circumstantial evidence and admission. The Court of Appeals affirmed the conviction, ruling that the chain of circumstances was sufficient and the confession to a private individual was valid.
digest.issue: Whether the prosecution proved the guilt of the accused beyond reasonable doubt based on the circumstantial evidence of identification and the extrajudicial confession.
digest.ruling: NO, the prosecution failed to prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt. Under the Rules on Evidence and the Constitution, circumstantial evidence must form an unbroken chain pointing solely to the accused, and confessions obtained during custodial investigation without counsel are inadmissible even if made to private persons if police-initiated. Here, the identification was unreliable due to the unauthenticated CCTV footage and suggestive show-up, while the alleged confession was void for lack of counsel during the police-arranged confrontation. Hence, the accused must be acquitted due to the insufficiency of the circumstantial evidence and the inadmissibility of his extrajudicial confession.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the appeal is GRANTED. The Decision dated August 30, 2022 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CR-HC No. 02496-MIN is REVERSED and SET ASIDE. For failure on the part of the prosecution to prove his guilt beyond reasonable doubt, accused-appellant Aron Akil y Guamalon is ACQUITTED of the crime charged in Criminal Case No. 5281-18. He is ORDERED IMMEDIATELY RELEASED from detention unless he is being detained for some other lawful cause. Let a copy of this Decision be furnished the Director General of the Bureau of Corrections for immediate implementation and to report the action he has taken to this Court within five days from receipt of this Decision. Let entry of judgment be ISSUED immediately.

digest.doctrine: Decisions rendered by the Regional Trial Court under Rule 40, Section 8, where it tries a case on the merits after finding the lower court lacked subject matter jurisdiction, are deemed promulgated in the exercise of its appellate jurisdiction rather than its original jurisdiction. Consequently, the proper mode of appeal to the Court of Appeals is via a petition for review under Rule 42, and an appeal taken by notice of appeal is erroneous and subject to dismissal.
digest.facts: Spouses Trinidad filed a forcible entry complaint against Reynaldo San Pedro which the Municipal Trial Court dismissed for failure to prove prior physical possession. On appeal, the Regional Trial Court ruled that the lower court lacked jurisdiction, assumed jurisdiction under Rule 40, Section 8 to try the case as if originally filed there, and eventually ordered Reynaldo to vacate the property,. Reynaldo challenged this decision before the Court of Appeals via a Notice of Appeal, but the appellate court dismissed it for being the wrong mode of appeal, prompting the present petition.
digest.issue: Whether the Court of Appeals correctly dismissed the appeal on the ground that the proper remedy from the RTC decision was a petition for review under Rule 42 rather than a notice of appeal.
digest.ruling: YES, the Court of Appeals correctly dismissed the appeal. Under Rule 41, Section 2(b) and Rule 50, Section 2 of the Rules of Court, an appeal from a judgment of the Regional Trial Court in the exercise of its appellate jurisdiction must be made via a petition for review under Rule 42, and utilizing a notice of appeal warrants dismissal. Here, the Supreme Court clarified that when a Regional Trial Court decides a case pursuant to Rule 40, Section 8, it still exercises appellate jurisdiction even if it tries the case as if originally filed with it. Hence, the petitioners use of a Notice of Appeal was fatal to his cause, rendering the Regional Trial Court decision final and executory.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Petition for Review on Certiorari is DENIED. The Resolutions dated January 11, 2023 and February 7, 2024 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 174613 are AFFIRMED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: An order denying a motion to dismiss is an interlocutory order that does not finally dispose of the case and is properly assailed via a petition for certiorari under Rule 65, while the issuance of a writ of possession in extrajudicial foreclosure is a ministerial duty that generally cannot be enjoined unless a third party proves adverse possession. Consequently, the appellate court erred in ruling that a Rule 45 petition was the proper remedy for the denial of the motion to dismiss, and the trial court validly issued the writ of possession because the intervenor failed to prove it held the property adversely to the judgment debtor.
digest.facts: Spouses Ramales filed a petition for annulment of foreclosure against Rural Bank of San Mateo without alleging the assessed value of the property, prompting the bank to move for dismissal for lack of jurisdiction, while in a related matter, the bank obtained a writ of possession over the foreclosed properties which Alvarez-Ramales School Foundation sought to enjoin by claiming ownership via donation. The Regional Trial Court denied the banks motion to dismiss in the first case and denied the foundations intervention in the second case, ruling that the writ of possession was ministerial. The Court of Appeals affirmed both rulings, dismissing the banks certiorari petition for being the wrong mode of appeal citing the Sunvar doctrine, and denying the foundations petition for failing to prove adverse possession.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the Court of Appeals erred in dismissing the banks petition for certiorari on the ground that the proper remedy was a petition for review under Rule 45.

2. Whether the trial court committed grave abuse of discretion in denying the foundations motion to intervene and issuing the writ of possession.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the dismissal was ultimately correct but the legal reasoning of the appellate court regarding the mode of appeal was erroneous. Under the Rules of Court, an order denying a motion to dismiss is interlocutory and unappealable, making a special civil action for certiorari under Rule 65 the proper remedy, whereas a Rule 45 petition applies to final judgments on questions of law. Here, the trial court did not abuse its discretion because the jurisdiction over the real action was determinable from the tax declarations attached to the complaint, rendering the denial of the motion to dismiss valid. Hence, the petition was properly dismissed for lack of merit despite the appellate courts incorrect invocation of the Sunvar ruling.

2. NO, the trial court did not commit grave abuse of discretion. Under the rule on extrajudicial foreclosure, the issuance of a writ of possession is ministerial and can only be enjoined if a third party possesses the property adversely to the judgment debtor. Here, the foundation failed to substantiate its third-party claim as it did not present witnesses to prove the donation and merely held the property as a successor-in-interest of the debtors rather than in its own right. Hence, the denial of the motion to intervene and the issuance of the writ of possession were valid.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Petitions for Review on Certiorari are DENIED for lack of merit. The February 10, 2020 Decision and January 6, 2021 Resolution of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 153530, as assailed in G.R. No. 256021, as well as the February 22, 2023 Decision and the July 26, 2023 Resolution of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 166173, questioned in G.R. No. 268716, are AFFIRMED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Lawyers are prohibited from engaging in forum shopping by instituting multiple suits involving the same parties and issues to secure a favorable judgment, and from abusing court processes by filing frivolous motions such as unjustified motions for inhibition. Consequently, the respondent is administratively liable for willful forum shopping and abuse of court processes when he files simultaneous pleadings in different courts seeking the same suspension of proceedings and moves to inhibit judges solely due to adverse rulings, warranting disciplinary sanctions under the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability.
digest.facts: Wilma Zamora filed a disbarment complaint against Atty. Makilito Mahinay arising from intra-corporate disputes where Mahinay represented the opposing faction. Zamora alleged that Mahinay engaged in forum shopping by filing a Motion to Suspend Proceedings and a Petition for Certiorari in separate courts seeking the same relief, abused court processes by moving for the inhibition of judges who issued adverse rulings, and made unjust accusations in his pleadings claiming Zamoras lawyers were plotting to assassinate him. The Integrated Bar of the Philippines Commission on Bar Discipline recommended suspension for the unjust accusations and admonition for abuse of court processes, but the Board of Governors modified this by dismissing the abuse of court process charge while upholding the suspension for the accusations.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the respondent is guilty of forum shopping and abuse of court processes.

2. Whether the respondent is guilty of making unjust and unfair accusations against other members of the Bar.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the respondent is guilty. Under the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability, lawyers are prohibited from knowingly engaging in forum shopping and from abusing court processes by filing frivolous suits or motions. Here, the respondent filed pleadings in both the Municipal Trial Court and Regional Trial Court praying for the same remedy of suspending proceedings, and filed motions for inhibition against judges solely because of their unfavorable rulings. Hence, the respondent is suspended for one year for forum shopping and fined for abuse of court processes.

2. YES, the respondent is guilty. Under the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability, a lawyer must act with courtesy, civility, fairness, and candor towards fellow members of the bar and shall not use language that is abusive, intemperate, or offensive. Here, the respondent imputed a crime against opposing counsel by stating in his pleadings that they were persons of interest in an alleged assassination plot against him without any material relevance to the case. Hence, the respondent is fined for violating the canons on dignified conduct.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Court finds Atty. Makilito B. Mahinay GUILTY of violating Canon II, Sections 2, 4 and 23 and Canon III, Section 7 of A.M. No. 22-09-01-SC, or the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability. From the foregoing and considering the presence of two aggravating circumstances, i.e. previous administrative liability and lack of remorse, he is hereby meted out the following penalties for each offense: (a) For willful and deliberate forum shopping in violation of Canon II, Section 23, Atty. Makilito B. Mahinay is SUSPENDED from the practice of law for a period of one year; (b) For abuse of court processes in filing frivolous motions for inhibition, in violation of Canon III, Section 7, Atty. Makilito B. Mahinay is hereby FINED PHP 35,000.00; and (c) For violation of Canon II, Sections 2 and 4, Atty. Makilito B. Mahinay is hereby FINED PHP 100,000.00. Atty. Makilito B. Mahinay is WARNED that a repetition of the same or similar offenses in the future shall be dealt with more severely. He is DIRECTED to file a Manifestation to the Court that his suspension has started, copy furnished all courts and quasi-judicial bodies where he has entered his appearance as counsel. Let copies of this Decision be furnished to the Office of the Bar Confidant, to be appended to the personal record of Atty. Makilito B. Mahinay, as an attorney-at-law; to the Integrated Bar of the Philippines; and to the Office of the Court Administrator for dissemination to all courts throughout the country for their guidance and information.

digest.doctrine: The Statute of Frauds requiring contracts for the sale of real property to be in writing applies only to executory contracts and not to those that have been partially or totally executed, as the acceptance of benefits or performance of acts such as the delivery of possession serves as sufficient evidence of the agreement. Consequently, the oral sale of the disputed property is valid and enforceable against the heirs of the seller because the buyers continuous possession, introduction of improvements, and custody of the owners duplicate title demonstrate that the contract was executed, thereby rendering parol evidence admissible to prove the transfer of ownership.
digest.facts: Respondents Noblesa and Ernesto, heirs of the registered owner Marcos, filed an action for recovery of possession against petitioners Benedicto and Daisy, who had occupied the subject lot since 1982 and possessed the owners duplicate title based on an alleged oral sale made by Marcos in 1972. Petitioners claimed they paid the initial installment to Marcos and the balance to his brother Marcelo after Marcos died, presenting witnesses and tax receipts to prove the sale and their long-standing possession, while respondents argued the sale was unenforceable under the Statute of Frauds and that payments to Marcelo were invalid. The Municipal Trial Court and Regional Trial Court ruled in favor of respondents, holding that the registered title prevailed over the unwritten sale and that Marcelo lacked authority to receive payments. The Court of Appeals affirmed the lower courts decisions, ruling that the sale was not sufficiently proven and that the petitioners acted in bad faith.
digest.issue: Whether the oral contract of sale is valid and enforceable against the heirs of the registered owner despite the absence of a written instrument.
digest.ruling: YES, the oral contract of sale is valid and enforceable. Under Articles 1403 and 1405 of the Civil Code and established jurisprudence, the requirement that a sale of real property be in writing is for enforceability, not validity, and does not apply to contracts that are partially or totally executed through acts such as the delivery of the property or title. Here, the petitioners proved the sale was executed through their continuous possession since 1982, the delivery of the title certificate to them, and the testimonial evidence of payment, which rendered the Statute of Frauds inapplicable. Hence, the petitioners are the lawful owners of the property, subject to the payment of the remaining balance to the proper heirs since the payments made to the unauthorized uncle were void.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the petition is GRANTED. The September 27, 2019 Decision and the February 5, 2021 Resolution of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP. No. 156620 are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. Petitioners Benedicto Batara Ocampo and Daisy Garcia-Ocampo are hereby ORDERED to PAY respondents Noblesa Batara-Sapad and Ernesto C. Batara the sum of PHP 37,000.00 plus interest at the legal rate of 12% per annum from December 31, 1982 until June 30, 2013, and 6% per annum from July 1, 2013 until full payment. The interest due on the purchase price shall likewise earn interest at the legal rate of 12% per annum from December 31, 1982 until June 30, 2013, and 6% per annum from July 1, 2013 until full payment. Upon full payment by petitioners Benedicto Batara Ocampo and Daisy Garcia-Ocampo of the amount due as decreed in this Decision, respondents Noblesa Batara-Sapad and Ernesto C. Batara are hereby ORDERED to EXECUTE a deed of sale over the parcel of land covered by Transfer Certificate of Title No. NT-41863.

digest.doctrine: Judicial review of Construction Industry Arbitration Commission awards regarding factual issues is strictly limited to the special civil action for certiorari under Rule 65 before the Court of Appeals, grounded solely on challenges to the integrity of the arbitral tribunal, such as allegations of corruption, fraud, or evident partiality, or violations of the Constitution or positive law. Consequently, the appellate court errs in conducting a factual review and vacating an arbitral award when the petitioner fails to make a sufficient and demonstrable showing that the tribunals integrity was compromised, as courts must exercise judicial restraint and deference to avoid defeating the purpose of arbitration.
digest.facts: Grand Exploit Builder Development, Inc. and Hoegaarden Realty Corporation entered into three construction contracts, but disputes arose leading Hoegaarden to file a request for arbitration with the Construction Industry Arbitration Commission claiming overpayment and damages, to which the contractor counterclaimed for unpaid billings and the value of appropriated equipment. The Arbitral Tribunal rendered a Final Award in favor of the contractor, ruling that Hoegaarden failed to prove overpayment and was liable for appropriating the contractors tools, prompting Hoegaarden to file a Rule 65 petition with the Court of Appeals alleging evident partiality by the tribunal regarding the admission of evidence and the monetary awards. The Court of Appeals granted the petition, vacating the award on the ground of evident partiality and remanding the case for rehearing, which the contractor challenged via a Rule 45 petition to the Supreme Court.
digest.issue: Whether the Court of Appeals erred in ruling that the CIAC Arbitral Tribunal acted with evident partiality and in vacating the Final Award.
digest.ruling: YES, the Court of Appeals erred. Under the guidelines established in Global Medical Center of Laguna, Inc. v. Ross Systems International, Inc., while factual issues regarding the integrity of the arbitral tribunal may be raised via Rule 65, the Court of Appeals may conduct a factual review only upon a sufficient and demonstrable showing that the tribunals integrity was indeed compromised or that it committed illegal acts. Here, the Supreme Court found that the CIAC Arbitral Tribunal did not manifest bias as it actually allowed the respondent to submit evidence, penalized the petitioner for procedural lapses, and based its monetary award for appropriated tools on the respondents own admissions and the law. Hence, the appellate court went beyond its mandate of limited factual review and the Final Award must be reinstated.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Petition for Review on Certiorari dated June 26, 2023 filed by Grand Exploit Builder Development, Inc. assailing the Decision dated June 7, 2023 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 177813 is REVERSED and SET ASIDE and the Final Award dated February 27, 2023 of the Construction Industry Arbitration Commission is REINSTATED.

digest.doctrine: The rule against conflict of interest prohibits a lawyer from representing inconsistent interests of two or more persons or representing a prospective client in a legal matter materially adverse to a former clients interests without written informed consent, regardless of whether confidential information was actually shared. Consequently, the respondents act of opposing a former clients trademark application and representing a party adverse to a company she previously served as counsel constitutes an intentional violation of the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability, warranting suspension from the practice of law.
digest.facts: Complainant Vera Law filed a disbarment complaint against respondent Atty. Hechanova, a former partner, alleging she used firm resources to promote herself, poached clients and lawyers, and represented conflicting interests. The complainant specifically averred that respondent opposed the trademark application of Gourdos Inc., a former client, and represented Newell et al. against AMSPEC, another client she handled while heading the firms IP department. The respondent denied the allegations, claiming her expulsion was illegal, the powers of attorney were limited, and no conflict existed as she only performed perfunctory tasks for AMSPEC. The IBP Board of Governors recommended a one-year suspension, modifying the Investigating Commissioners recommendation of three years.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the respondent is guilty of undignified conduct for recruiting lawyers from her firm while still a partner.

2. Whether the respondent is guilty of representing conflicting interests.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the respondent is guilty of undignified conduct. Under Canon II, Section 2 of the CPRA, a lawyer must act with courtesy, civility, fairness, and candor towards fellow members of the bar and avoid conduct that adversely reflects on their fitness to practice law. Here, the respondent clandestinely recruited two senior lawyers to join her new firm while still a partner at the complainant firm, which constituted a betrayal of trust and a failure to exercise the highest level of honesty towards her colleagues. Hence, she is liable for simple misconduct.

2. YES, the respondent is guilty of representing conflicting interests. Under Canon III, Sections 13 and 18 of the CPRA, a lawyer shall not represent conflicting interests except by written informed consent, which encompasses representing a prospective client in a legal matter materially adverse to a former clients interests. Here, the respondent opposed the trademark application of her former client Gourdos Inc. and represented a party adverse to AMSPEC, a client she previously advised as the head of the firms IP department, thereby violating her fiduciary obligation. Hence, she is suspended for intentional violation of the rule on conflict of interests.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Court finds respondent Atty. Editha R. Hechanova GUILTY of violating Canon II, Section 2 and Canon III, Sections 13 and 18 of A.M. No. 22-09-01-SC, or the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability. Considering the attendant circumstances, she is hereby meted out the following penalties for each offense: (a) For simple misconduct, Atty. Editha R. Hechanova is hereby FINED PHP 100,000.00; (b) For intentional violation of the rule on conflict of interests in relation to Gourdos Inc., Atty. Editha R. Hechanova is SUSPENDED from the practice of law for a period of six months and one day; and (c) For intentional violation of the rule on conflict of interests in relation to AMSPEC, Atty. Editha R. Hechanova is SUSPENDED from the practice of law for a period of six months and one day. Atty. Editha R. Hechanova is WARNED that a repetition of the same or similar offense in the future shall be dealt with more severely.

digest.doctrine: Judges may overrule the prosecutions objection to a plea bargaining proposal if said objection is based solely on inconsistency with internal Department of Justice guidelines, provided the proposal conforms to the Supreme Court framework, and under the Omnibus Motion Rule, the prosecution is deemed to have waived all other valid grounds for objection, such as recidivism or strong evidence of guilt, if it fails to raise them in its opposition. Consequently, the trial courts approval of a plea bargain is valid and must be reinstated when the prosecutions opposition is limited to non-conformity with internal circulars, as the failure to allege and prove other disqualifying circumstances precludes the reopening of the case for that purpose.
digest.facts: Petitioner Lo and his co-accused were charged with violations of Sections 5 and 12 of Republic Act No. 9165 and filed a proposal to plead guilty to the lesser offenses of Sections 12 and 15, which the prosecution opposed solely on the ground that it violated DOJ Circular No. 027 regarding acceptable plea bargains. The Regional Trial Court approved the plea bargain over the objection, convicted the accused of the lesser offenses, and granted their application for probation, ruling that the proposal conformed to the Supreme Court framework. The Court of Appeals, however, granted the prosecutions petition for certiorari and annulled the trial courts rulings, holding that the consent of the prosecutor is mandatory and the plea bargain could not proceed without it.
digest.issue: Whether the trial court validly approved the plea bargaining agreement over the objection of the prosecution which was based solely on internal DOJ guidelines.
digest.ruling: YES, the trial court validly approved the plea bargain. Under the guidelines established in Aquino v. People, judges may overrule the prosecutions objection if it is based solely on inconsistency with DOJ internal rules, and the prosecution is deemed to have waived other valid grounds for objection, such as recidivism or strong evidence of guilt, if it fails to raise them in its opposition. Here, the prosecution only objected based on the proposals non-conformity with DOJ Circular No. 027 and failed to present evidence on other disqualifying circumstances, meaning those grounds were waived. Hence, the trial courts approval of the plea bargain was within its sound discretion and must be reinstated.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the instant Petition for Review on Certiorari is GRANTED. The Decision dated November 10, 2020 and the Resolution dated December 1, 2021 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 161602 relative only to petitioner Anthony Arnaldo Lo @ White are both hereby SET ASIDE, and the following rulings of Branch 15, Regional Trial Court of Tabaco City, Albay, are hereby REINSTATED relative only to petitioner Anthony Arnaldo Lo @ White: 1) the Order dated March 15, 2019, which approved and granted the plea-bargaining proposal; 2) the Decision dated April 2, 2019, which convicted petitioner for the downgraded offenses; and 3) the Order dated April 15, 2019, which approved petitioners application for probation. Petitioner Anthony Arnaldo Lo @ White is also hereby ORDERED to submit to a drug dependency test pursuant to A.M. No. 18-03-16-SC (dated April 10, 2018), otherwise known as the Plea-Bargaining Framework in Drug Cases.

digest.doctrine: Disciplinary proceedings against lawyers are sui generis actions focused solely on the respondents fitness to practice law and are not the proper venue for the collection of civil debts, unless the money owed is intrinsically linked to the lawyer-client relationship. Consequently, the Court cannot grant a motion for execution to collect a sum of money in a disbarment case where the obligation arose from a loan incurred by a construction company and not the lawyer personally, as this constitutes a purely civil liability distinct from administrative accountability.
digest.facts: Spouses Palaganas filed an administrative complaint against Atty. Panganiban for issuing bouncing checks to secure a loan, which the IBP Board of Governors dismissed for lack of merit while paradoxically ordering Panganiban to pay the outstanding balance of PHP 87,058.00. After the Supreme Court initially closed the case in 2008, the spouses filed a motion for entry of judgment and writ of execution to enforce the monetary award, but the IBP refused to issue the writ stating it lacked authority. The case was elevated to the Supreme Court to resolve the motion, necessitating a review of the records which revealed that the checks were actually drawn by MLP Construction, a company owned by Panganibans wife, and not by Panganiban personally, although he signed them.
digest.issue: Whether the Supreme Court should issue a writ of execution to enforce the monetary award recommended by the IBP Board of Governors in the administrative case.
digest.ruling: NO, the motion is denied. Under Canon VI, Section 37 of the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability, the Court may only order the return of money in administrative proceedings if the obligation is intrinsically linked to the lawyer-client relationship. Here, the records established that no lawyer-client relationship existed between the parties and the debt was a corporate obligation of MLP Construction rather than a personal liability of the respondent. Hence, the administrative proceeding is not the proper forum for the collection of the debt and the respondent cannot be ordered to pay the amount.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Motion for Entry of Judgment and Issuance of Writ of Execution is DENIED. Respondent Atty. Mario P. Panganiban is hereby declared NOT ADMINISTRATIVELY LIABLE for violation of the Lawyers Oath and Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability. Lastly, this case is considered CLOSED and TERMINATED.

digest.doctrine: The prescriptive period for the crime of bigamy commences from the day on which the crime is discovered by the offended party, the authorities, or their agents, and not from the date of registration of the bigamous marriage, as the rule on constructive notice does not apply to this offense which is often committed in secrecy. Consequently, the prosecution of the accused is not barred by prescription even if the bigamous marriage was registered decades prior, provided the complaint was filed within the prescriptive period reckoned from the actual discovery of the multiple marriages by the private complainants.
digest.facts: Erwin Bonbon contracted a third marriage with Elizabeth Brua in 1999 while his 1988 marriage to Gemma Cunada was still subsisting, a fact discovered by his sisters only in 2020 through Philippine Statistics Authority records. Erwin defended that the action had prescribed based on alleged earlier knowledge by his family and that the 1999 marriage was void for lack of a marriage ceremony, claiming they only signed a blank contract. The Regional Trial Court convicted Erwin and Elizabeth of Bigamy, upholding the validity of the marriage certificate over Erwins bare allegations. The Court of Appeals affirmed the conviction, ruling that prescription runs from discovery and that the bigamous marriage was validly established by public documents.
digest.issue: Whether the prosecution for bigamy is barred by prescription and whether the guilt of the accused was proven beyond reasonable doubt.
digest.ruling: NO, the prosecution is not barred by prescription and the guilt of the accused was proven. Under Article 91 of the Revised Penal Code and established jurisprudence, the prescriptive period for bigamy runs from the discovery of the crime by the offended party or authorities, as the constructive notice rule from civil registration does not apply to bigamy cases. Here, the Court held that the prescriptive period began only upon the sisters discovery of the marriage records in 2020, and Erwin failed to present clear evidence to rebut the presumption of regularity of the marriage certificate to prove the marriage was void. Hence, the filing of the case in 2022 was timely and the conviction is sustained.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the instant Petition for Review on Certiorari is DENIED. The Decision dated September 8, 2023 and the Resolution dated January 19, 2024 of the Court of Appeals, Cagayan de Oro City, in CA-G.R. CR No. 02312-MIN are hereby AFFIRMED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Preventive suspension is a disciplinary measure justified only when the employees continued employment poses a serious and imminent threat to the life or property of the employer or co-workers pending investigation. Consequently, the suspension of the petitioner was valid because, at the time it was imposed, the ownership of the disputed computer programs had not yet been adjudicated, and his refusal to grant access posed a perceived threat to the employers property rights.
digest.facts: Petitioner Sillano, a Senior Engineer, was preventively suspended and then terminated by respondent JGC for refusing to unlock computer programs he created, claiming ownership over them against the companys claim of employer ownership. The Labor Arbiter dismissed the complaint for illegal dismissal, but the National Labor Relations Commission reversed this, ruling the dismissal illegal while upholding the validity of the preventive suspension and denying claims for damages and benefits. The Court of Appeals affirmed the decision, holding that the suspension was valid due to the threat posed to the companys perceived property pending the ownership dispute and that the claims for damages and benefits were unsubstantiated and raised belatedly.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the preventive suspension imposed on the petitioner was valid.

2. Whether the petitioner is entitled to moral and exemplary damages and other benefits.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the preventive suspension was valid. Under the Omnibus Rules Implementing the Labor Code, an employer may place a worker under preventive suspension if their continued employment poses a serious and imminent threat to the life or property of the employer or co-workers. Here, the Supreme Court found that at the time of suspension, the ownership of the computer programs was yet to be determined, making the petitioners refusal to turn over source codes a threat to what the employer reasonably deemed its property. Hence, the suspension did not violate the law as it was within the thirty-day limit and based on valid grounds pending the investigation.

2. NO, the petitioner is not entitled to damages and other benefits. The Supreme Court held that claims for damages and benefits must be supported by clear evidence and cannot be raised for the first time on appeal if they were not included in the original complaint or position papers. Here, the petitioner admitted to belatedly submitting evidence for the benefits and failed to prove the bad faith required for moral and exemplary damages, as the employers actions were based on a property dispute. Hence, the denial of these additional monetary claims was proper, subject only to the imposition of legal interest on the separation pay and backwages previously awarded.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Petition for Review is DENIED. The Decision and the Resolution dated July 31, 2023, and March 14, 2024, respectively, of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 165691 are AFFIRMED with MODIFICATION that the monetary award adjudged in favor of petitioner, Santiago dJ. Sillano, shall earn legal interest at the rate of 6% per annum from the date of the finality of this Decision until full payment.

digest.doctrine: Judges have the authority to overrule the prosecutions objection to a plea bargaining proposal if said objection is based solely on the ground that the proposal is inconsistent with internal Department of Justice guidelines, provided the proposal conforms to the Supreme Court Plea Bargaining Framework. Consequently, the trial court validly approved the accuseds plea bargain over the prosecutions objection because the opposition was anchored merely on non-compliance with DOJ Circular No. 027, which was inconsistent with the Courts framework and subsequently amended, and the prosecution failed to raise other valid grounds such as recidivism.
digest.facts: Petitioner Aguiling, charged with illegal sale and possession of dangerous drugs and paraphernalia under Republic Act No. 9165, filed a proposal to plead guilty to the lesser offenses of violation of Sections 12 and 15, which the prosecution opposed on the sole ground that DOJ Circular No. 027 did not allow pleading from Section 5 to Section 12. The Regional Trial Court granted the proposal over the objection, ruling that it conformed to the Supreme Courts framework in A.M. No. 18-03-16-SC, and convicted Aguiling of the lesser offenses. The Court of Appeals reversed the trial courts decision via certiorari, holding that the prosecutions consent is indispensable in plea bargaining and that the trial court committed grave abuse of discretion in overruling the objection without said consent.
digest.issue: Whether the trial court acted with grave abuse of discretion in approving the plea bargaining proposal over the prosecutions objection.
digest.ruling: NO, the trial court did not commit grave abuse of discretion. Under the guidelines established in Aquino v. People and People v. Montierro, judges may overrule the prosecutions objection if it is based solely on inconsistency with internal DOJ rules, and the prosecution is deemed to have waived other valid grounds like recidivism if not raised in their opposition pursuant to the Omnibus Motion Rule. Here, the prosecutions objection was anchored entirely on the proposals non-conformity with DOJ Circular No. 027, a ground which the trial court correctly overruled as the proposal was compliant with the Supreme Courts framework and the inconsistency was later cured by DOJ Circular No. 18. Hence, the trial courts decision to approve the plea bargain was a valid exercise of discretion and must be reinstated.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Petition for Review on Certiorari is GRANTED. The Decision dated February 23, 2021 and the Resolution dated June 22, 2022 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 12965 are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. The Orders dated April 15, 2019 and April 26, 2019, and the Decision dated May 6, 2019 of Branch 17 of the Regional Trial Court of Roxas City, Sixth Judicial Region in Criminal Case Nos. C-474-16, C-475-16, and C-476-16 are hereby REINSTATED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: The right to speedy disposition of cases is violated when there is inordinate delay in the conduct of preliminary investigation proceedings that is not justified by the prosecution, taking into account the length of delay, reasons for delay, assertion of the right, and prejudice to the accused. When a criminal case is dismissed due to a violation of this right, it amounts to an acquittal which bars further prosecution under the principle of double jeopardy. Consequently, the dismissal of the criminal charges is valid because the prosecution failed to provide sufficient justification for the delay of more than six years in the preliminary investigation which exceeded prescribed periods. Thus, the dismissal is final and the accused cannot be re-litigated as double jeopardy has already attached.
digest.facts: A complaint for graft and malversation was filed in 2017 against respondents Tumang and Colis regarding municipal purchases made in 2006, leading to a resolution finding probable cause in 2018 which was approved by the Ombudsman in 2019. However, the Ombudsman only resolved the respondents motions for reconsideration in 2024, causing the Informations to be filed in the Sandiganbayan more than six years after the initial complaint, prompting the respondents to move for dismissal on the ground of inordinate delay. The Sandiganbayan granted the motion to quash and dismissed the cases, ruling that the delay violated the respondents constitutional right to speedy disposition of cases and that the COVID-19 pandemic was an insufficient excuse given that the delay persisted well beyond the health crisis.
digest.issue: Whether the Sandiganbayan committed grave abuse of discretion in dismissing the criminal cases against the respondents on the ground of inordinate delay.
digest.ruling: NO, the Sandiganbayan did not commit grave abuse of discretion. Under the Constitution and established jurisprudence, the State must resolve criminal proceedings within reasonable periods, and delays beyond such periods shift the burden to the prosecution to prove that the delay was justified and caused no prejudice. Here, the preliminary investigation lasted over six years without valid justification, as the cited COVID-19 pandemic did not explain the inaction before and long after the health crisis, while the respondents timely asserted their rights and suffered actual prejudice from the uncertainty. Hence, the dismissal was proper and constitutes an acquittal that bars further prosecution under the rule on double jeopardy.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Petition for Certiorari dated August 8, 2024 is DISMISSED, and the Sandiganbayan First Divisions Resolution dated June 10, 2024 is AFFIRMED.

digest.doctrine: The exemption of wages from execution under the Civil Code and Rules of Court protects only manual laborers to ensure their subsistence and does not extend to public officials, whose salaries are liable to garnishment absent specific statutory immunity. Consequently, the garnishment of a city councilors salary is valid because he is a public official not covered by the exemption for laborers, and no law prohibits the satisfaction of his civil liability through his compensation.
digest.facts: Petitioner Bagbagen, a city councilor, was acquitted of estafa but held civilly liable to respondent Perez, resulting in a Notice of Garnishment against his salary account at Philippine Veterans Bank. Bagbagen moved to lift the notice claiming public officials salaries are exempt from garnishment, but the Regional Trial Court denied this, ruling that the funds ceased to be public funds once deposited. The Court of Appeals affirmed the denial, finding no grave abuse of discretion in allowing the garnishment of the petitioners salary.
digest.issue: Whether the salary of a public official is exempt from garnishment.
digest.ruling: NO, the salary is not exempt. Under Article 1708 of the Civil Code and Rule 39 of the Rules of Court, the exemption from execution applies strictly to laborers wages, referring to manual workers, and does not extend to public officials who lack specific statutory immunity. Here, the petitioner is a city councilor whose salary does not fall under the definition of laborers wages and is therefore available for execution to satisfy his judgment debt. Hence, the garnishment was properly upheld as no law exempts the compensation of public officials from such legal processes.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Petition for Review on Certiorari is hereby DENIED. The Decision dated August 18, 2023 and the Resolution dated April 15, 2024 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 164945 are hereby AFFIRMED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Proof of service by registered mail requires both the registry receipt issued by the mailing office and the affidavit of the person mailing to be considered valid, particularly when the addressee denies receipt. Consequently, the dismissal of an appeal based on a registry return receipt alone is invalid because, without the authenticating affidavit of the postmaster specifying the manner of delivery, the presumption of regularity in the performance of official duty cannot overcome the direct denial of receipt and substantial evidence to the contrary.
digest.facts: Petitioner Labastida, a municipal officer, was dismissed from service for gross neglect of duty via a decision dated June 10, 2016, which the Civil Service Commission and Court of Appeals ruled became final because she failed to appeal within fifteen days from June 14, 2016, the date the registry return receipt indicated she refused to accept the mail. Labastida argued she only received the decision on March 8, 2017 through a Commission on Audit notice and filed her appeal on March 16, 2017, contending the registry receipt was insufficient proof of service without a postmasters affidavit and pointing to a certification from the incumbent Mayor that no records of the case existed in the municipal office. The Civil Service Commission dismissed her appeal for being filed out of time, and the Court of Appeals affirmed this ruling, relying on the presumption of regularity of the postal service despite the lack of a postmasters affidavit.
digest.issue: Whether the Court of Appeals erred in ruling that the appeal was filed out of time based on the registry return receipt.
digest.ruling: YES, the Court of Appeals erred. Under Rule 13, Section 13 of the Rules of Civil Procedure applied suppletorily, proof of service by registered mail consists of the affidavit of the person mailing and the registry receipt, and the presumption of regularity does not apply when there is clear evidence to the contrary. Here, the respondent failed to present the required postmasters affidavit to authenticate the registry return receipt which bore a suspicious refusal notation, while the petitioner presented overwhelming evidence, including a certification from the Mayor, proving she did not receive the decision on the alleged date. Hence, the appeal filed within the reglementary period reckoned from actual receipt on March 8, 2017 was timely and must be given due course.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Petition for Review on Certiorari is GRANTED. The April 10, 2019 Decision and the January 23, 2020 Resolution of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CEB SP. No. 12157 affirming the December 19, 2017 and September 24, 2018 Orders of the Civil Service Commission, are hereby REVERSED and SET ASIDE. The case is remanded to the Civil Service Commission which is DIRECTED to give due course to the appeal of Victoria M. Labastida for a proper resolution on the merits with dispatch.

digest.doctrine: Every element constituting the offense must be alleged in the Information to satisfy the constitutional right of the accused to be informed of the nature and cause of the accusation, such that a failure to allege a specific spatial element renders the Information fatally defective regardless of the evidence presented at trial. Consequently, the accused cannot be convicted of violating the election gun ban under Section 32 of Republic Act No. 7166 when the Information failed to expressly allege that the firearm was carried in a public place, even if the prosecution later proved during trial that the incident occurred on a public highway.
digest.facts: Petitioner Baguinon, a security guard, was charged with violating the election gun ban under Section 32 of Republic Act No. 7166 for carrying a firearm during the 2004 election period following a traffic altercation where he fired shots at a tricycle driver. The Information alleged that he carried the firearm at Barangay 9 San Pedro, Paoay, Ilocos Norte, describing the location merely as outside his security agencys office rather than explicitly stating it was a public place. The Regional Trial Court convicted the petitioner, rejecting his defense of performance of duty and ruling that the gun ban exemption was not yet valid. The Court of Appeals affirmed the conviction, holding that the elements of the crime were established including the fact that the incident occurred on a street.
digest.issue: Whether the Information was sufficient to sustain a conviction for violation of Section 32 of Republic Act No. 7166 given the failure to allege the element of carrying the firearm in a public place.
digest.ruling: NO, the Information was insufficient. Under Article III, Section 14(2) of the Constitution and Rule 110 of the Rules of Court, every element of the offense must be alleged in the Information to enable the accused to prepare for their defense, and a variance between the allegation and proof is fatal if it involves an essential element. Here, the Information merely described the location as being outside the employers office without alleging that it was a public place, which is a specific essential element of Section 32 of Republic Act No. 7166 distinguishing it from other election offenses. Hence, despite evidence showing the incident happened on a highway, the failure to allege this essential element rendered the Information fatally defective, necessitating the petitioners acquittal.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the petition is GRANTED. The January 10, 2020 Decision and the February 8, 2021 Resolution of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CR No. 42567 are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. Petitioner Efren Sadiarin Baguinon, Sr. is hereby ACQUITTED.

digest.doctrine: In labor cases involving money claims, the burden of proving payment rests on the employer who has custody of pertinent personnel files and payroll records. Consequently, an employer fails to discharge this burden when the payroll documents presented are found to be dubious or forged, such as containing identical signatures and markings across different months, rendering them liable for the unpaid wages and benefits claimed by the employees.
digest.facts: Petitioners Maitim and her co-workers were hired by respondent Teknika Skills and Trade Services, Inc. for deployment to Saudi Arabia under contracts stipulating an eight-hour workday and USD 400.00 monthly salary, but were forced to sign inferior contracts upon departure and work twelve-hour shifts for less pay. They filed complaints for underpayment and benefits, which the Labor Arbiter partially granted, and the National Labor Relations Commission subsequently expanded to include overtime and food allowance after rejecting the respondents payrolls as forgeries. The Court of Appeals reversed the labor tribunals and dismissed the complaint, ruling that the payrolls were admissible because petitioners allegedly admitted the signatures were theirs, a finding the Supreme Court found unsupported by the records.
digest.issue: Whether the Court of Appeals erred in reversing the rulings of the labor tribunals and dismissing the petitioners money claims.
digest.ruling: YES, the Court of Appeals erred. Under established labor jurisprudence, the burden of proving payment of wages and benefits rests on the employer, and doubts arising from the evidence must be resolved in favor of the worker. Here, the Supreme Court found that the payroll records submitted by respondents were dubious and forged as they contained identical signatures and markings for different months, and the daily time records were incomplete and unsigned. Hence, the respondents failed to prove payment, justifying the reinstatement of the National Labor Relations Commissions award for salary differentials, overtime pay, and other benefits.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Petition is GRANTED. The Decision dated February 28, 2018 and the Resolution dated June 11, 2018 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 153484 are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. Resultantly, the Decision dated August 29, 2017 and the Resolution dated October 25, 2017 issued by the National Labor Relations Commission in NLRC LAC No. (OFW) 03-000241-17 are hereby REINSTATED with MODIFICATION. See full text for full disposition.

digest.doctrine: An order of reinstatement issued by a Labor Arbiter is immediately executory even pending appeal, obligating the employer to pay the wages of the dismissed employee from the time of the decision until a final reversal by a higher court, which refers to a reversal that is not subsequently set aside. Consequently, the employees are entitled to accrued reinstatement wages for the entire duration of the appeal proceedings, including any interim period where a tribunal temporarily reversed the illegal dismissal ruling before reinstating it on reconsideration, up until the date the appellate court renders the final reversal judgment.
digest.facts: Respondents filed complaints for illegal dismissal against petitioners, leading to a Labor Arbiter decision in their favor which was initially reversed by the NLRC on appeal but subsequently reinstated on reconsideration. The Court of Appeals later annulled the NLRCs reinstatement resolution and declared the dismissal valid in a decision that attained finality. Respondents moved for an Alias Writ of Execution to claim reinstatement wages for the pendency of the case, which the Labor Arbiter granted but excluded the interim period when the NLRC had temporarily reversed the illegal dismissal finding. The NLRC affirmed the computation of wages, and the Court of Appeals subsequently upheld the entitlement to wages for the periods the reinstatement order was deemed effective.
digest.issue: Whether the respondents are entitled to reinstatement wages for the entire period from the Labor Arbiters decision until the Court of Appeals final reversal, including the interim period of temporary reversal by the NLRC.
digest.ruling: YES, the respondents are entitled to reinstatement wages for the entire period. Under Article 229 of the Labor Code and established jurisprudence, an employer must reinstate and pay the wages of a dismissed employee during the period of appeal until the final reversal by a higher court, which implies a reversal that is not later set aside. Here, the Supreme Court held that the NLRCs initial reversal was not final as it was set aside by the NLRC itself on reconsideration, meaning the reinstatement order remained legally effective until the Court of Appeals ultimately reversed it on June 30, 2015. Hence, petitioners are liable for reinstatement wages covering the continuous period from November 25, 2013 to June 30, 2015.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, in view of the foregoing premises, the Petition for Review on Certiorari is DENIED. The Court of Appeals Decision dated March 14, 2019, in CA-G.R. SP No. 151070 is AFFIRMED with MODIFICATION. The Labor Arbiter's Order dated August 30, 2016 is MODIFIED in that respondents Romeo M. Jaranilla, Marlon H. Guantero, and Jesus B. Domanais are entitled to reinstatement wages from November 25, 2013 to June 30, 2015. Let an Alias Writ of Execution be ISSUED to such effect. The Labor Arbiter is further DIRECTED to make a re-computation of the amount of respondents' reinstatement wages for the said period and determine whether the amounts already released to respondents exceed or are less than the amounts that respondents are entitled to. Thereafter, the Labor Arbiter is DIRECTED to collect from petitioners the amount necessary for the full satisfaction of their reinstatement wages or return to petitioners any excess thereof. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine:
Section 3(e) of Republic Act No. 3019 penalizes two distinct actsâ€”causing undue injury or granting unwarranted benefitsâ€”and an accused cannot be convicted for a mode of committing the offense that was not alleged in the Information without violating their constitutional right to be informed of the nature and cause of the accusation. Consequently, the conviction of the accused for granting unwarranted benefits is invalid because the Information charged them solely with causing undue injury, and the prosecution presented no evidence regarding the specific beneficiaries of such alleged benefits.

Undue injury in Section 3(e) of Republic Act No. 3019 signifies actual damage that must be specified, quantified, and proven to the point of moral certainty, such that the mere absence of public bidding does not automatically equate to actual loss to the government. Consequently, the accused must be acquitted because the prosecution failed to provide a reference price or evidence that the projects could have been built at a lower cost, and the completed projects utilizing donated funds negatived claims of actual damage to the government.
digest.facts: Mayor Lupoyon and other municipal officials of Barlig, Mountain Province, were charged with violation of Section 3(e) of Republic Act No. 3019 for implementing a pathway and an open gymnasium project using funds donated by GMA Network and ABS-CBN without conducting public bidding. The officials transferred the donated funds from the municipal trust fund to a different account, believing the private donations were outside state audit jurisdiction, and directly administered the construction to maximize the funds by utilizing local labor. The Sandiganbayan convicted the accused, ruling that the lack of public bidding caused undue injury to the government by depriving it of the most advantageous price and granted unwarranted benefits to suppliers.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the accused can be convicted of granting unwarranted benefits when the Information only alleged causing undue injury.

2. Whether the prosecution proved the element of undue injury to the government beyond reasonable doubt.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the accused cannot be convicted of granting unwarranted benefits. Under established jurisprudence and the constitutional right of the accused to be informed of the nature of the accusation, the two modes of violating Section 3(e) of Republic Act No. 3019â€”causing undue injury and granting unwarranted benefitsâ€”are distinct, and an accused cannot be convicted under a mode not alleged in the Information. Here, the Informations specifically charged the accused only with causing undue injury, and the prosecution failed to present evidence regarding any specific party who received unwarranted benefits. Hence, the Sandiganbayan erred in convicting the accused based on the unalleged act of granting unwarranted benefits.

2. NO, the prosecution failed to prove undue injury. Under Section 3(e) of Republic Act No. 3019, undue injury equates to actual damage which must be specified, quantified, and proven to the point of moral certainty, and cannot be presumed solely from the absence of public bidding. Here, the prosecution failed to present a reference price to show that the projects could have been implemented at a lower cost had they been bid out, and the projects were actually completed and used by the community using the donated funds. Hence, the acquittal of the accused is warranted as the element of undue injury was not established beyond reasonable doubt.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, this appeal is GRANTED. The February 26, 2021 Decision and the September 20, 2021 Resolution of the Sandiganbayan in Criminal Case Nos. SB-16-CRM-0323 to 0324 are hereby REVERSED and SET ASIDE. Accused-appellants Magdalena K. Lupoyon, Albert Tenglab Marafo, Edmundo Challiis Sidchayao, Clark Chatongna Ngaya, Fernando Yacam-ma Cablog, and Danilo Rabina Lucas are ACQUITTED. The hold departure orders against them are LIFTED. Any amount paid by way of a bail bond is ordered RETURNED. Let entry of judgment be issued immediately. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: While the sixty-day period for filing a petition for certiorari is generally inextendible, courts may grant an extension for compelling reasons or when the gross negligence of counsel deprives the client of due process, necessitating a relaxation of procedural rules to serve the interests of substantial justice. Consequently, the dismissal of the petition is invalid because the failure to file on time was caused by the abrupt abandonment of the petitioners counsel, which constitutes a compelling circumstance given that the petitioners are minimum wage earners who cannot readily secure new legal representation.
digest.facts: Petitioners, who were former laborers at a feed mill plant, filed a complaint for illegal dismissal against respondents San Miguel Foods, Inc. and Hua Tong Far East Inc., claiming the former was their true employer. The Labor Arbiter dismissed the complaint for lack of employer-employee relationship with San Miguel and lack of merit against Hua Tong, a decision affirmed by the National Labor Relations Commission which subsequently denied the petitioners motion for reconsideration. The petitioners had until December 10, 2022 to file a petition for certiorari, but due to their counsels alleged abandonment despite payment of fees, they filed a motion for extension on December 5, 2022 and the petition itself on January 10, 2023 through new counsel. The Court of Appeals denied the motion for extension and dismissed the petition, ruling that the petitioners excuse regarding their counsel was insufficient and that they failed to exert enough effort to meet the deadline.
digest.issue: Whether the Court of Appeals erred in dismissing the petition for certiorari by denying the motion for extension of time.
digest.ruling: YES, the Court of Appeals erred. Under established jurisprudence, while the sixty-day period for certiorari is generally strict, exceptions exist for compelling reasons or when the gross negligence of counsel deprives the client of due process, especially where the interests of justice so require. Here, the Supreme Court found that the abrupt abandonment by the petitioners counsel, coupled with their status as minimum wage earners who cannot readily secure new legal services, constituted a compelling circumstance to relax the rules. Hence, the petition should be reinstated to prevent a miscarriage of justice and to uphold the petitioners right to be heard.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Petition for Review on Certiorari is GRANTED. The Resolutions dated January 16, 2023 and May 26, 2023 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 176393 are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. CA-G.R. SP No. 176393 is hereby REINSTATED, with instructions for the Court of Appeals to process and resolve the same with deliberate dispatch. Let a copy of this Decision be furnished to the Commission on Bar Discipline of the Integrated Bar of the Philippines, which is hereby DIRECTED to investigate Atty. Geneses R. Abot for his administrative liability as a member of the Bar, if any. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Republic Act No. 7890 expressly repealed Section 261(d) of the Omnibus Election Code regarding coercion of subordinates, thereby removing it as a ground for disqualification, yet Section 261(e) remains a valid ground penalizing the use of threats, intimidation, or fraudulent devices to compel or induce participation in an election campaign. Consequently, while the petitioner could not be disqualified under the repealed Section 261(d), his disqualification was validly sustained under Section 261(e) because substantial evidence established that he employed a fraudulent scheme involving the unauthorized use of government resources and exercised inherent intimidation over a casual employee to print campaign materials.
digest.facts: Petitioner Noveras, the incumbent Governor of Aurora running for Vice-Governor, was subjected to a disqualification petition by respondent Amansec after the latter witnessed a casual government employee printing Noveras campaign materials inside the provincial training center using government equipment. Amansec originally filed the petition based on Section 261(o) regarding the use of public facilities, but the COMELEC First Division disqualified Noveras under Section 261(d) for coercing a subordinate, a ruling the COMELEC En Banc affirmed while adding Section 261(e) as a ground based on the use of fraudulent schemes and threats. Noveras filed a petition for certiorari arguing that Section 261(d) had been repealed by Republic Act No. 7890 and that there was no evidence linking him to the act to justify a violation of Section 261(e).
digest.issue:
1. Whether Section 261(d) of the Omnibus Election Code serves as a valid ground for disqualification despite Republic Act No. 7890.

2. Whether the petitioner was correctly disqualified under Section 261(e) of the Omnibus Election Code.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, Section 261(d) is not a valid ground. Under Section 2 of Republic Act No. 7890, Section 261(d) of the Omnibus Election Code was expressly repealed, removing it from the corpus of statutory law and excluding it as a predicate offense for disqualification under Section 68. Here, the COMELEC erred in initially disqualifying the petitioner based on Section 261(d) as the provision had ceased to have legal effect and could not support the administrative action. Hence, the disqualification cannot be sustained on this specific ground.

2. YES, the petitioner was correctly disqualified under Section 261(e). Under this provision, it is an election offense to use fraudulent schemes or intimidation to induce participation in a campaign, and findings of fact by the COMELEC are final if supported by substantial evidence. Here, the unauthorized use of government premises and the casual employees submission to the Governor's inherent moral ascendancy constituted a fraudulent scheme and indirect intimidation calculated to aid the petitioners campaign. Hence, the disqualification is valid based on the violation of Section 261(e).
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the present petition is DISMISSED. The September 6, 2023 Resolution of the Commission on Elections En Banc in SPA Case No. 22-048 (DC) is AFFIRMED insofar as it disqualified petitioner Gerardo Jerry A. Noveras from standing as a candidate in the May 9, 2022 National and Local Elections, on the basis of Section 261(e) of Batas Pambansa Blg. 881, as amended. See full text for full disposition.

digest.doctrine: A search warrant must be issued in connection with one specific offense to prevent the issuance of scatter-shot warrants, and violations of distinct special laws cannot be lumped together in a single warrant even if they were previously covered by the same decree. However, the inclusion of items belonging to an unrelated offense does not automatically invalidate the entire warrant, as the court may apply the principle of severability to uphold the valid portion supported by probable cause while excluding the evidence seized under the invalid portion.
digest.facts: Search Warrant No. 0015-2019 was issued against petitioner Puguon for a violation of Republic Act No. 10591, authorizing the seizure of various firearms and two hand grenades, the latter of which are punishable under a separate law, Republic Act No. 9516. Puguon moved to quash the warrant as a scatter-shot warrant, but the Regional Trial Court denied the motion, ruling that the offenses belonged to the same class under Presidential Decree No. 1866.
