The Court of Appeals affirmed the denial, holding that the laws merely changed penalties and remained related offenses that could be covered by a single warrant.
digest.issue: Whether the search warrant is valid despite covering items punishable under two separate special laws.
digest.ruling: PARTIALLY YES, the warrant is valid but only insofar as the firearms are concerned. Under Rule 126, Section 4 of the Rules of Court, a search warrant must issue in connection with one specific offense, and Republic Act No. 10591 is a distinct law from Republic Act No. 9516, meaning a single warrant cannot validly cover violations of both. Here, the Supreme Court applied the principle of severability, ruling that the improper inclusion of the grenades did not invalidate the finding of probable cause for the firearms. Hence, the warrant is valid for the firearms charge, but the case for illegal possession of explosives must be dismissed as the evidence seized therefor is inadmissible.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Petition for Review on Certiorari is PARTIALLY GRANTED. The Decision dated June 30, 2021 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 164326 is AFFIRMED with MODIFICATION. Search Warrant No. 0015-2019, issued by Branch 31 of the Regional Trial Court of Cabarroguis, Quirino, is declared VALID insofar as the evidence obtained in relation to Criminal Case No. 3901-2019 is concerned. However, Criminal Case No. 3902-2019 filed against petitioner Jimmy B. Puguon, Jr., is ordered DISMISSED and all pieces of evidence collected in relation thereto are deemed inadmissible in any criminal or other proceeding. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Section 3, Rule IV of the 2004 Rules on Notarial Practice disqualifies a notary public from performing a notarial act if they or their relatives within the fourth civil degree will receive any direct or indirect commission, fee, advantage, right, title, interest, cash, property, or other consideration from the instrument. Consequently, the respondents notarization of a Special Power of Attorney is invalid and constitutes an ethical violation because it facilitated the transfer of property rights to his own children, thereby bestowing upon them a prohibited indirect benefit resulting from his official act.
digest.facts: Complainant Malapit hired respondent Atty. Watin to prepare a Special Power of Attorney for her agent Petronila but later discovered the document was notarized despite her alleged refusal to sign and was used to sell her properties, with some lots being acquired by respondents own wife and children. Malapit filed criminal cases against Petronila where respondent acted as defense counsel, leading her to file this administrative complaint alleging that respondent violated notarial rules by benefiting from the document and representing conflicting interests. The IBP Board of Governors affirmed the Investigating Commissioners recommendation to suspend the respondent for two years, finding him guilty of misconduct for the indirect benefits his family received and for representing the agent in cases questioning the validity of the document he prepared for the complainant.
digest.issue: Whether the respondent is administratively liable for violating the Rules on Notarial Practice and the rule on conflict of interest.
digest.ruling: YES, the respondent is administratively liable. Under Section 3 of the 2004 Rules on Notarial Practice and Canon III of the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability, a notary is disqualified from performing acts that yield indirect benefits to his relatives, and a lawyer cannot represent conflicting interests without written informed consent. Here, the respondent notarized a Special Power of Attorney that enabled his children to acquire property rights, creating a prohibited indirect benefit, and he improperly represented the agent in legal actions involving the very instrument he had previously drafted for the complainant. Hence, the respondent committed serious offenses warranting his suspension from the practice of law and disqualification as a notary public.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Court finds respondent Atty. Rogelio M. Watin GUILTY of violating the 2004 Rules on Notarial Practice and the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability. He is meted the penalties of SUSPENSION from the practice of law for TWO YEARS, REVOCATION of his existing notarial commission, if any, and DISQUALIFICATION from reappointment as notary public for a period of TWO YEARS, which is to take effect after he has served the penalty of two-year suspension from the practice of law. He is also STERNLY WARNED that a repetition of the same offense or similar acts in the future shall be dealt with more severely. The suspension from the practice of law shall take effect immediately upon respondents receipt of this Decision. See full text for full disposition.

digest.doctrine: Under Article 177 of the Revised Penal Code, the crime of usurpation of official functions requires the performance of an act pertaining to a person in authority or public officer under pretense of official position, and strictly construed, a lawyer is not deemed a person in authority under Article 152 except for purposes of direct assault and resistance to authority. Consequently, the accused cannot be convicted of usurpation of official functions for falsely representing himself as a lawyer and appearing in court, as the private practice of law does not vest one with jurisdiction or make one an agent of a person in authority for the purposes of Article 177.
digest.facts: Petitioner Pedro Pequero, whose birth name was registered as such, publicly represented himself as Atty. Epafrodito Nollora, a deceased lawyer, appearing as counsel in various cases and signing pleadings. Following a complaint, NBI agents conducted an entrapment operation where Pedro was apprehended while appearing for a client in the Municipal Trial Court. The Municipal Trial Court convicted him of use of illegal alias, use of fictitious name, and usurpation of authority, findings which were affirmed in toto by the Regional Trial Court. The Court of Appeals likewise affirmed the conviction, ruling that his acts of representing himself as a lawyer constituted usurpation of authority and that he had no authority to use the alias or the name of the deceased lawyer.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the petitioner is guilty of usurpation of official functions under Article 177 of the Revised Penal Code.

2. Whether the petitioner is guilty of using a fictitious name under Article 178 of the Revised Penal Code.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the petitioner is not guilty of usurpation of official functions. Under Article 177 in relation to Article 152 of the Revised Penal Code, a lawyer is not considered a person in authority or a public officer for the purpose of usurpation, as they are not directly vested with jurisdiction or charged with the maintenance of public order. Here, although the petitioner falsely represented himself as a lawyer and performed acts of a legal counsel, these acts do not pertain to a person in authority or public officer within the specific context of Article 177. Hence, the petitioner must be acquitted of the charge of usurpation of official functions.

2. YES, the petitioner is guilty of using a fictitious name. Under Article 178 of the Revised Penal Code, the penalty of arresto mayor shall be imposed upon any person who publicly uses a fictitious name for the purpose of causing damage. Here, the petitioner publicly used the name of a deceased lawyer to represent clients, thereby deceiving the public and causing damage to his paying clients who believed they were represented by a genuine lawyer. Hence, his conviction is proper, but the penalty is modified to arresto mayor in accordance with the retroactive application of Republic Act No. 10951.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Petition for Review on Certiorari is PARTIALLY GRANTED. The Joint Decision of the Municipal Trial Court in Criminal Case Nos. 11-252, 11-253 and 11-254, as affirmed by the Regional Trial Court and the Court of Appeals in its Decision dated March 23, 2022 and Resolution dated September 19, 2022 in CA-G.R. CR No. 44373, is MODIFIED in that: (i) in Criminal Case No. 11-253 for use of fictitious name, Pedro Pequero y Nollora is found GUILTY beyond reasonable doubt of use of fictitious name (Article 178, Paragraph 1 of the Revised Penal Code, as amended by Republic Act No. 10951) and is hereby sentenced to imprisonment of four months of arresto mayor, including all its accessory penalty as prescribed by law and to pay a FINE of PHP 500.00, with subsidiary imprisonment for nonpayment; and (ii) in Criminal Case No. 11-254 for usurpation of authority or official function, Pedro Pequero y Nollora is ACQUITTED of the crime of usurpation of official functions as defined and penalized under Article 177 of the Revised Penal Code. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: The recruitment, transportation, transfer, harboring, or receipt of a child for the purpose of exploitation shall be considered as trafficking in persons even if it does not involve any of the means set forth in the law, such as threat, use of force, or coercion, because the consent of the minor is irrelevant and immaterial. The crime is committed when the offender recruits the victim for the purpose of sexual exploitation, and the non-presentation of the specific equipment used, such as a computer, is not a prerequisite for conviction where the testimonial evidence of the victims is credible and sufficient to establish the guilt of the accused beyond reasonable doubt.
digest.facts: Two informations for violation of Section 4(e) of Republic Act No. 9208 were filed against Roxin Grace Batomalaque. The prosecution evidence showed that Batomalaque recruited AAA, a six-year-old child, and BBB, a seventeen-year-old working student, to her house. Inside a locked room equipped with a computer and camera, Batomalaque instructed them to perform sexual acts, including masturbation, oral sex, and intercourse, often with other minors, while being broadcast to foreigners via the internet. Batomalaque paid the victims minimal amounts after these sessions. A search warrant implemented by the NBI yielded computer paraphernalia and sex-related videos, although the computer was not functioning at the time of the search. Batomalaque denied the accusations, claiming she was in Ozamis City during the material dates and that the charges were extortive. The RTC convicted her, giving full faith to the testimonies of the victims. The CA affirmed the conviction with modification as to the interest on the damages.
digest.issue: Whether the CA erred in affirming the conviction of the accused-appellant for Qualified Trafficking in Persons.
digest.ruling: No. The Supreme Court found the appeal bereft of merit and affirmed the conviction. The Court held that the prosecution successfully established all the elements of trafficking in persons. Under the law, the recruitment of a child for exploitation constitutes trafficking even without the use of coercion or deception, as a minor cannot give valid consent. The Court found the testimonies of the victims to be categorical, consistent, and credible, detailing the sexual acts they were forced to perform. These positive identifications and narratives prevailed over the accused-appellant's defenses of denial and alibi, which are weak defenses especially when not substantiated by clear and convincing evidence. The Court also ruled that the failure to present the computer unit as evidence was not fatal to the case, as the commission of the crime was adequately proved by the direct testimonies of the victims.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the appeal is DISMISSED. The Decision dated December 14, 2022 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CR-HC No. 01628-MIN is AFFIRMED.

digest.doctrine: Under Section 20(E) of the 2010 POEA-SEC, a seafarer is disqualified from claiming compensation only if they knowingly conceal a pre-existing illness, which requires proof of an intentional act to deceive rather than mere honest mistakes or inaccuracies by laypersons. Consequently, a seafarers failure to disclose a past diagnosis does not amount to fraudulent concealment when the rigorous pre-employment medical examinations conducted by the employer should have detected the condition and the seafarer subsequently admits the history to company doctors, thereby negating bad faith.
digest.facts: Petitioner Davantes, a seafarer employed by respondent C.F. Sharp Crew Management Inc., suffered a heart attack after an emergency drill and was repatriated, subsequently claiming total and permanent disability benefits after arguing that a prior settlement he received was unconscionably low. The respondents argued that Davantes was disqualified from receiving benefits because he failed to disclose a diagnosis of hypertension from 2010 during his Pre-Employment Medical Examination. The Labor Arbiter ruled in favor of Davantes, finding the quitclaim invalid, and the NLRC affirmed with modification, but the Court of Appeals reversed and dismissed the complaint, ruling that while the disability was total and permanent by operation of law due to the lack of a timely final assessment, the petitioner knowingly concealed his pre-existing hypertension.
digest.issue: Whether the petitioner is entitled to total and permanent disability benefits despite the alleged concealment of a pre-existing illness.
digest.ruling: YES, the petitioner is entitled to total and permanent disability benefits. Under Section 20(E) of the 2010 POEA-SEC, concealment of a pre-existing illness must be intentional to disqualify a seafarer from benefits, and failure to disclose is not concealment if the illness could have been detected by required medical examinations or if there is no intent to deceive. Here, the petitioner underwent a rigorous PEME C which should have revealed his hypertension, and his subsequent admission of the past diagnosis to the company physician immediately upon repatriation negates the intent to deceive required for concealment. Hence, the petitioner is entitled to full benefits as his failure to disclose was not a knowing concealment and the quitclaim he signed for a lower amount is invalid.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Petition for Review on Certiorari is GRANTED. The Decision dated October 20, 2021 and the Resolution dated March 7, 2022 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 167172 are ANNULLED and SET ASIDE. Respondents C.F. Sharp Crew Management Inc., Claus-Peter Offen Tankschiffreederei (GMBH & Co.) KG, and Miguel Rocha are ORDERED to JOINTLY AND SOLIDARILY PAY petitioner Paolo B. Davantes the following: (a) USD 60,000.00 or its peso equivalent representing his disability benefits under the 2010 Philippine Overseas Employment Administration-Standard Employment Contract, less the amount of USD 20,900.00 already received by petitioner Paolo B. Davantes; and (b) Attorneys fees equivalent to 10% of the total monetary award. The total monetary award shall be subject to interest rate of 6% per annum from the date of finality of this Decision until full payment. The Labor Arbiter is hereby ORDERED to make a computation of the total monetary awards due to petitioner Paolo B. Davantes in accordance with this Decision. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Mandamus will not lie to enforce the constitutional right to information if the petitioner fails to exhaust available administrative remedies provided by the government agency having custody of the records, as the doctrine of exhaustion requires utilizing administrative processes before seeking judicial intervention. Consequently, the petition for mandamus filed by the voters is dismissible because they failed to follow the specific procedures and appellate mechanisms prescribed in the Commission on Elections Freedom of Information Manual before rushing to the Court, thereby violating the rule on exhaustion of administrative remedies.
digest.facts: Petitioners, claiming to represent voters of Pangasinan, sent a document titled Apela to the Commission on Elections requesting a manual recount of the 2022 election results due to alleged fraud and anomalies, asserting this was an exercise of their right to information and a Peoples Initiative. The Commission on Elections Law Department responded that it had no jurisdiction over the Apela as it did not meet the requirements for an election protest or a valid initiative, prompting the petitioners to file a petition for certiorari and mandamus before the Supreme Court. They argued that the refusal to conduct a recount violated their constitutional rights of suffrage and information, while the respondent countered that the petition was procedurally defective for lack of verification, standing, and merit, as there is no legal right to a manual recount outside of an election protest.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the remedy of mandamus lies to compel the Commission on Elections to conduct a manual recount based on the petitioners right to information.

2. Whether the petitioners failed to exhaust administrative remedies regarding their request for access to information.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, mandamus does not lie to compel a manual recount. Under Rule 65 of the Rules of Court, the writ of mandamus may only be issued when the petitioner has a clear legal right to the act demanded and the respondent has an imperative duty to perform it. Here, the petitioners have no statutory right to demand a manual recount of provincial election results based merely on the general right to information or unverified suspicions, as such a remedy is strictly limited to election protests. Hence, the petition lacks merit as the petitioners failed to demonstrate a clear legal right enforceable by mandamus.

2. YES, the petitioners failed to exhaust administrative remedies. The doctrine of exhaustion of administrative remedies mandates that parties must avail of all available administrative processes before seeking judicial relief to afford the agency an opportunity to address the matter. Here, the petitioners did not properly request access to information or utilize the appeals process under the Commission on Elections Freedom of Information Manual, effectively bypassing the agencys primary jurisdiction. Hence, the petition is premature and must be dismissed for violation of the doctrine of exhaustion of administrative remedies.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the instant Petition for Certiorari and Mandamus is hereby DISMISSED.

digest.doctrine: Under Canon II of the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability, a lawyer must act with propriety and maintain the appearance of propriety in personal and professional dealings, avoiding conduct that adversely reflects on their fitness to practice law or affects the dignity of the profession. Consequently, a lawyer commits simple misconduct when they sponsor lavish and excessive trips for officers of the Integrated Bar of the Philippines, as such extravagant generosity towards persons in authority creates a sense of obligation that compromises the independence and integrity of the institution, even if not done for electioneering purposes.
digest.facts: An anonymous letter alleged that Atty. Nilo Divina engaged in illegal campaign activities for the IBP-Central Luzon Governorship by sponsoring lavish trips for regional officers to Balesin Island Club and Bali, Indonesia, and distributing cash and gift checks. Atty. Divina and the impleaded officers admitted the sponsorships but argued they were unconditional acts of generosity for team-building and Christmas celebrations, denying any intent to campaign as Atty. Divina was not a candidate. The Supreme Court assumed jurisdiction to investigate whether these acts violated the IBP By-Laws on prohibited election practices or the ethical standards expected of lawyers under the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the respondent lawyer committed prohibited acts and practices relative to elections under the IBP By-Laws.

2. Whether the respondent lawyer and the recipient officers are administratively liable for simple misconduct under the CPRA.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the respondent lawyer did not commit prohibited acts relative to elections. Under Section 14 of the Revised IBP By-Laws, prohibited acts must be committed for the purpose of inducing or influencing a member to vote for or against a candidate. Here, there was no concrete evidence that the respondent intended to run for Governor or that the sponsorships were meant to influence votes, especially since the delegates who would vote had not yet been elected at the time of the trips. Hence, the charge of illegal campaigning is without merit.

2. YES, the respondents are liable for simple misconduct. Under Canon II, Sections 1 and 2 of the CPRA, lawyers must act with propriety, maintain the appearance of propriety, and uphold the dignity of the profession, avoiding conduct that reflects adversely on their fitness to practice law. Here, the sponsorships were excessive and extravagant gifts given solely to officers, which created a sense of obligation or gratitude that compromised the appearance of impartiality and independence of the IBP as a public institution. Hence, the lawyer and the recipient officers are guilty of simple misconduct and fined accordingly.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Court finds Atty. Nilo T. Divina GUILTY of Simple Misconduct in violation of Canon II, Section 1 and Section 2 of the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability and is hereby FINED PHP 100,000.00 with a STERN WARNING that a repetition of the same or similar offense will be dealt with more severely. The Court likewise finds Attys. Peter Paul S. Maglalang, Winston M. Ginez, Jocelyn Jo M. Clemente, Jade Paulo T. Molo, Enrique V. Dela Cruz, Jr., and Jose I. Dela Rama, Jr., GUILTY of simple misconduct in violation of Canon II, Section 1 and Section 2 of the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability and are hereby FINED PHP 100,000.00 each with a STERN WARNING that a repetition of the same or similar offense will be dealt with more severely. The Courts Resolution dated April 25, 2023 holding in abeyance the election of officers for the Integrated Bar of the Philippines â€“ Central Luzon is hereby lifted. Accordingly, the Integrated Bar of the Philippines â€“ Central Luzon is hereby ORDERED to proceed with the election of its Governor for the 2023-2025 term. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under Canon I, Section 1 of the Code of Conduct for Court Personnel, court personnel are strictly prohibited from utilizing their official positions to secure unwarranted benefits, privileges, or exemptions for themselves or others. Consequently, a court sheriff who utilizes the official franking privilege to mail a personal comment for an administrative case commits simple misconduct by securing a pecuniary benefit at the governments expense, regardless of his honest belief that the transaction was official, as this act constitutes an unauthorized use of court resources for private advantage.
digest.facts: Complainant Gonzales filed a complaint against Sheriff Geronimo for violating the Code of Conduct for Court Personnel after receiving a letter from the respondent in an official court envelope which contained a Verified Comment for a pending administrative case. Gonzales alleged that Geronimo misused the franking privilege to avoid paying postage, to which Geronimo admitted but claimed good faith belief that defending himself in an administrative case regarding his duties was an official transaction. The Judicial Integrity Board recommended finding Geronimo guilty of simple misconduct but not for violating the Franking Privilege Law, reasoning that the latter is a penal statute requiring a higher quantum of proof than the substantial evidence required in administrative proceedings.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the respondent is administratively liable for simple misconduct.

2. Whether the respondent can be held administratively liable for violating the Franking Privilege Law (Presidential Decree No. 26).
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the respondent is liable for simple misconduct. Under Canon I, Section 1 of the Code of Conduct for Court Personnel, court employees must not use their official positions to secure unwarranted benefits or privileges. Here, the respondent utilized the franking privilege intended for official judicial business to send a personal pleading, thereby improperly exempting himself from postage fees. Hence, he is guilty of simple misconduct for securing an unwarranted benefit through his office.

2. NO, the respondent cannot be held administratively liable for violating the Franking Privilege Law. The Supreme Court held that administrative and criminal cases are distinct, and the Franking Privilege Law is a penal statute requiring proof beyond reasonable doubt which cannot be satisfied in an administrative proceeding that relies only on substantial evidence. Here, finding the respondent guilty of violating the penal decree in this administrative case would disregard the required quantum of evidence for criminal liability. Hence, previous rulings allowing administrative liability for this penal offense are overturned, and the respondent is penalized solely for simple misconduct without prejudice to the filing of a proper criminal case.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Court finds respondent Dwight Aldwin S. Geronimo, Sheriff IV, Branch 121, Regional Trial Court, Imus, Cavite, GUILTY of simple misconduct for which he is FINED PHP 18,000.00, with a stern warning that a repetition of the same offense will be dealt with more severely.

digest.doctrine: Under Canon IV, Section 6 and Canon III, Sections 49 and 56 of the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability, a lawyer is duty-bound to regularly inform the client of the status of their case and, upon termination of engagement, immediately account for and turn over all funds and properties belonging to the client. Consequently, a lawyer who fails to provide updates despite repeated inquiries and refuses to return legal fees and documents after the termination of services commits simple negligence and acts indicative of misappropriation, warranting administrative sanctions such as suspension from the practice of law and restitution of funds.
digest.facts: Complainant Stewart engaged respondent Atty. Rioflorido to handle criminal cases against her husband, paying him a total of PHP 130,000.00 for acceptance fees and legal expenses based on his assurances of a favorable outcome. Despite receiving the payments and documents, the respondent failed to take any significant action on the cases, ceased communicating with the complainant, and ignored her repeated requests for updates and demands for the return of her money and documents. Consequently, Stewart filed a complaint before the Integrated Bar of the Philippines, where the Investigating Commissioner recommended a one-year suspension and return of funds, a recommendation subsequently adopted by the IBP Board of Governors.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the respondent is administratively liable for simple negligence for failing to update the client on the status of her cases.

2. Whether the respondent is administratively liable for failure to return the clients money and documents.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the respondent is liable for simple negligence. Under Canon IV, Section 6 of the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability, a lawyer must regularly inform the client of the status of the matter undertaken and respond within a reasonable time to requests for information. Here, the respondent failed to exercise the diligence required of lawyers by ignoring the complainants repeated inquiries and failing to provide any updates or proof of service rendered. Hence, the respondent is guilty of simple negligence for failing to keep the client informed, which is a less serious offense.

2. YES, the respondent is liable for failure to return the clients money and documents. Under Canon III, Sections 49 and 56 of the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability, a lawyer must render a full account of and turn over all documents and funds belonging to the client immediately upon termination of the engagement. Here, the respondents unjustified refusal to return the PHP 130,000.00 legal fees and case documents despite the complainants formal demand gives rise to the presumption of misappropriation. Hence, the respondent is guilty of serious and less serious offenses warranting separate penalties of suspension and an order for restitution.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Court finds respondent Atty. Crisaldo R. Rioflorido GUILTY of violation of: (1) Canon IV, Section 6 of the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability; and (2) Canon III, Sections 49 and 56 the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability. He is SUSPENDED from the practice of law for a total period of TWO YEARS, effective immediately upon his receipt of this Decision, with a STERN WARNING that a repetition of the same or similar act will be dealt with more severely. He is, likewise, ORDERED to return to complainant Myrna Gomez Stewart, the amount of PHP 130,000.00, which shall earn legal interest at the rate of 6% per annum from his receipt of this Decision until full payment. He is DIRECTED to submit to the Court proof of restitution within 10 days from payment. Failure to comply with this directive shall warrant the imposition of a more severe penalty. Finally, Atty. Crisaldo R. Rioflorido is ORDERED to report to this Court the date of his receipt of this Decision in order to determine when his suspension from the practice of law shall take effect.

digest.doctrine: Under the Code of Judicial Conduct and the New Code of Judicial Conduct, a judge must diligently discharge administrative responsibilities and organize court personnel to ensure prompt dispatch of business, meaning judicial duties take precedence over all other activities. Consequently, a judge who orders nearly all court staff to leave the office during official hours to clean a new office site commits simple misconduct, as this reflects bad court management and indifference to official duties, even if done without corruption or bad faith.
digest.facts: An anonymous complaint alleged that Respondent Judge Villavicencio-Olan and her staff violated the no noon break policy and closed their court branch during office hours. Investigation revealed that on July 19, 2019, the Judge and nearly all her staff left the Hall of Justice in the afternoon to visit and clean their new office site, leaving the court effectively closed. The respondents admitted leaving but argued it was necessary to expedite their transfer to the new office, claiming they performed official tasks at the site. The Office of the Court Administrator recommended dismissal for insufficiency of evidence, but the Judicial Integrity Board recommended finding the Judge guilty of simple misconduct for bad court management while exonerating the staff who merely followed orders.
digest.issue: Whether the respondent Judge is administratively liable for simple misconduct for ordering her staff to leave the court during office hours to work on a new office site.
digest.ruling: YES, the respondent Judge is administratively liable for simple misconduct. Under Canon 3 of the Code of Judicial Conduct and Canon 6 of the New Code of Judicial Conduct, judicial duties take precedence over all other activities, and a judge must diligently discharge administrative responsibilities to ensure the prompt dispatch of business. Here, the respondent ordered nearly her entire staff to leave the office during working hours to perform manual labor at a construction site, tasks which belonged to contractors and janitors, thereby causing the court to close to the public. Hence, this act constitutes simple misconduct as it displays bad court management and indifference to official duties, warranting a fine.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Court hereby finds respondent Judge Myla M. Villavicencio-Olan, Presiding Judge, Branch 7, Regional Trial Court of San Pablo City, Laguna, GUILTY of SIMPLE MISCONDUCT for which she is FINED in the amount of PHP 18,000.00. The Court also DIRECTS Court Stenographer Fritz B. Abril and Legal Researcher II Eric Ivans D. Soriano to EXPLAIN why they should not be held administratively liable. The case against Clerk of Court V Atty. Rica Kathrine R. Austria, Sheriff IV Alwin P. Pilit, Psychologist II Keren Keshia Bobis, Stenographer III Irene M. Anatalio, Clerk III Clarrene Faith Aliazas, Process Server Oscar R. Rodelas, Jr., and Interpreter III Monette P. Camacho is DISMISSED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: In crimes classified as mala prohibita, while the prosecution need not prove criminal intent or malice, it must still establish beyond reasonable doubt that the accused had the volition or intent to perpetrate the prohibited act freely and consciously. Consequently, the conviction of a public official for failure to remit compulsory premiums is invalid when the evidence demonstrates a lack of volition to commit the omission due to a mistaken belief that the funds were already withheld by the national government for that purpose.
digest.facts: Accused-appellant Talaue, a former municipal mayor, was charged with violation of the GSIS Act of 1997 for allegedly failing to remit premium contributions of municipal employees from 1997 to 2004 despite demands from the GSIS. Talaue defended himself by claiming he believed the Department of Budget and Management had already withheld the amounts from the municipal budget for remittance and that he subsequently entered into a Memorandum of Agreement with GSIS to restructure the obligation as a loan. The Sandiganbayan convicted him, ruling that the crime is malum prohibitum where good faith is no defense, while the Supreme Court initially affirmed the conviction before reconsidering the case upon Talaues motion.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the Information charging the accused was defective for failing to allege essential details.

2. Whether the accused is criminally liable for failure to remit GSIS premiums considering the nature of the offense as malum prohibitum.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the Information is not defective. Under Sections 6, 8, and 9 of Rule 110 of the Rules of Court, an Information is sufficient if it states the ultimate facts constituting the offense in ordinary and concise language to enable a person of common understanding to know the charge. Here, the Information clearly stated the material dates and the nature of the unremitted premiums, and the inclusion of dates when the accused was not in office is a matter of defense rather than a defect in the charge. Hence, the accused was sufficiently informed of the nature and cause of the accusation against him.

2. NO, the accused is not criminally liable. Under the jurisprudence on mala prohibita crimes, the prosecution must prove that the prohibited act was done intentionally by the accused, as there is a distinction between the intent to commit the crime and the intent to perpetrate the act or volition. Here, the accused demonstrated a lack of volition to fail in remittance because he honestly believed the funds were withheld by the budget department and he took active steps to settle the obligation through a payment agreement. Hence, the accused is acquitted as the prosecution failed to prove the intent to perpetrate the prohibited act.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Motion for Reconsideration dated March 3, 2021, the Motion for Leave of Court to File and Admit Supplement to Appellant's Motion for Reconsideration dated April 22, 2022, and the Supplement to Appellant's Motion for Reconsideration, also dated April 22, 2022, are GRANTED. The Court's Decision dated January 12, 2021 is REVERSED and SET ASIDE. digest.doctrine: Under Republic Act No. 9208, the consent of a minor victim is not a defense in human trafficking cases because such consent is rendered meaningless by the coercive, abusive, or deceptive means employed by perpetrators, or is simply not given out of free will. Consequently, an accused who recruits minors under the pretext of religious education but subjects them to forced construction labor is guilty of qualified trafficking, as the victims alleged voluntary participation based on religious belief cannot negate the criminal liability for exploitation.
digest.facts: Accused-appellant Si Young Oh, a Korean pastor, recruited minors AAA, BBB, and CCC to a seminary in Pampanga with the promise of free theological education, but instead compelled them to perform unpaid manual construction labor for long hours without conducting actual classes. The prosecution established that the accused operated without government permits and utilized the victims religious devotion to exploit their labor, while the defense claimed the work was voluntary service to God. The Regional Trial Court convicted the accused of Qualified Trafficking in Persons, and the Court of Appeals affirmed the conviction with modification, ruling that the elements of the crime were present and the victims consent was immaterial.
digest.issue: Whether the accused is guilty of Qualified Trafficking in Persons despite the defense of voluntary religious service.
digest.ruling: YES, the accused is guilty of Qualified Trafficking in Persons. Under Section 3(a) and Section 6 of Republic Act No. 9208, trafficking involves the recruitment of persons through fraud or deception for the purpose of exploitation, such as forced labor, and the offense is qualified when the victim is a child, making their consent irrelevant. Here, the accused deceived the minors into believing they were entering a legitimate educational institution but instead exploited their vulnerability and religious faith to extract forced manual labor for the construction of his facilities. Hence, the defense of voluntary religious service is unavailing, and the conviction is sustained as the crime was committed against minors on a large scale.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the appeal is DISMISSED for lack of merit. The Decision dated February 10, 2021 of the Court of Appeals, in CA-G.R. CR-HC No. 09864 is AFFIRMED with MODIFICATION. Accused-appellant Si Young Oh a.k.a. Steve Oh is found GUILTY beyond reasonable doubt of the crime of Qualified Trafficking in Persons as defined and penalized under Section 4(a) in relation to Section 6(a) and (c) of Republic Act No. 9208, otherwise known as the Anti-Trafficking in Persons Act of 2003, and is sentenced to suffer the penalty of life imprisonment and to pay a fine in the amount of PHP 2 million. He is also ORDERED to pay each of the victims AAA, BBB, and CCC the amounts of PHP 500,000.00 as moral damages and PHP 100,000.00 as exemplary damages. All damages due AAA, BBB, and CCC shall earn legal interest at the rate of 6% per annum from the date of the finality of this Decision until their full satisfaction. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under the 2010 POEA-SEC and established jurisprudence, a company-designated physician must not only issue a final, definite, and conclusive medical assessment within the prescribed 120 or 240-day period but must also properly furnish the seafarer with a copy of such assessment to satisfy the requirements of due process. Consequently, the failure of the employer to provide the seafarer with a copy of the final assessment within the mandatory period renders the medical findings ineffective, thereby transforming the disability into total and permanent by operation of law regardless of the medical prognosis.
digest.facts: Petitioner Ampolitod, a seafarer employed by respondents for six years, was repatriated in 2015 due to dizziness and bruising and was subsequently diagnosed with Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS). While the company-designated physician discontinued treatment in May 2016 claiming the petitioner was fit to work based on normal blood counts, the petitioner continued to suffer symptoms and was declared permanently disabled by his personal physicians. The Labor Arbiter awarded disability benefits finding the illness work-related due to chemical exposure, but the NLRC reversed this decision for lack of causal proof, a ruling subsequently affirmed by the Court of Appeals which held that the petitioner failed to prove the illness was work-related.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the petitioner is entitled to total and permanent disability benefits on the ground that his illness is work-related.

2. Whether the failure to furnish the petitioner with a valid final medical assessment renders his disability total and permanent.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the illness is work-related. Under Section 20(A) of the 2010 POEA-SEC, a seafarer must prove by substantial evidence that the risk of contracting a non-listed illness was aggravated by working conditions. Here, the petitioner established a reasonable linkage between his MDS and his six-year exposure to benzene-containing solvents and paints while performing his duties, which medical science recognizes as a cause of the disease. Hence, the illness is compensable.

2. YES, the disability is total and permanent. Under the rules regarding medical assessments, the company-designated physician must issue and furnish the seafarer with a final medical assessment within the 120 or 240-day period. Here, the respondents failed to furnish the petitioner with the alleged final assessment within the prescribed period, and the evidence showed he was still being treated months after the purported clearance. Hence, the lack of a valid and properly served final assessment renders the disability total and permanent by operation of law.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Petition for Review on Certiorari is GRANTED. The Decision dated November 28, 2019 and the Resolution dated March 12, 2020 promulgated by the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP. No. 159193 which affirmed the Decision dated August 28, 2018 of the National Labor Relations Commission in NLRC LAC No. 05-000363-18 are hereby REVERSED and SET ASIDE. The Decision dated March 23, 2018 of the Labor Arbiter in NLRC NCR Case No. (M) 11-16305-17 is REINSTATED with MODIFICATION. Respondents Top Ever Marine Management Phils., Inc., TEMM Maritime Co. Ltd. and Oscar Orbeta are ORDERED to jointly and severally PAY Rudy T. Ampolitod the amount of USD 60,000.00, plus 10% attorneys fees amounting to USD 6,000.00, all in its peso equivalent at the time of payment. The foregoing amounts shall earn legal interest at the rate of 6% per annum from finality of this Decision until full payment. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under the Data Privacy Act of 2012, the processing of personal information is lawful when necessary for the fulfillment of the constitutional or statutory mandate of a public authority, provided it adheres to principles of transparency, legitimacy, and proportionality. Consequently, the Ombudsman may lawfully process a public officials mobile phone number contained in their Personal Data Sheet to verify involvement in illegal schemes, as this falls within its mandate to investigate public officers and the information is relevant to the administrative inquiry.
digest.facts: Petitioner Zoleta, a high-ranking official in the Office of the Ombudsman, was administratively charged with Serious Dishonesty and Grave Misconduct after an entrapment operation caught another employee, Nicolas, Jr., who identified Zoleta as his accomplice in a case-fixing scheme. The complaint relied on Nicolas, Jr.s affidavit and text messages exchanged with a number listed in Zoletas Personal Data Sheet, which Zoleta argued was inadmissible and protected by the Data Privacy Act, while also claiming a violation of due process due to the lack of cross-examination. The Internal Affairs Board of the Ombudsman found Zoleta guilty and dismissed him from service, a ruling affirmed by the Court of Appeals which held that substantial evidence supported the guilt and that technical rules of evidence do not strictly apply in administrative proceedings.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the admission of the affidavit and text messages without cross-examination violated the petitioners right to due process.

2. Whether the use of the petitioners mobile phone number from his Personal Data Sheet violated the Data Privacy Act of 2012.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the admission of evidence did not violate due process. Under the jurisprudence on administrative due process, technical rules of procedure and evidence are not strictly applied in administrative proceedings, and the right to cross-examine witnesses is not an indispensable requirement as long as the party is given a reasonable opportunity to explain their side. Here, the petitioner was afforded the opportunity to submit his counter-affidavit and position paper to refute the evidence, which included the affidavit and text messages that constituted substantial evidence of his participation in the scheme. Hence, the petitioners right to due process was not violated despite the absence of cross-examination.

2. NO, the use of the mobile number did not violate the Data Privacy Act. Under Section 21(f) of the Implementing Rules and Regulations of the Data Privacy Act, the processing of personal information is lawful when necessary for the fulfillment of the constitutional or statutory mandate of a public authority. Here, the Ombudsman lawfully processed the petitioners personal information from his Personal Data Sheet to verify his identity in the text messages, which was necessary for the investigation of the administrative complaint pursuant to its constitutional duty to ensure accountability in public service. Hence, the evidence obtained is admissible and the processing was lawful.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Petition for Review on Certiorari is hereby DENIED.

digest.doctrine: In administrative cases, misconduct is classified as grave only when the elements of corruption, clear intent to violate the law, or flagrant disregard of an established rule are manifest; otherwise, the transgression is properly characterized as simple misconduct. Consequently, a police officer who uses excessive force during an arrest due to a lapse in judgment and failure to follow operational guidelines, without proof of corruption or flagrant disregard for rules, is liable only for simple misconduct rather than grave misconduct.
digest.facts: Petitioner Besmonte, a police officer, participated in a buy-bust operation where he arrested a suspect named Abenojar who allegedly resisted, prompting him to use physical force to subdue her. Abenojar filed a complaint for physical abuse supported by a medical certificate showing swelling and tenderness, claiming Besmonte punched and kicked her, while Besmonte argued he used reasonable force against a resisting suspect. The NAPOLCOM found Besmonte guilty of Grave Misconduct and imposed a one-rank demotion, which the Civil Service Commission affirmed but modified to the penalty of dismissal from service, a ruling subsequently upheld by the Court of Appeals.
digest.issue: Whether the petitioner is administratively liable for grave misconduct for the use of excessive force against a suspect.
digest.ruling: NO, the petitioner is liable only for simple misconduct. Under established jurisprudence and the Uniform Rules on Administrative Cases in the Civil Service, grave misconduct requires the presence of corruption, clear intent to violate the law, or flagrant disregard of an established rule, while simple misconduct involves a transgression of an established rule of action without these aggravating elements. Here, while the petitioner employed excessive force against a lone female suspect in violation of PNP operational guidelines, his actions were deemed a lapse of judgment rather than a flagrant disregard of rules or an act of corruption. Hence, the petitioner is guilty only of simple misconduct and is suspended rather than dismissed from service.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the petition is PARTIALLY GRANTED. The Decision dated October 29, 2021 and the Resolution dated March 28, 2022 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 161581 are hereby AFFIRMED with MODIFICATION in that petitioner Herminio A. Besmonte is found GUILTY of Simple Misconduct and is ORDERED suspended from office for a period of six (6) months. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine:
Local autonomy does not empower local government units to enact appropriation ordinances that contravene national statutes prohibiting the establishment of separate or supplementary retirement benefit plans. Consequently, a local ordinance granting separation incentives based on years of service is void for being ultra vires as it functions as a prohibited supplementary retirement plan.

Public officers who merely certify the availability of funds or perform administrative tasks in the implementation of an ordinance without participating in its enactment are shielded from civil liability for disallowed disbursements under the presumption of good faith. Consequently, subordinate employees who rely on the presumed validity of a local ordinance to process payments are absolved from the obligation to refund the disallowed amounts.
digest.facts: Petitioners Bayron and other officials of Puerto Princesa City filed a Motion for Reconsideration regarding the Supreme Courts decision which affirmed the Commission on Audits disallowance of funds disbursed for the Early and Voluntary Separation Incentive Program established by City Ordinance No. 438. They argued that the disallowance constituted an improper collateral attack on the ordinance, that the program was a valid reorganization incentive rather than a prohibited supplementary retirement plan, and that they acted in good faith relying on the ordinances presumption of validity. The Court previously declared the ordinance void for violating the prohibition against supplementary retirement plans under the Government Service Insurance System Act.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the local ordinance establishing the separation incentive program is void for being a prohibited supplementary retirement plan.

2. Whether the petitioners are liable to refund the disallowed amounts.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the ordinance is void. Under Commonwealth Act No. 186 as amended, government agencies and local units are expressly prohibited from establishing supplementary retirement or pension plans distinct from the Government Service Insurance System. Here, the local program granted incentives calculated based on years of service to reward loyalty, which constitutes a retirement benefit rather than a separation package for reorganization. Hence, the ordinance is ultra vires and the disbursements were properly disallowed.

2. NO, the subordinate petitioners are not liable, but the liability of the elective officials is deferred. Under the guidelines in Madera v. Commission on Audit, approving officers who act in good faith performance of their duties based on presumed valid ordinances are absolved from civil liability. Here, petitioners Herrera and Atienza merely certified funds and screened applicants as part of their administrative duties and did not participate in enacting the invalid ordinance. Hence, they are absolved from liability, while the liability of the mayor and council members is referred to the Ombudsman.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the instant Motion for Reconsideration is PARTIALLY GRANTED. Petitioners Roberto D. Herrera and Mylene J. Atienza are hereby ABSOLVED of any monetary liability relative to the refunding of the amounts covered by the Notices of Disallowance subject of respondent Commission on Audits Decision No. 2020-100 dated January 16, 2020. The rest of the Courts Decision dated November 29, 2022 STANDS.

digest.doctrine: All appeals from judgments rendered by the Regional Trial Court in the exercise of its appellate jurisdiction must be brought to the Court of Appeals by filing a petition for review under Rule 42 regardless of whether the appellant raises questions of fact, law, or mixed questions. Consequently, a litigant who files a petition for certiorari under Rule 65 instead of a timely petition for review utilizes the wrong remedy which cannot substitute for a lost appeal, thereby rendering the assailed decision final and executory by operation of law.
digest.facts: Respondent Reyes, the lawful possessor of a lot, leased the property to Petitioner Pacheco who later defaulted on rentals and claimed ownership to justify non-payment, prompting Reyes to file an unlawful detainer case. The MeTC ruled in favor of Reyes applying the principle of estoppel against tenants denying their landlords title, and the RTC affirmed this decision in the exercise of its appellate jurisdiction. Petitioner then filed a Petition for Certiorari under Rule 65 with the Court of Appeals alleging grave abuse of discretion, which the CA dismissed outright for being the wrong remedy and for being filed beyond the reglementary period.
digest.issue: Whether the Court of Appeals correctly dismissed the petition for certiorari filed by the petitioner.
digest.ruling: YES, the Court of Appeals correctly dismissed the petition. Under the Rules of Court, appeals from RTC judgments in the exercise of appellate jurisdiction must be made via a petition for review under Rule 42, and certiorari under Rule 65 is not a substitute for a lost appeal. Here, the petitioner erroneously availed of certiorari to challenge the RTC decision and filed the petition on the 50th day, far beyond the 15-day period for an appeal. Hence, the RTC decision became final and executory by operation of law, warranting the petitions dismissal.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the Petition for Review on Certiorari is DENIED. The July 26, 2022 and the May 8, 2023 Resolutions of the Court of Appeals, in CA-G.R. SP No. 173904 are AFFIRMED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under Article 11, paragraph 2 of the Revised Penal Code, the justifying circumstance of defense of a relative requires clear and convincing proof of unlawful aggression, reasonable necessity of the means employed, and that the defender had no part in the provocation given by the person attacked. Consequently, an accused who fatally stabs a victim is justified in doing so when the evidence shows the victim was the initial aggressor who inflicted multiple wounds on the accused and his relatives, compelling the accused to retrieve a weapon and inflict a single fatal blow to neutralize the persistent threat to his kin.
digest.facts: Petitioner Galorio was charged with Homicide for stabbing the victim during a fiesta celebration after the latter allegedly arrived and immediately attacked the petitioner and his relatives with a bolo. The petitioner claimed defense of a relative, asserting that after being wounded himself, he retrieved a bayonet from his motorcycle to protect his nephew whom the victim was pinning down and attacking, while the prosecution witnesses claimed the victim was threatened by the petitioners nephew with a gun before being stabbed while helpless. The Regional Trial Court convicted the petitioner, ruling that unlawful aggression had ceased and the defense was incredible, a decision affirmed by the Court of Appeals which held that the act was mere retaliation.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the petitioners right to speedy trial was violated.

2. Whether the petitioner is entitled to acquittal based on the justifying circumstance of defense of a relative.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the petitioners right to speedy trial was violated. Under the Constitution and the Speedy Trial Act of 1998, a criminal case may be dismissed if the proceedings are attended by vexatious, capricious, and oppressive delays that violate the rights of the accused. Here, the trial lasted nearly nine years with numerous unexplained postponements, including a three-month delay in arraignment and a gap of over one year between hearings, which constituted an unreasonable deprivation of liberty and anxiety for the petitioner. Hence, the excessive and unjustified delays warrant the dismissal of the case.

2. YES, the petitioner is entitled to acquittal based on defense of a relative. Under Article 11, paragraph 2 of the Revised Penal Code, an accused is justified in killing an aggressor if there is unlawful aggression, reasonable necessity of the means employed, and the defender took no part in any provocation. Here, the evidence established that the victim initiated a violent, unprovoked attack with a bolo, inflicting multiple wounds on the petitioner and his relatives, and remained a persistent threat even after the petitioner temporarily retreated to retrieve a weapon to neutralize him. Hence, the petitioner is acquitted as his act of inflicting a single fatal stab wound was reasonably necessary to protect his nephew from imminent danger.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the instant Petition for Review on Certiorari is GRANTED. The Decision dated July 28, 2015 of Branch 51, Regional Trial Court of Carmen, Bohol in Criminal Case No. 0954, as well as the Decision dated February 22, 2019 and the Resolution dated August 28, 2020 of the Court of Appeals 20th Division in CA-G.R. CEB-CR No. 02697, are all REVERSED and SET ASIDE, and petitioner Floro Galorio y Gapas is thus ACQUITTED on the ground of DEFENSE OF A RELATIVE in accordance with Article 11, paragraph 2 of Act No. 3815, otherwise known as the Revised Penal Code, as amended. Petitioner Floro Galorio y Gapas is also ADJUDGED and DECLARED to be NOT CIVILLY LIABLE to the heirs of the late Andres G. Muring, Sr. Petitioner Floro Galorio y Gapas is also ORDERED to be IMMEDIATELY RELEASED from confinement if he is still detained, unless he is being held for other lawful case. Let entry of judgment be issued immediately. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under the totality of circumstances test regarding out-of-court identification, the reliability of a witnesss identification depends on factors such as the opportunity to view the criminal, the accuracy of any prior description, and the absence of suggestiveness in the identification procedure. Consequently, a show-up identification is inadmissible and insufficient to support a conviction when it is tainted by the lack of any prior physical description and relies on information supplied by third parties rather than the witnesss own memory.
digest.facts: Private complainant Flores was robbed at gunpoint in the early morning but failed to report the incident immediately or provide a physical description of the perpetrator to authorities. Instead, he relied on information from bystanders who named petitioner Pagtakhan as the culprit based on his notoriety, leading Flores to identify the petitioner only after seeing him detained at a police station for a different offense. The Regional Trial Court convicted the petitioner of robbery, relying solely on the complainants positive identification and disregarding the defense of alibi. The Court of Appeals affirmed the conviction, ruling that the identification was credible and sufficient despite the delay in reporting.
digest.issue: Whether the out-of-court identification of the petitioner was valid and sufficient to establish his guilt beyond reasonable doubt.
digest.ruling: NO, the out-of-court identification was not valid. Under the totality of circumstances test established in jurisprudence, an out-of-court identification must be free from suggestiveness and supported by a prior accurate description to be admissible and reliable. Here, the identification was tainted because the complainant gave no prior description of the perpetrator and only identified the petitioner after bystanders suggested his name and he was presented in a suggestive show-up at the police station. Hence, the prosecution failed to prove the identity of the accused beyond reasonable doubt, warranting his acquittal.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the instant Petition for Review on Certiorari is hereby GRANTED. The Decision dated November 10, 2020 and the Resolution dated October 8, 2021 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CR No. 43208, as well as the Decision dated March 13, 2019 of Branch 108, Regional Trial Court of Pasay City vis-Ã -vis Criminal Case No. R-PSY-18-15642-CR, are all hereby REVERSED and SET ASIDE. For failure on the part of the prosecution to prove his guilt beyond reasonable doubt, petitioner Mark Anthony Pagtakhan y Flores is hereby ACQUITTED of the crime charged, and is also hereby ORDERED to be IMMEDIATELY RELEASED from confinement if he is still so detained, unless he is being held for other lawful cause. Any amount paid by way of bail bond is thus also ORDERED to be IMMEDIATELY RETURNED to petitioner Mark Anthony Pagtakhan y Flores. Let entry of judgment be issued immediately. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine:
The term monthly salary for purposes of computing the monetization of leave credits refers only to basic pay and excludes bonuses and allowances, consistent with the formula used for Terminal Leave Benefits under Civil Service rules. Consequently, a government financial institutions practice of computing the money value of leave credits based on gross monthly cash compensation, which includes allowances and other benefits, is illegal and properly disallowed for being inconsistent with the Omnibus Rules on Leave.

The constitutional right to speedy disposition of cases is violated when the Commission on Audit incurs inordinate and unjustified delay in resolving appeals and motions for reconsideration, which serves as a valid ground to excuse recipients from the civil liability to refund disallowed amounts based on undue prejudice. Consequently, where the COA takes eleven years to resolve an appeal and motion for reconsideration without valid justification, the recipients of the disallowed benefits are absolved from the obligation to refund due to the vexatious and oppressive delay that prejudiced them.
digest.facts: Petitioner DBP issued Circular No. 10 amending the computation of the money value of leave credits for its employees to be based on gross monthly cash compensation rather than basic salary, resulting in higher payouts. The Commission on Audit (COA) issued Notices of Disallowance totaling PHP 26.1 million, ruling that the computation violated the Revised Government Service Insurance Act and Civil Service rules which define salary as basic pay excluding allowances. DBP appealed citing its board's authority to fix compensation and a subsequent presidential approval, but the proceedings suffered significant delays totaling eleven years before the COA Commission Proper finally affirmed the disallowance while modifying the liability to require refunds from all parties. The COA Legal Services Sector initially affirmed the disallowance, and the COA Commission Proper subsequently upheld the disallowance but eventually required refunds from all recipients regardless of good faith.
digest.issue:
1. Whether DBP Circular No. 10 correctly computed the money value of leave credits based on gross monthly cash compensation.

2. Whether the COA violated DBPs right to speedy disposition of cases, thereby excusing the recipients from refunding the disallowed amounts.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, DBP Circular No. 10 is invalid. Under the Omnibus Rules on Leave and DBM Budget Circular No. 2002-1, the computation for monetization of leave credits must be based on monthly salary, which strictly refers to basic pay excluding bonuses and allowances. Here, DBP Circular No. 10 incorrectly used gross monthly cash compensation as the basis, contrary to the specific formulas prescribed by the Civil Service Commission and the Department of Budget and Management. Hence, the disallowance was proper as DBPs authority to fix compensation is subject to existing laws and regulations.

2. YES, the COA violated the right to speedy disposition of cases. Under Section 16, Article III of the Constitution and the ruling in Madera v. COA, inordinate delay by the COA in resolving cases constitutes a violation of the right to speedy disposition, which serves as a valid ground to excuse recipients from refunding disallowed amounts due to undue prejudice. Here, the COA took eleven years to resolve the appeal and motion for reconsideration without valid justification, keeping the threat of reimbursement hanging over the employees for nearly two decades. Hence, the recipients are absolved from the liability to refund the disallowed amounts on the ground of equity and violation of constitutional rights.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the petition is PARTIALLY GRANTED. The Decision No. 2018-197 dated January 30, 2018 and the Decision No. 2022-072 dated January 24, 2022 of the Commission on Audit are AFFIRMED with MODIFICATION in that the persons identified as liable under Notices of Disallowance Nos. HRM-MVLC-2006-04 (01-01) to HRM MVLC-2006-04 (01-03), all dated February 28, 2007 and Notice of Disallowance No. HRM-MVLC-2006-04 (03) dated July 4, 2007 are not required to refund the disallowed amounts therein. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine:
Under A.M. No. 00-2-03-SC and established jurisprudence, the sixty-day period to file a petition for certiorari may be extended for compelling reasons, such as a surge in COVID-19 infections and resulting lockdowns that restrict movement and government transactions. Consequently, the dismissal of a petition filed within the requested extension period is erroneous when such exceptional circumstances rendered timely filing impossible.

Constructive dismissal exists when an act of clear discrimination, insensibility, or disdain by an employer becomes so unbearable that it forecloses any choice by the employee except to forego continued employment. Consequently, a migrant worker who requests repatriation due to substantial contract breaches, verbal abuse, and life-threatening behavior by the foreign employer is legally deemed constructively dismissed and is entitled to full reimbursement of placement fees and salaries for the unexpired portion of the contract.
digest.facts: Petitioner Denusta was hired as a kitchen hand in the Cook Islands by respondents Migrant Workers Manpower Agency and K&G Manpower Services but suffered contract violations regarding salary and hours as well as maltreatment including verbal abuse and a knife threat from her employers family member which compelled her to request release from her contract. She filed a complaint for illegal dismissal which the Labor Arbiter granted upon finding constructive dismissal, but the NLRC reversed this ruling by dismissing the complaint for lack of merit. The Court of Appeals subsequently dismissed her petition for certiorari for being filed out of time after denying her motion for extension despite her plea based on COVID-19 restrictions.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the Court of Appeals erred in dismissing the petition for certiorari for being filed beyond the reglementary period despite the motion for extension due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

2. Whether the petitioner was constructively dismissed from her employment.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the Court of Appeals erred. Under the Rules of Court and Supreme Court administrative issuances, motions for extension of time to file petitions for certiorari are allowed for compelling reasons. Here, the petitioner faced a surge in COVID-19 infections and lockdowns which restricted movement and government transactions, constituting a compelling reason to grant the extension. Hence, the CA should have decided the case on the merits instead of dismissing it on technical grounds.

2. YES, the petitioner was constructively dismissed. Under labor laws and jurisprudence, constructive dismissal occurs when continued employment is rendered impossible or unreasonable due to the employers unbearable treatment. Here, the petitioner suffered breach of contract regarding salary and hours and endured verbal abuse and threats to her life with a knife which rendered her working environment intolerable and forced her to resign. Hence, she is entitled to salaries for the unexpired portion of her contract and reimbursement of placement fees.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, in view of the foregoing premises, the instant petition is GRANTED. The Court of Appeals Resolutions dated June 14, 2022, and the October 19, 2022, in CA-G.R. SP No. 171524 are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. The January 27, 2021 Decision of the Labor Arbiter is REINSTATED in so far as it ruled that petitioner Melba Alcantara Denusta was illegally dismissed and that respondents Migrant Workers Manpower Agency, Inc., K&G Manpower Services Ltd., and Theresita M. Ceralde are ordered to pay, jointly and severally, her salary for the unexpired portion of her contract, as well as for salary differentials, and attorney's fees, with MODIFICATIONS that petitioner be entitled to an increased amount of moral damages, and exemplary damages, as well as reimbursement of placement fee. Accordingly, respondents are further ORDERED to pay petitioner Melba Alcantara Denusta the following: 1. Moral and exemplary damages in the amount of PHP 50,000.00 and PHP 25,000.00, respectively. 2. PHP 90,000.00, as reimbursement for the placement fee which petitioner paid to Migrant Workers Manpower Agency, Inc. An interest of six percent (6%) per annum of the total monetary awards shall be imposed, computed from the time the complaint was filed until its full satisfaction. The Labor Arbiter is ORDERED to compute the total monetary benefits awarded and due the petitioner in accordance with this Resolution. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability, a lawyer is strictly prohibited from borrowing money from a client during the existence of the lawyer-client relationship unless the clients interests are fully protected by the nature of the case or by independent advice. Consequently, a lawyer who borrows money from a client whom he assisted in claiming death benefits is administratively liable for abusing the trust and confidence reposed in him, regardless of whether the loan was subsequently paid or intended for a specific purpose like house construction.
digest.facts: Complainant Villafuerte engaged respondent Atty. Tajanlangit to facilitate the release of death benefits from her deceased partner, establishing a lawyer-client relationship. After receiving the benefits, the respondent borrowed a substantial sum from the complainantâ€”alleged by her to be PHP 800,000.00 and by him to be PHP 300,000.00 for her house constructionâ€”which he failed to fully pay initially, leading to the filing of the complaint. The IBP Commission on Bar Discipline recommended a reprimand for violation of the rule against borrowing from clients, while the IBP Board of Governors modified the penalty to a three-month suspension.
digest.issue: Whether the respondent is administratively liable for borrowing money from his client.
digest.ruling: YES, the respondent is administratively liable. Under Section 52, Canon III of the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability, formerly Rule 16.04 of the Code of Professional Responsibility, a lawyer is prohibited from borrowing money from a client unless the clients interests are protected by the nature of the case or independent advice. Here, the respondent admitted to borrowing money from the complainant while a lawyer-client relationship existed to facilitate her claims, an act which degrades the trust and confidence essential to the profession and constitutes an abuse of influence. Hence, the respondent is suspended from the practice of law for six months, considering his previous infraction of a similar nature.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, respondent Atty. Cezar R. Tajanlangit is SUSPENDED for SIX (6) MONTHS from the practice of law for violation of Section 52, Canon III of the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability, effective upon the receipt of this Resolution. He is WARNED that a repetition of the same or a similar act will be dealt with more severely. Let a copy of this Resolution be furnished to the Office of the Bar Confidant, to be appended to the personal record of Atty. Cezar R. Tajanlangit as a member of the Bar; the Integrated Bar of the Philippines, for distribution to all its chapters; and the Office of the Court Administrator, for distribution to all courts in the land for their information and guidance. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under Article 854 of the Civil Code, preterition is the complete and total omission of a compulsory heir from the inheritance without express disinheritance, which results in the annulment of the institution of heirs while preserving the validity of devises and legacies insofar as they are not inofficious. Consequently, when a testators will contains specific bequests to some heirs while totally omitting others due to a void legacy, the probate court must not dismiss the petition for probate entirely but should instead remand the case to determine whether the valid devises impair the legitimes of the preterited heirs.
digest.facts: Petitioner Nelfa Trinidad sought the probate of the will of her late husband Wenceslao, which bequeathed a specific condominium unit to her and all his children, including respondents from his first marriage, while leaving other real properties solely to his second family. Respondents opposed the petition claiming preterition, arguing that the condominium unit actually belonged to a third party named Monique Toda and not Wenceslao, thereby leaving them with absolutely no inheritance. The Regional Trial Court dismissed the petition for probate on the ground of preterition after finding Wenceslao did not own the condominium unit, a ruling affirmed by the Court of Appeals which held that the omission of the respondents rendered the will intrinsically void.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the respondents were preterited from the will.

2. Whether the preterition of compulsory heirs warrants the total dismissal of the petition for probate.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the respondents were preterited. Under Article 854 of the Civil Code, preterition is the total omission of a compulsory heir from the inheritance without express disinheritance, and under Article 930, a devise of a thing belonging to another is void if the testator erroneously believed he owned it. Here, the evidence proved Wenceslao did not own the condominium unit he bequeathed to respondents, and since they received no other inheritance, donation, or advance, they were totally omitted from the estate. Hence, preterition occurred.

2. NO, the total dismissal of the probate is unjustified. Under Article 854 and established jurisprudence, preterition annuls the institution of heirs but mandates that devises and legacies shall remain valid insofar as they are not inofficious. Here, the will contained other specific devises of real property to the petitioners which are distinct from the institution of heirs and must be respected unless they impair the legitimes of the preterited respondents. Hence, the case is remanded to determine if these bequests must be reduced.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, in view of the foregoing premises, the instant petition is PARTIALLY GRANTED. The Court of Appeals Decision promulgated on September 17, 2020, and the Resolution dated November 27, 2020, in CA-G.R. CV No. 113463 are MODIFIED. The Petition for Probate of the Will of Wenceslao B. Trinidad is REMANDED to the Regional Trial Court for further proceedings. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under Section 21 of Republic Act No. 9165 the mandatory insulating witnesses must be readily available at or near the intended place of arrest to witness the inventory of seized items immediately after confiscation and the prosecution must prove their identity and credentials to establish compliance with the chain of custody. Consequently a buy-bust operation is fatally defective where the witnesses arrive significantly late after the seizure and the prosecution fails to present valid identification or proof of authority for the elected public official and media representative thereby casting reasonable doubt on the integrity of the corpus delicti and warranting the acquittal of the accused.
digest.facts: Police officers conducted a buy-bust operation against the appellants seizing small amounts of shabu but admitted that the inventory was conducted at the police station rather than the place of arrest and that the mandatory witnesses consisting of a media representative and a barangay kagawad were called only after the arrest and took fifteen to thirty minutes to arrive. The prosecution failed to provide valid identification for the barangay kagawad or explain discrepancies in the media representatives signature while the defense claimed frame-up and irregularities in the custody of the accused. The Regional Trial Court convicted the appellants relying on the presumption of regularity in the performance of official duties. The Court of Appeals affirmed the conviction ruling that the chain of custody was preserved despite the procedural lapses.
digest.issue: Whether the prosecution proved the guilt of the accused beyond reasonable doubt despite the delay in the arrival of the insulating witnesses and the lack of proof of their credentials.
digest.ruling: NO the prosecution failed to prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt. Under Section 21 of Republic Act No. 9165 and the chain of custody rule the mandatory insulating witnesses must be readily available to witness the inventory immediately after seizure and the prosecution must prove their actual presence and valid credentials to ensure the integrity of the seized items. Here the witnesses arrived significantly late after the arrest effectively failing the requirement of being readily available and the prosecution failed to substantiate the identity and authority of the barangay official and the media representative which cast doubt on the corpus delicti. Hence the presumption of regularity was overturned and the appellants must be acquitted.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the instant appeal is hereby GRANTED. The Decision dated December 22, 2020 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CR-HC No. 11650, as well as the Joint Decision of the Regional Trial Court of Quezon City, Branch 77 vis-Ã -vis Criminal Case No. R-QZN-16-14780-CR, are hereby REVERSED and SET ASIDE. For failure on the part of the prosecution to prove their guilt beyond reasonable doubt, remaining accused-appellants Gerald Flores y Alagdon and Harrold Francisco y Gabat a.k.a. Punonoy are hereby ACQUITTED of the crime charged.

digest.doctrine: Under Section 3(e) of Republic Act No. 3019, a violation of procurement laws does not automatically lead to a conviction for graft unless the prosecution establishes beyond reasonable doubt that the act was animated by corrupt intent, which entails the acquisition of gain in dishonest ways. Consequently, public officers who allow a contractor to proceed with a project prior to public bidding due to urgent time constraints are not criminally liable when the evidence shows no overpricing, the contractor was the lowest bidder, and the actions were not driven by a perverse motive or ill will to favor a private party.
