digest.facts: Accused-appellants, officials of the DPWH and a private contractor, were charged with violation of Section 3(e) of Republic Act No. 3019 for the alleged irregular procurement of decorative lampposts for the ASEAN Summit, specifically for executing a Memorandum of Understanding that allowed the contractor GAMPIK to proceed with the project six days before the actual public bidding. The prosecution argued this constituted manifest partiality and predetermination of the winner, while the defense contended that the agreement was executed due to extreme pressure to complete the projects before the summit and that the contractor was eventually determined to be the lowest bidder. The Sandiganbayan convicted the accused-appellants, ruling that the premature execution of the agreement constituted manifest partiality and gross inexcusable negligence by giving unwarranted preference to the contractor.
digest.issue: Whether the accused-appellants are guilty of violating Section 3(e) of Republic Act No. 3019 despite the lack of proof of corrupt intent.
digest.ruling: NO, the accused-appellants are not guilty. Under Section 3(e) of Republic Act No. 3019 and established jurisprudence, a violation of procurement laws does not automatically result in a conviction for graft unless the prosecution proves beyond reasonable doubt that the accused acted with corrupt intent which entails the acquisition of gain in dishonest ways. Here, the execution of the agreement prior to bidding was driven not by a corrupt motive to favor the contractor but by the urgent necessity to complete the projects for the ASEAN Summit, especially considering the contractor was the lowest bidder and the project was not overpriced. Hence, the element of corrupt intent was absent warranting the acquittal of the accused.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the appeal is GRANTED. The Joint Decision dated September 29, 2020 and the Resolution dated December 23, 2020 of the Sandiganbayan 6th Division are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. Accused-appellants Robert G. Lala, Pureza A. Fernandez, Agustinito P. Hermoso, and Gerardo S. Surla are ACQUITTED of the crime of violation of Section 3(e) of Republic Act No. 3019 in Criminal Case No. SB-12-CRM-0006. Let entry of judgment be issued immediately.

digest.doctrine: Date or time is not a material ingredient of the crime of rape, so inconsistencies regarding these details do not impair the credibility of the testimony provided the essential elements of carnal knowledge through force or intimidation are present. Consequently, the conviction of the accused is sustained despite discrepancies in the timeline of events because the victims positive identification and narrative of the assault remained consistent and credible against a weak defense of alibi.
digest.facts: Private complainant AAA was sleeping in her home when she was awakened by accused-appellant Pajarilla, a neighbor and family acquaintance, who was on top of her and proceeded to rape her through force and intimidation while threatening her silence. AAA immediately reported the incident to neighbors and the police resulting in Pajarillas arrest, while the latter raised the defense of denial and alibi claiming he was asleep and alleged a frame-up by AAAs father-in-law due to a prior misunderstanding. The Regional Trial Court convicted the accused-appellant of rape, crediting the straightforward testimony of the victim over his weak alibi, a decision which the Court of Appeals affirmed with modification as to the damages awarded.
digest.issue: Whether the Court of Appeals erred in affirming the conviction of the accused-appellant for the crime of rape.
digest.ruling: NO, the Court of Appeals did not err in affirming the conviction, though the penalty requires modification. Under Article 266-A of the Revised Penal Code, rape is committed through carnal knowledge of a woman by force or intimidation, and the victims positive identification prevails over the defense of alibi unless physical impossibility is proven. Here, the prosecution established beyond reasonable doubt that the accused-appellant raped the victim through force and threats, and his defense of alibi failed because he lived only twenty meters away from the crime scene. Hence, the conviction is affirmed, but the penalty is modified to reclusion perpetua without qualification because the crime committed was simple rape which does not carry the death penalty.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the appeal is DISMISSED. The Decision dated January 31, 2020 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CEB-HC No. 02576 is hereby AFFIRMED with MODIFICATION in that accused-appellant Tito Pajarilla y Alas is proven GUILTY beyond reasonable doubt of the crime of Simple Rape and is sentenced to suffer the penalty of reclusion perpetua. Accused-appellant Tito Pajarilla y Alas is ORDERED to pay moral damages in the amount of P75,000.00, civil indemnity of P75,000.00, and exemplary damages of P75,000.00 to AAA. All monetary awards are subject to six percent (6%) interest per annum from finality of this decision until fully paid. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under Article 12 of the Revised Penal Code, the exempting circumstance of insanity or imbecility requires a complete deprivation of intelligence or freedom of the will, such that mere mental retardation or a mental age of a child does not automatically exempt an accused from liability unless it results in a total lack of discernment. Consequently, an accused diagnosed with mild mental retardation and a mental age of nine years remains criminally liable for rape when medical evidence and observed behavior demonstrate that he is capable of distinguishing right from wrong and performing ordinary duties, although such condition constitutes a mitigating circumstance of diminished will power.
digest.facts: Private complainant AAA, a woman suffering from moderate mental retardation, was found by her sister BBB in a compromising position with the accused-appellant XXX, who was standing with his genitals exposed while AAA had her underwear down. The accused-appellant denied the rape charge and argued that he should be exempt from criminal liability because he himself suffers from mild mental retardation and has a mental age of a nine-year-old. The Regional Trial Court convicted the accused-appellant of rape, ruling that his mental condition did not deprive him of the capacity to distinguish right from wrong. The Court of Appeals affirmed the conviction, holding that the prosecution established the elements of the crime and that the accused-appellants denial could not prevail over positive testimony.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the crime committed is rape under Article 266-A, paragraph 1(b) of the Revised Penal Code.

2. Whether the accused-appellant is exempt from criminal liability due to his mental retardation.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the crime committed is rape under Article 266-A, paragraph 1(b). Under the Revised Penal Code, rape is committed against a woman deprived of reason when she suffers from a mental condition that affects her capacity to resist and give consent, while statutory rape applies only if the victims mental age is proven to be below twelve years old. Here, AAAs mental retardation was undisputed but her specific mental age was not established, yet her condition clearly rendered her incapable of giving rational consent. Hence, the accused-appellant is liable for rape of a woman deprived of reason.

2. NO, the accused-appellant is not exempt from criminal liability. Under Article 12 of the Revised Penal Code, the exempting circumstance of insanity requires complete deprivation of intelligence or discernment, and mere abnormality or diminished mental faculties does not exclude imputability. Here, the medical evaluation showed the accused-appellant had mild mental retardation with a mental age of nine but could still distinguish right from wrong and function normally in society. Hence, he is criminally liable, though his condition constitutes a mitigating circumstance of diminished will power.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, in view of the foregoing, the appeal is hereby DISMISSED. Accordingly, the Decision dated March 30, 2015, of the Court of Appeals Cagayan de Oro Station in CA-G.R. CR-HC No. 01213-MIN convicting the accused-appellant XXX of the crime of Simple Rape under Article 266-A(l)b in relation to Article 266-B of the Revised Penal Code and imposing upon him the penalty of reclusion perpetua is hereby AFFIRMED with MODIFICATION in that accused-appellant XXX is ordered to pay private complainant AAA P75,000.00 as civil indemnity, P75,000.00 as moral damages, and P75,000.00 as exemplary damages. All of which shall earn interest at the rate of six percent (6%) per annum from the date of finality of this Decision until fully paid. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Republic Act No. 11573 is a curative statute that applies retroactively to pending land registration applications, shortening the required period of possession to twenty years immediately preceding the filing and accepting a geodetic engineers certification as sufficient proof of alienability and disposability. Consequently, a pending application invoking the previous requirement of possession since June 12, 1945 must be remanded to allow the applicant to present evidence satisfying the new evidentiary standards and the shortened prescriptive period of twenty years.
digest.facts: Respondents filed an application for registration of title over a lot in Batangas City claiming they acquired it from heirs of the original owners and presenting tax declarations from 1968 and CENRO certifications to prove the lands alienability. The Republic opposed arguing failure to prove possession since June 12, 1945 and insufficiency of the land classification evidence, while respondents relied on the testimony of a neighbor which was vague regarding specific dates of possession. The Municipal Trial Court in Cities granted the application ruling that the evidence sufficiently established ownership and classification, and the Court of Appeals affirmed this decision holding that there was substantial compliance with the requirements.
digest.issue: Whether Republic Act No. 11573 applies retroactively to the respondents pending application warranting a remand of the case.
digest.ruling: YES, Republic Act No. 11573 applies retroactively warranting a remand. Under Section 6 and 7 of the said law as interpreted in Republic v. Pasig Rizal Co., Inc., the period of possession is shortened to twenty years prior to filing and the proof of land classification is simplified to a geodetic engineers certification. Here, the case was pending during the laws enactment and the respondents evidence did not strictly comply with the new documentary requirements nor clearly establish possession dating back to 1989 as now required. Hence, the case is remanded to the Court of Appeals to allow the reception of additional evidence in accordance with the new legal parameters.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, premises considered, the instant Petition for Review on Certiorari is hereby DENIED in part. The Decision dated October 26, 2016 and the Resolution dated July 7, 2017 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV No. 101418 are hereby SET ASIDE, and the case is REMANDED to the Court of Appeals for the reception of evidence relative to the subject propertys land classification status based on the parameters set forth in Section 7 of Republic Act No. 11573, as well as evidence relative to the possession and occupation of the predecessors-in-interest of respondents spouses Rolly D. Tan and Grace Tan dating back to March 11, 1989 or prior. Thereafter, the Court of Appeals is DIRECTED to resolve the present case in accordance with this Decision with due and deliberate dispatch. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under Section 50-A of Republic Act No. 6657 as amended by Republic Act No. 9700 and A.O. No. 03-11 courts are mandated to automatically refer a case to the Department of Agrarian Reform when there is an allegation of an agrarian dispute and one of the parties is a farmer or tenant regardless of whether the case is civil or criminal in nature. Consequently a criminal case for qualified theft involving the taking of farm produce must be dismissed or the accused acquitted when a prior administrative ruling confirms the accused are tenants de jure as this negates the element of taking without the owners consent and establishes the agrarian nature of the controversy.
digest.facts: Private complainant Tan filed separate informations for qualified theft against petitioners Bacar and Mercado for allegedly stealing copra and coconuts from his plantation but the petitioners moved to quash the informations arguing that the Regional Trial Court lacked jurisdiction because the Department of Agrarian Reform Adjudication Board had already declared them as tenants de jure of the subject landholdings. The Regional Trial Court denied the motions to quash in both cases ruling that qualified theft falls under its jurisdiction and does not involve an agrarian dispute. The Court of Appeals affirmed the denial in Bacars case holding the RTC had jurisdiction but reversed the ruling in Mercados case ordering the referral of the latter to the Department of Agrarian Reform due to the existence of a tenancy relationship.
digest.issue: Whether the criminal cases for qualified theft should be dismissed or referred to the Department of Agrarian Reform due to the status of the accused as tenants de jure.
digest.ruling: YES, the cases must be dismissed and the accused acquitted. Under Section 50-A of Republic Act No. 6657 as amended and established jurisprudence courts must automatically refer cases to the Department of Agrarian Reform when there is an allegation of an agrarian dispute and one of the parties is a tenant because a finding of tenancy negates the element of taking without consent in theft cases. Here the Department of Agrarian Reform Adjudication Board had already issued a final decision declaring the accused as tenants de jure effectively establishing their authority to harvest produce and proving the existence of an agrarian dispute that removes the case from the ordinary jurisdiction of the trial court. Hence a referral is now redundant and the accused must be acquitted because the essential elements of qualified theft regarding the lack of consent cannot be established given their legal status as tenants.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the Petition for Review on Certiorari in G.R. No. 226098 is GRANTED and the Petition for Review on Certiorari in G.R. No. 233817 is DENIED. Roberto Bacar and Michael Mercado are ACQUITTED of the crime of Qualified Theft defined and penalized under Article 310 of the Revised Penal Code. Let entry of judgment be issued immediately. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under Act No. 3135, the extrajudicial foreclosure of a real estate mortgage strictly requires a special power to sell inserted in or attached to the mortgage deed, as the statutory term sale made under a special power contemplates an express authority to sell or alienate the mortgaged property. Consequently, a mortgage contract that merely stipulates that the mortgage shall be foreclosed extra-judicially in accordance with law without explicitly granting the mortgagee the power to sell or alienate the property renders the subsequent notarial foreclosure and auction sale void for lack of authority.
digest.facts: Petitioner Palo obtained a loan from respondent Nakamura secured by a real estate mortgage which provided that upon default the mortgage shall be foreclosed either judicially or extra-judicially in accordance with law. After Palo failed to pay, Nakamura initiated extrajudicial foreclosure proceedings resulting in the sale of the property to respondent Baquirquir, prompting Palo to file a complaint to annul the foreclosure on the ground that Nakamura lacked the requisite special power of attorney to foreclose. The Regional Trial Court dismissed the complaint on judgment on the pleadings, ruling that the mortgage provision sufficiently authorized the foreclosure. The Court of Appeals affirmed the dismissal, holding that no particular formality is required to empower the mortgagee to sell the property.
digest.issue: Whether the provision in the mortgage contract authorizing extrajudicial foreclosure constitutes the valid special power to sell required by Act No. 3135.
digest.ruling: NO, the provision is insufficient. Under Act No. 3135 and established jurisprudence, a valid extrajudicial foreclosure requires a special power to sell inserted in or attached to the mortgage, and a general stipulation merely agreeing to extrajudicial foreclosure does not constitute the specific authority to sell. Here, the mortgage contract only stated that the mortgage shall be foreclosed extra-judicially in accordance with law but failed to expressly grant Nakamura the power to sell or alienate the property which is distinct from the general power to foreclose. Hence, the extrajudicial foreclosure and the subsequent sale to Baquirquir are null and void for lack of the requisite special power.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the motion for reconsideration is GRANTED. The assailed Resolution of this Court, dated November 20, 2017, is hereby SET ASIDE. The Decision, dated March 10, 2016, and the Resolution, dated October 19, 2016, of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV No. 04717 are hereby REVERSED and SET ASIDE. Judgment is hereby rendered NULLIFYING: 1) the document entitled Notice of Notarial Foreclosure for NF # 0041-L, dated May 12, 2004 and signed by Atty. Orpha T. Casul-Arendain; 2) the document entitled Certificate of Sale dated July 1, 2004 signed by Atty. Orpha T. Casul-Arendain; and 3) Transfer Certificate of Title No. T-152541 in the name of Rey C. Baquirquir, married to Fleurdeline B. Baquirquir. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under the guidelines established in People v. Montierro, trial courts exercise sound discretion to grant plea bargaining in drugs cases and may overrule the prosecutions objection if it is based solely on inconsistency with internal DOJ rules, provided the proposal conforms to the Supreme Court Plea Bargaining Framework. Consequently, an appellate court errs in nullifying a plea bargain solely due to the lack of prosecutorial consent when the trial court validly overruled the objection based on conflicting administrative circulars, warranting a remand to determine if specific disqualifications like recidivism or strong evidence of guilt apply.
digest.facts: Petitioner Aguilar was charged with violation of Sections 5 and 11 of Republic Act No. 9165 and filed a proposal to plea bargain to the lesser offense of violation of Section 12, which the prosecution objected to for being inconsistent with Department of Justice guidelines. The Regional Trial Court granted the plea bargaining proposal over the objection, ruling that the Supreme Court Plea Bargaining Framework prevails over the DOJ guidelines and noting that the petitioner was not a drug dependent. The Court of Appeals reversed the trial court decision and nullified the plea bargain, holding that the consent of the prosecution is a condition precedent and its objection mandated the continuation of the proceedings.
digest.issue: Whether the Court of Appeals erred in nullifying the Regional Trial Courts decision to grant the plea bargaining proposal despite the prosecutions objection.
digest.ruling: YES, the Court of Appeals erred. Under the guidelines laid down in People v. Montierro, judges may overrule the prosecutions objection to a plea bargaining proposal if said objection is based solely on inconsistency with DOJ internal rules, provided the proposal aligns with the Supreme Court Plea Bargaining Framework. Here, the Regional Trial Court correctly overruled the prosecutions objection which relied entirely on the DOJ circular, but it failed to assess whether the petitioner was disqualified due to being a recidivist, habitual offender, or if the evidence of guilt was strong. Hence, the Court of Appeals decision is set aside, and the case is remanded to the trial court to determine if such disqualifying circumstances exist.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the Decision dated December 23, 2020 and the Resolution dated May 27, 2021 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 12611 are SET ASIDE. Criminal Case No. C-238-18 and Criminal Case No. C-239-18 against petitioner Edwin Aguilar y Duron are REMANDED to the Regional Trial Court of Roxas City, Capiz, Branch 16 to determine if: (a) petitioner Edwin Aguilar y Duron is a recidivist, a habitual offender, a known drug addict within the community, had relapsed after rehabilitation, or had been charged many times; or (b) the evidence of guilt is strong. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under Executive Order No. 1008 and the alternative dispute resolution laws the Construction Industry Arbitration Commission exercises original and exclusive jurisdiction over construction disputes among parties bound by arbitration agreements which jurisdiction harmonizes with and modifies the enforcement of solidary liability under Article 1729 of the Civil Code. Consequently a subcontractor seeking to enforce a claim for unpaid services against a contractor and a project owner under Article 1729 must proceed before the Construction Industry Arbitration Commission rather than regular courts when the underlying contracts contain arbitration clauses effectively treating the subcontractor as an assignee bound to arbitrate.
digest.facts: Petitioner Grandspan a subcontractor filed a complaint for sum of money against respondent Advance Engineering Corporation the main contractor and respondent Franklin Baker Inc. the project owner seeking unpaid balances for structural works based on the Subcontractors Agreement and Article 1729 of the Civil Code. Respondent owner moved to dismiss citing the arbitration clause in its Construction Contract with the contractor while the contractor invoked the arbitration clause in the Subcontractors Agreement to assert the jurisdiction of the Construction Industry Arbitration Commission. The Regional Trial Court dismissed the complaint for lack of jurisdiction and directed the parties to initiate arbitration. The Court of Appeals affirmed the dismissal and modified the order to expressly refer the construction dispute among all parties to the Construction Industry Arbitration Commission.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the complaint against the contractor is subject to the jurisdiction of the Construction Industry Arbitration Commission.

2. Whether the petitioner can validly implead the project owner in the arbitration proceedings pursuant to Article 1729 of the Civil Code.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the complaint is subject to CIAC jurisdiction. Under Section 4 of Executive Order No. 1008 the CIAC has original and exclusive jurisdiction over disputes arising from construction contracts where the parties have agreed to submit to voluntary arbitration. Here the Subcontractors Agreement between the petitioner and the contractor contained a clear arbitration clause stipulating the submission of disputes to the CIAC. Hence the trial court correctly dismissed the complaint and referred the matter to the specialized arbitral body.

2. YES, the petitioner can implead the project owner before the CIAC. Under Article 1729 of the Civil Code read in harmony with Executive Order No. 1008 a subcontractor may enforce the solidary liability of the owner and contractor for unpaid labor and materials but this right must be pursued within the proper jurisdictional framework of the CIAC when arbitration clauses exist. Here the petitioner is effectively an assignee of the Construction Contract and subrogated to the contractors rights allowing the CIAC to exercise plenary jurisdiction over the construction dispute involving the owner contractor and subcontractor to avoid splitting causes of action. Hence the claim against the owner must be resolved by the CIAC.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the instant petition is hereby DENIED for lack of merit, and accordingly, the Decision dated March 15, 2019 and the Resolution dated January 15, 2020 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV No. 110751 are hereby AFFIRMED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Extrinsic fraud serves as a valid ground for a petition for annulment of judgment when the prevailing party commits a fraudulent act outside of the trial that prevents the defeated party from having his day in court or keeps him in ignorance of the suit. Consequently, a final judgment in a probate proceeding must be annulled when the testator deliberately omits the known addresses of compulsory heirs in the petition and fails to serve them with the mandatory notices of hearing, as this constitutes extrinsic fraud and a violation of due process by effectively disinheriting the heirs without affording them an opportunity to defend their rights.
digest.facts: Petitioners Isabel and Emilio Jr., legitimate grandchildren of the deceased Federico Suntay, filed a petition for annulment of judgment to set aside the decisions of the Regional Trial Court which admitted Federicos Second Will to probate and approved the partition of his estate. Petitioners alleged that Federico committed extrinsic fraud by deliberately filing the probate petition in a venue where he did not reside, omitting their known addresses in the petition, and failing to serve them with notices of hearing, thereby keeping them ignorant of the proceedings and depriving them of their right to participate. The Regional Trial Court had rendered judgment admitting the will and approving the partition after finding the will duly executed, while the Court of Appeals denied the petition for annulment of judgment, ruling that the omission of addresses was not a fatal defect and that the service of processes enjoyed the presumption of regularity.
digest.issue: Whether the petition for annulment of judgment should be granted on the grounds of extrinsic fraud and lack of due process.
digest.ruling: YES, the petition is granted. Under Rule 47 of the Rules of Court, a judgment may be annulled on the ground of extrinsic fraud when a party is prevented from fully exhibiting his side due to the fraudulent acts of the opponent, and jurisprudence establishes that a denial of the fundamental right to due process renders a judgment void. Here, the evidence showed that the testator knowingly omitted the petitioners addresses in the probate petition and failed to serve them with the required notices of hearing, which constituted extrinsic fraud and a violation of due process by keeping the heirs ignorant of the case and depriving them of the opportunity to protect their hereditary rights. Hence, the decisions of the trial court are annulled and set aside to correct the fatal infirmity caused by the lack of notice.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the petition is GRANTED. The Decision dated October 18, 1999 and the Decision dated January 29, 2002 of the Regional Trial Court of La Trinidad City, Benguet, Branch 10, in Special Proceeding Case No. 99-SP-010 are hereby ANNULLED and SET ASIDE. This is without prejudice to the original action for the probate of the Last Will and Testament of deceased Federico C. Suntay from being refiled in the proper court. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: The authority of the Board of Directors of a government financial institution to fix remuneration under its charter is not absolute but remains subject to the principles of the Salary Standardization Law and existing administrative rules which define monthly salary for leave monetization as basic pay excluding allowances. Consequently, the computation of the money value of leave credits based on gross monthly cash compensation is legally baseless and properly disallowed, although the recipients are excused from refunding the amounts received due to the violation of their constitutional right to speedy disposition of cases caused by the Commission on Audits inordinate delay of eleven years in resolving the appeal.
digest.facts: Petitioner DBP issued Circular No. 10 which amended the formula for the money value of leave credits of its officials and employees to be based on gross monthly cash compensation including allowances, instead of the basic salary. The Commission on Audit disallowed the payments totaling P26.18 million, ruling that under existing laws and Civil Service rules, the computation must be based solely on basic salary notwithstanding DBPs charter exemption from the Salary Standardization Law. DBP appealed invoking its boards fiscal autonomy and a subsequent presidential approval, but the Commission on Audit affirmed the disallowance and held the officers liable while excusing passive recipients. The Commission on Audit took eight years to decide the appeal and another three years to resolve the motion for reconsideration, prompting DBP to allege a violation of the right to speedy disposition of cases.
digest.issue:
1. Whether DBP Circular No. 10 computing the money value of leave credits based on gross monthly cash compensation is valid.

2. Whether the DBP officers and employees are liable to refund the disallowed amounts.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the circular is invalid. Under the Omnibus Rules on Leave and established jurisprudence, the formula for the money value of leave credits is based on monthly salary which refers strictly to basic pay excluding allowances and bonuses. Here, DBP Circular No. 10 improperly used gross monthly cash compensation as the basis, and DBPs charter exemption does not grant it unbridled authority to deviate from the principles of the Salary Standardization Law or rely on a void presidential approval made during an election ban. Hence, the disallowance of the excess payments is correct.

2. NO, they are not liable to refund. Under the Madera rules and the Constitution, approving officers are excused from liability if they acted in good faith, while recipients may be excused if the delay in the proceedings violates their right to speedy disposition of cases. Here, the officers acted in good faith reliance on their charter, and the Commission on Audit took an unreasonable eleven years to resolve the case which caused undue prejudice to the recipients. Hence, all persons held liable are excused from refunding the disallowed amounts.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the petition is PARTIALLY GRANTED. The Decision No. 2018-197 dated January 30, 2018 and the Decision No. 2022-072 dated January 24, 2022 of the Commission on Audit are AFFIRMED with MODIFICATION in that the persons identified as liable under Notices of Disallowance Nos. HRM-MVLC-2006-04 (01-01) to HRM MVLC-2006-04 (01-03), all dated February 28, 2007 and Notice of Disallowance No. HRM-MVLC-2006-04 (03) dated July 4, 2007 are not required to refund the disallowed amounts therein.

digest.doctrine: The right to speedy disposition of cases enshrined in the Constitution extends to preliminary investigations before quasi-judicial bodies like the Commission on Elections, compelling the dismissal of criminal complaints when the proceedings are attended by vexatious, capricious, and oppressive delays without valid justification. Consequently, a delay of eleven years in resolving a straightforward preliminary investigation for an election offense constitutes inordinate delay that violates the accuseds due process rights, especially when the agency offers no explanation for the administrative stagnation.
digest.facts: Petitioner Villanueva, the former municipal mayor, requested the reassignment of an election officer for alleged neglect of duty and subsequently ordered the closure of the municipal election office when the Commission on Elections failed to act on her request. The Commission on Elections Law Department filed a complaint against her for coercion of election officials under Section 261(f) of the Omnibus Election Code and recommended the filing of an information four years later, which the Commission on Elections En Banc approved. Petitioner moved for reconsideration arguing that the offense applies only during the election period, but the Commission on Elections took another six years to deny the motion, prompting the petitioner to file a petition for certiorari alleging inordinate delay. The Commission on Elections maintained that the offense can be committed at any time but failed to provide any justification for the eleven-year delay in resolving the preliminary investigation.
digest.issue:
1. Whether Section 261(f) of the Omnibus Election Code regarding coercion of election officials applies only during the election period.

2. Whether the Commission on Elections committed inordinate delay in resolving the preliminary investigation against the petitioner.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the offense is not limited to the election period. Under Section 261(f) of the Omnibus Election Code, the crime of coercion punishes threats against election officials in the performance of their election functions and duties, which jurisprudence clarifies are continuing tasks such as voter registration that occur even outside the election period. Here, the petitioners closure of the office to coerce the election officer regarding his duties falls within the definition of the crime regardless of the timing. Hence, the petitioner was correctly charged under the statute despite the act occurring after the election.

2. YES, the Commission on Elections committed inordinate delay. Under Article III, Section 16 of the Constitution and established jurisprudence, inordinate delay in the resolution of preliminary investigations violates the right to speedy disposition of cases and warrants dismissal when the prosecution fails to justify the delay in simple cases. Here, the Commission on Elections took eleven years to resolve a straightforward coercion case involving non-voluminous records without providing any explanation for the stagnation. Hence, the case is dismissed for violation of the petitioners constitutional rights.
digest.dispositive: CONSEQUENTLY, the present petition is GRANTED. The December 11, 2015 and January 21, 2022 Resolutions of the Commission on Elections in E.O. Case No. 11-092 are hereby NULLIFIED and SET ASIDE. E.O. Case No. 11-092 against petitioner Agnes C. Villanueva is hereby DISMISSED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under the Bunkhouse Rule and the Personal Comfort Doctrine as applied to seafarers, an injury is deemed work-related and compensable if it arises out of and in the course of employment, which includes injuries sustained during employer-sanctioned recreational activities like sports performed on board the vessel during free time. Consequently, a seafarer who suffers an injury while playing basketball on the ship is entitled to disability benefits because the nature of the employment requires living on the premises, making such necessary recreational acts incidental to the service and beneficial to the employer.
digest.facts: Petitioner Arguilles, an Ordinary Seaman, suffered a left ankle injury while playing basketball on board the vessel during his free time, leading to his medical repatriation and diagnosis of a high-grade Achilles tendon tear. He sought disability benefits after the company-designated physicians failed to issue a final assessment within the statutory periods, while respondents argued the injury was not work-related as it occurred during leisure and later claimed, based on a belatedly submitted medical prescription, that he was declared fit to work. The Labor Arbiter ruled in favor of the petitioner finding the injury work-related under the Bunkhouse Rule and the disability total and permanent due to the lapse of the 120-day period. However, the National Labor Relations Commission reversed its initial favorable ruling and dismissed the complaint, a decision which the Court of Appeals affirmed on the ground that the injury was not work-related.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the injury sustained by the seafarer while playing basketball on board the vessel is work-related and compensable.

2. Whether the seafarer is entitled to total and permanent disability benefits due to the lack of a final medical assessment.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the injury is work-related and compensable. Under the POEA Standard Employment Contract and the Bunkhouse Rule, a work-related injury is one arising out of and in the course of employment, which covers acts reasonably necessary to the health and comfort of the employee while at work, including sanctioned recreational activities on board. Here, the petitioner sustained the injury while playing basketball, an employer-sanctioned activity on the vessel, and respondents failed to prove that the injury resulted from a willful or criminal act or intentional breach of duties. Hence, the injury is compensable as it occurred during the term of employment and is incidental to the seafarers service.

2. YES, the petitioner is entitled to total and permanent disability benefits. Under established jurisprudence, if the company-designated physician fails to issue a final medical assessment within the 120-day or 240-day period, the seafarers disability becomes permanent and total by operation of law. Here, the 240-day period lapsed without a valid final medical report from the company-designated physicians, and the document presented by respondents was merely a medical prescription submitted belatedly. Hence, the disability is deemed total and permanent, entitling the petitioner to full benefits under the Collective Bargaining Agreement.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the petition is GRANTED. The Decision dated January 24, 2020 and the Resolution dated November 9, 2020 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 160276 are hereby REVERSED and SET ASIDE. The Decision dated April 30, 2018 issued by Labor Arbiter Renaldo O. Hernandez in NLRC RAB Case No. (M) NCR-08-12093-17 is hereby REINSTATED with MODIFICATION. Respondents Wilhelmsen Smith Bell Manning, Inc., Wilhelmsen Ship Management Ltd., and the corporate officers of Wilhelmsen Smith Bell Manning, Inc. are hereby ORDERED to PAY, jointly and severally, petitioner Rosell R. Arguilles US$90,000.00 as total and permanent disability benefits. Interest at the rate of six percent (6%) per annum is likewise imposed on the total monetary award, reckoned from the date of finality of this judgment until its full satisfaction. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under Section 3(j) of Rule 131 of the Rules on Evidence, the disputable presumption that a person found in possession of a thing taken in the doing of a recent wrongful act is the taker applies only when such possession is unexplained by any innocent origin and the crime is proven to have been committed recently. Consequently, an accused who offers a satisfactory and plausible explanation for holding the item, such as picking it up from the ground during a commotion, successfully rebuts this presumption, rendering a conviction based solely on such possession legally unsustainable as it fails to overcome the constitutional presumption of innocence.
digest.facts: Petitioners Tijam and Bacsid were charged with theft after private complainant Mugot lost his cellphone while boarding a bus where he was allegedly pinned against the door by Bacsid. Mugot later saw Tijam hand the phone to Bacsid at the unloading area and immediately accused them of stealing it, while Tijam explained he merely picked up the phone from the ground after seeing it fall. The Regional Trial Court convicted the petitioners relying on the presumption that a person in possession of stolen goods is the taker, and the Court of Appeals affirmed this conviction holding that the prosecution established the elements of theft through circumstantial evidence including Mugots positive identification.
digest.issue: Whether the petitioners are guilty beyond reasonable doubt of simple theft based on the circumstantial evidence and presumption of possession.
digest.ruling: NO, the petitioners are not guilty. Under Section 3(j) of Rule 131 of the Rules on Evidence and established jurisprudence, the presumption of guilt arising from the possession of stolen goods is disputable and may be rebutted by a satisfactory explanation consistent with innocence. Here, Tijam plausibly explained that he picked up the phone from the pavement which is consistent with the chaotic situation of passengers rushing the bus, and the circumstantial evidence failed to establish an unbroken chain pointing to the petitioners to the exclusion of others. Hence, the presumption was sufficiently rebutted and the prosecution failed to prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt necessitating an acquittal.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the Petition for Review on Certiorari is GRANTED. The November 20, 2019 Decision and January 29, 2020 Resolution of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CR No. 42347 are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. Petitioners Julius Enrico Tijam and Kenneth Bacsid are hereby ACQUITTED on the ground that their guilt was not proven beyond reasonable doubt. Let entry of judgment be issued immediately. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under Section 2 Article XII of the Constitution the exploration of natural resources must be under the full control and supervision of the State and agreements with foreign-owned corporations involving large-scale exploration must be entered into by the President and reported to Congress. Consequently a Joint Marine Seismic Undertaking executed by a government corporation with foreign entities that allows joint ownership of data from seismic surveys constitutes illegal exploration and is unconstitutional as it surrenders the States full control over the information regarding the countrys natural resources.
digest.facts: Petitioners filed a suit assailing the constitutionality of the Tripartite Agreement for Joint Marine Seismic Undertaking (JMSU) entered into by the Philippine National Oil Company with the China National Offshore Oil Corporation and the Vietnam Oil and Gas Corporation covering an area in the South China Sea. Respondents filed a Motion for Reconsideration of the Supreme Courts decision which declared the agreement void arguing that the seismic surveys were merely pre-exploration activities not covered by the constitutional restriction and that the agreement was a corporate act of the PNOC that did not require the Presidents signature. The Court had previously ruled that the agreement involved exploration and violated the Constitution by allowing foreign access to and ownership of data regarding the countrys petroleum potential.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the activities under the JMSU constitute exploration under the Constitution.

2. Whether the JMSU is constitutional.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the activities constitute exploration. Under Section 2 Article XII of the Constitution and the Petroleum Act of 1949 exploration is defined as the search or discovery of natural resources which encompasses activities like seismic surveys designed to determine petroleum resource potential. Here the objective of the JMSU was explicitly to engage in joint research of petroleum resource potential in the agreement area through seismic work. Hence the agreement falls within the constitutional ambit of exploration.

2. NO, the JMSU is unconstitutional. Under Section 2 Article XII of the Constitution agreements with foreign-owned corporations for large-scale exploration must be entered into by the President and must ensure the States full control and supervision over the natural resources. Here the JMSU was not signed by the President but only by the PNOC head and it illegally allowed joint ownership of the information acquired from the seismic survey with foreign corporations. Hence the agreement is void for violating the constitutional mandate of full state control over natural resources and the requisite presidential execution.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the motion is DENIED with FINALITY. The Decision dated January 10, 2023 declaring the Tripartite Agreement for Joint Marine Seismic Undertaking in the Agreement Area in the South China Sea By and Among China National Offshore Oil Corporation and Vietnam Oil and Gas Corporation and Philippine National Oil Company unconstitutional and void is AFFIRMED.

digest.doctrine: Under the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability and the 2004 Rules on Notarial Practice, notarizing two deeds of sale covering the same property with different consideration amounts for the purpose of minimizing tax liability constitutes a serious offense involving falsehood and a defiance of the law. Consequently, a lawyer who prepares and notarizes a second deed of sale with a lower price to enable his client to evade correct taxes violates his solemn oath to do no falsehood and warrants the penalty of suspension from the practice of law and revocation of his notarial commission.
digest.facts: Complainant Mendoza filed a disbarment complaint against respondent Atty. Santiago, Jr. alleging that he notarized two Deeds of Absolute Sale covering the same 147-square meter property but indicating different amounts to minimize taxes. The first deed reflecting a price of P3,130,000.00 was used in an ejectment case, while the second deed reflecting a lower price of P1,500,000.00 was submitted to the Bureau of Internal Revenue and Registry of Deeds. Respondent argued that the complainant lacked legal personality and that his official function ceased upon submission of the documents. The IBP-CBD recommended suspension for one year and revocation of commission for two years, which the IBP Board of Governors modified by increasing the suspension to two years.
digest.issue: Whether respondent should be held administratively liable for notarizing two deeds of sale with different amounts for the same property.
digest.ruling: YES, the respondent is liable. Under the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability and the 2004 Rules on Notarial Practice, a lawyer is prohibited from counseling or abetting activities aimed at defiance of the law, and notarizing documents with untruthful consideration to reduce tax liability constitutes a serious offense. Here, the respondent admitted to notarizing the two deeds with different amounts for the purpose of minimizing his clients tax payments, thereby assisting in tax evasion and making a mockery of the notarial act. Hence, the respondent is suspended from the practice of law for two years and his notarial commission is revoked.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, respondent Atty. Cesar R. Santiago, Jr. is found GUILTY of violating the 2004 Rules on Notarial Practice and Canon VI of the Code of Professional Responsibility and Accountability. He is hereby SUSPENDED from the practice of law for a period of two (2) years; his notarial commission is hereby REVOKED, effective immediately; and he is hereby DISQUALIFIED from being commissioned as a notary public for a period of two (2) years. He is, likewise, STERNLY WARNED that a repetition of the same or similar act in the future will be dealt with more severely. He is DIRECTED to report the date of receipt of this Decision in order to determine when his suspension shall take effect.

digest.doctrine: The condonation doctrine, which prohibits disciplining elective officials for wrongful acts committed during a preceding term upon their reelection, applies strictly to elective officials and does not extend to appointed public officers. Consequently, appointed officials cannot invoke the reelection of their appointing authority or their own reappointment to evade administrative liability for past misconduct, as there is no expression of sovereign will or public trust involved in their retention.
digest.facts: Petitioners filed a complaint with the Ombudsman against Governor Garcia and appointed provincial officials Angeles, Talento, and De Mesa for violation of the Anti-Graft and Corrupt Practices Act regarding an alleged irregular tax delinquency sale and compromise agreement. The Ombudsman ordered the preventive suspension of the respondents, but they filed a petition for certiorari with the Court of Appeals invoking the existence of a prejudicial question and the condonation doctrine. The Court of Appeals reversed the Ombudsman, ruling that a prejudicial question existed and that the condonation doctrine effectively exonerated not only the reelected governor but also the appointed officials.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the condonation doctrine applies to appointed government officials.

2. Whether the Ombudsman committed grave abuse of discretion in ordering the preventive suspension of the respondents.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the doctrine does not apply. Under the ruling in Civil Service Commission v. Sojor, the condonation doctrine is strictly limited to elective officials because their reelection expresses the sovereign will of the people forgiving past faults, a principle inapplicable to appointed officials. Here, respondents Angeles, Talento, and De Mesa were appointed officials, not elected, at the time of the commission of the acts and during the subsequent terms. Hence, the Court of Appeals egregiously erred in extending the benefits of the condonation doctrine to them.

2. NO, the Ombudsman did not commit grave abuse of discretion. Under Section 24 of Republic Act No. 6770, the Ombudsman is expressly authorized to preventively suspend public officers pending investigation if the evidence of guilt is strong and the charge involves dishonesty, oppression, or grave misconduct. Here, the Ombudsman justified the suspension on the ground that the respondents continued stay in office posed a threat of intimidating witnesses or tampering with records vital to the prosecution. Hence, the preventive suspension was a valid exercise of the Ombudsmans discretionary power.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the petitions are PARTLY GRANTED. The Decision dated December 22, 2011 and the Resolution dated May 16, 2012 issued by the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 106026 are hereby REVERSED and SET ASIDE insofar as respondents Aurelio C. Angeles, Jr., Emerlinda S. Talento, and Rodolfo H. De Mesa are concerned. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under Section 52 of the Property Registration Decree and the rule of notice the registration of every conveyance or entry affecting registered land constitutes constructive notice to all persons from the time of such recording creating an irrebuttable presumption that a purchaser has examined every instrument of record affecting the title. Consequently buyers are charged with knowledge of all annotations and encumbrances on the mother title even if the specific certificates presented to them are clean precluding them from claiming the status of innocent purchasers for value when prior entries disclose the superior rights of another.
digest.facts: Petitioner Republic filed a complaint for cancellation of titles against respondents Espejo and others involving three parcels of land originally donated to Roxas National High School but subsequently titled to respondents through conflicting subdivision plans and unauthorized reconveyances by a school principal. Respondents Espejo claimed status as innocent purchasers for value because they relied on clean titles without adverse claims and confirmed through ocular inspection that the lots were outside the school fence. The Regional Trial Court ruled in favor of the respondents declaring their titles valid as buyers in good faith. The Court of Appeals affirmed the dismissal of the complaint holding that the respondents were not privy to the fraud and had exercised due diligence.
digest.issue: Whether the respondents are innocent purchasers for value whose titles should prevail over the rights of the petitioner.
digest.ruling: NO, the respondents are not innocent purchasers for value. Under Section 52 of the Property Registration Decree and the doctrine of constructive notice the registration of any instrument affecting registered land serves as notice to the whole world and a purchaser is presumed to know every fact shown by the record which cannot be overcome by proof of innocence or good faith. Here the respondents were charged with constructive notice of the annotations on the predecessor title TCT No. T-143478 which revealed the donation to the School and the lack of authority of the principal to reconvey the land regardless of whether they personally examined said title. Hence the respondents failed to validly acquire ownership and the Schools title must prevail.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the Petition for Review on Certiorari dated August 30, 2016 is GRANTED. The Decision dated March 15, 2016 and the Resolution dated June 30, 2016 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV No. 100085, which affirmed the Decision dated October 25, 2012 of the Regional Trial Court of Roxas, Isabela, Branch 23 are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. TCT No. T-241939, in the name of Gregorio Espejo, TCT No. T-250138, in the name of Ma. Carolina Espejo, and TCT No. 256435, in the names of Grelinda Espejo and Ma. Carolina Espejo, are declared NULL and VOID. The titles of their predecessors-in-interest, specifically, Roger V. Umipig, Alma V. Umipig, Helen V. Umipig and Faustino Llanes are, likewise, declared NULL and VOID. The Register of Deeds for the Province of Isabela is hereby ORDERED to issue new titles in favor of Roxas National High School.

digest.doctrine: Under the POEA Standard Employment Contract and established jurisprudence the referral to a third doctor is a mandatory procedure when the seafarers physician disagrees with the company-designated physicians assessment requiring the seafarer to send a valid written request accompanied by a medical report. However when the employer fails to respond to such a valid request the findings of the company-designated physician do not automatically become binding nor do the seafarers findings become conclusive rather the tribunals must resolve the conflict by weighing the inherent merits of the respective medical findings based on the totality of evidence. Consequently a seafarers claim for disability benefits will still be denied despite the employers violation of the referral procedure if the medical opinion of the seafarers chosen physician lacks scientific basis and is unsupported by medical records compared to the extensive and documented treatment provided by the company-designated physician.
digest.facts: Petitioner Bunayog a chief cook repatriated for pneumonia and pleural effusion was declared fit to work by the company-designated physician after two months of extensive treatment and monitoring. He subsequently consulted a personal physician who declared him unfit for sea duty prompting him to send a letter to respondent Foscon Shipmanagement attaching his doctors report and signifying his willingness to undergo a third doctor referral to which the respondents failed to reply. The Labor Arbiter dismissed his complaint for disability benefits giving credence to the company-designated physicians findings a ruling affirmed by the National Labor Relations Commission which held that the third doctor referral requires mutual agreement. The Court of Appeals likewise affirmed the dismissal noting that the assessment of the petitioners physician was not based on specific tests or treatment responses.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the failure of the employer to respond to the seafarers valid request for a third doctor referral renders the findings of the seafarers physician conclusive.

2. Whether the petitioner is entitled to total and permanent disability benefits based on the inherent merits of the medical findings.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the failure of the employer does not render the seafarers physicians findings conclusive. Under the guidelines established in this case and the POEA-SEC while an employers failure to respond to a valid request for a third doctor constitutes a violation of the contract the consequence is that the tribunals must weigh the inherent merits of the conflicting medical assessments rather than automatically favoring one side. Here the respondents ignored the petitioners valid request compelling the Court to review the medical findings of both parties based on the totality of evidence instead of applying the conclusiveness rule. Hence the case must be resolved on the merits of the medical evidence presented.

2. NO, the petitioner is not entitled to disability benefits. Under the principle that entitlement to disability benefits must be supported by substantial evidence and scientific basis the medical assessment of a physician which is vague and unsupported by diagnostic tests cannot prevail over one based on extensive treatment. Here the company-designated physicians declaration of fitness was supported by months of monitoring and diagnostic tests whereas the petitioners chosen doctor issued a certification without conducting any medical examination or discussing test results. Hence the findings of the company-designated physician prevail and the claim was correctly dismissed.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, in view of the foregoing premises, the instant petition is DISMISSED. The Court of Appeals Decision dated February 21, 2020 and the Resolution dated September 16, 2020 in CA-G.R. SP No. 154603, are AFFIRMED in toto. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under Rule 39 Section 12 of the Rules of Court a levy on execution creates a lien in favor of the judgment obligee over the right and title and interest of the judgment obligor in such property at the time of the levy subject to existing liens and encumbrances. Consequently a levy upon real property is valid and binding even if the certificate of title is not registered in the name of the judgment debtor provided that the evidence establishes that the debtor holds a beneficial interest or ownership right in the property at the time of the levy.
digest.facts: Petitioner Yau obtained a final executory judgment for a sum of money against Silverio Sr. and other directors of Philfinance which led to the sheriff levying upon Silverio Sr.s interest in three properties in Makati City known as the Intsia Cambridge and Bel-Air properties. Although these properties were registered in the names of Silverio Sr.s children the sheriff relied on a decision from a separate civil case which declared the properties to be conjugal assets of Silverio Sr. and his late wife to justify the levy. Respondent Judge Veloso issued orders nullifying the levy and sale upon the motion of Silverio Jr. ruling that the properties were not in Silverio Sr.s name and that the judgment award had been effectively reduced by a co-defendants successful appeal. Yau filed a petition for certiorari directly with the Supreme Court alleging grave abuse of discretion and arguing that the levy was valid based on Silverio Sr.s beneficial interest and that the execution could proceed despite Silverio Sr.s subsequent death.
digest.issue:
1. Whether Silverio Sr. had a leviable interest in the Makati properties at the time they were levied upon despite the titles not being registered in his name.

2. Whether the execution sale can proceed despite the alleged death of the judgment debtor.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the judgment debtor had a leviable interest. Under the beneficial interest test established by jurisprudence and the Rules of Court every interest which the judgment debtor may have in property may be subjected to levy on execution even if the title stands in the name of another. Here the evidence showed that while the titles were registered in the names of his children a final court decision in a separate case had declared the properties to be conjugal assets of Silverio Sr. and his late wife thereby establishing his ownership interest. Hence the levy was valid as Silverio Sr. held a beneficial interest in the properties at the time of the execution.

2. YES, the execution sale may proceed. Under Section 7 of Rule 39 of the Rules of Court if a judgment debtor dies after execution is actually levied upon any of his property the same may be sold for the satisfaction of the judgment. Here the levy and sale were completed years prior to Silverio Sr.s purported demise rendering the proceedings valid and enforceable against his estate without need for a separate claim in the settlement proceedings. Hence the execution sale could legally proceed although the Court ordered a new auction to adjust for the reduced judgment liability resulting from a co-debtors successful appeal.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the petition is GRANTED. The Orders dated November 25, 2010, December 6, 2010, and December 16, 2011, issued by the Regional Trial Court of Cebu City, Branch 6, in Civil Case No. CEB-2058, are hereby NULLIFIED and SET ASIDE. The July 26, 2001 auction sale and the August 6, 2001 Certificate of Sale issued by Sheriff Ruben S. Nequinto, still in Civil Case No. CEB-2058, are likewise NULLIFIED and SET ASIDE. The case is hereby REMANDED to the Regional Trial Court of Cebu City, Branch 6 for the conduct of a new auction sale and for further proceedings in accordance with this Decision. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: While affidavits of desistance executed after conviction are generally viewed with disfavor, they may engender serious doubts as to the liability of the accused when coupled with an express repudiation of material points alleged in the Information and special circumstances such as the non-presentation of the complainant during trial. Consequently, an accused must be acquitted of Estafa when the private complainant admits in a belated affidavit that no transaction occurred between the parties, thereby negating the essential elements of deceit and damage and destroying the prosecutions case beyond reasonable doubt.
digest.facts: Petitioner Manuel was charged with Estafa for issuing worthless checks allegedly in payment for live chickens purchased from Ebots Farm, which the prosecution claimed was owned by private complainant Uy. While prosecution witnesses testified that petitioner transacted with the farm and issued the checks, petitioner maintained she dealt with a different owner named Uson and issued the checks in blank, only for them to be filled out with Uys name without her knowledge. The Regional Trial Court convicted petitioner of Estafa sentencing her to thirty years of reclusion perpetua. The Court of Appeals affirmed the conviction but modified the penalty to an indeterminate sentence. During the appeal to the Supreme Court, petitioner submitted an Affidavit of Desistance from Uy, who had not testified during the trial, wherein Uy categorically admitted she had no transaction with petitioner and that the criminal charges had no legal basis.
digest.issue: Whether the petitioner is guilty beyond reasonable doubt of Estafa under Article 315, paragraph 2(d) of the Revised Penal Code considering the belated Affidavit of Desistance by the private complainant.
digest.ruling: NO, the petitioner is not guilty. Under established jurisprudence, while affidavits of desistance are generally frowned upon, they may warrant acquittal when special circumstances raise serious doubts about the truth of the testimony used to convict, particularly when the essential elements of deceit and damage are negated. Here, the private complainants affidavit and subsequent testimony explicitly repudiated the existence of any transaction or obligation between her and the petitioner, contradicting the prosecution witnesses assertions and proving that the checks were not issued to defraud her. Hence, the prosecution failed to prove the elements of deceit and damage beyond reasonable doubt, necessitating the petitioners acquittal and the extinguishment of civil liability.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the Petition for Review on Certiorari dated September 18, 2014 filed by petitioner Lucia Manuel y Cadiz is GRANTED. The Decision dated February 21, 2014 and the Resolution dated July 23, 2014 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CR-HC No. 05737 convicting petitioner are hereby REVERSED and SET ASIDE. Petitioner is ACQUITTED of the crime of Estafa defined and penalized under Article 315, paragraph 2(d) of the Revised Penal Code on the ground of reasonable doubt.

digest.doctrine: The crime of violence against women and children committed through denial of financial support is mala in se and requires the concurrence of the willful denial of support legally due and the specific criminal intent to inflict mental or emotional anguish upon the victim. Consequently, the mere failure or inability to provide financial support does not give rise to criminal liability if there is no evidence that the accused willfully withheld such support for the specific purpose of causing the woman psychological pain or suffering.
digest.facts: Petitioner XXX and private complainant AAA were married in 2002 but separated in 2004 when XXX worked abroad as a seafarer. XXX initially remitted part of his salary but stopped later that year to pay for his parents cancer treatments, subsequently losing communication with AAA for thirteen years while she supported herself through a sari-sari store and massage therapy work. Years later, after AAA learned XXX had returned to the country without contacting her, she filed a case for violation of Section 5(i) of Republic Act No. 9262 alleging economic abuse and abandonment. The Regional Trial Court convicted the petitioner for denial of financial support, a decision affirmed by the Court of Appeals which held that the unilateral decision to stop support caused the victim pain and suffering.
digest.issue: Whether the petitioner is guilty beyond reasonable doubt of violating Section 5(i) of Republic Act No. 9262 for denial of financial support.
digest.ruling: NO, the petitioner is not guilty. Under Section 5(i) of Republic Act No. 9262 and established jurisprudence, the crime of denial of financial support is mala in se requiring proof that the accused willfully denied support for the specific purpose of inflicting mental or emotional anguish upon the woman. Here, the petitioner stopped sending support not to inflict pain but to pay for his parents medical expenses, and the prosecution failed to prove he knew AAA needed support given her lack of demand and her own gainful employment. Hence, the elements of willful denial and criminal intent were not established, necessitating his acquittal.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, premises considered, the Petition for Review on Certiorari is hereby GRANTED. The Decision dated September 12, 2019 and the Resolution dated February 11, 2021 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CR No. 41438 are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. Petitioner XXX is ACQUITTED of the crime charged. Let an entry of final judgment be issued immediately. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Bad faith under Section 3(e) of Republic Act No 3019 does not simply connote bad judgment or negligence but necessitates a manifest deliberate intent on the part of the accused to do wrong or to cause damage spurred by a corrupt motive or ill will. Consequently the temporary stoppage of remittance of salary deductions to a mutual benefit association by a public officer due to a pending leadership controversy constitutes a prudent management decision to protect the funds rather than an act of evident bad faith or manifest partiality warranting criminal indictment.
digest.facts: Petitioners filed criminal and administrative charges against private respondent Romero the Officer-in-Charge of the Bureau of Fire Protection for stopping the remittance of salary deductions to the BFPMBAI mutual aid association and for allegedly coercing them to recognize him as chairman. Private respondent argued the stoppage was necessary due to a leadership dispute following a failed election resulting in two conflicting boards and he subsequently filed an interpleader case while the funds reverted to the Bureau of the Treasury. The Ombudsman dismissed all charges finding that the private respondent acted in good faith to protect the funds pending the legal resolution of the legitimate board and that the remedy for the administrative dismissal was improper. Petitioners filed a certiorari petition directly with the Supreme Court challenging the dismissal of both the criminal and administrative complaints.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the petitioners utilized the correct remedy in filing a petition for certiorari directly with the Supreme Court to assail the Ombudsmans dismissal of the administrative charges.

2. Whether the Ombudsman committed grave abuse of discretion in finding no probable cause to charge the private respondent with violation of the Anti-Graft and Corrupt Practices Act and Grave Coercion.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the petitioners failed to utilize the correct remedy. Under established jurisprudence and the rules of procedure the proper remedy to assail the Ombudsmans decision dismissing an administrative charge is a petition for certiorari under Rule 65 filed with the Court of Appeals not the Supreme Court. Here the petitioners filed a Rule 65 petition directly with the Supreme Court covering both criminal and administrative aspects effectively by-passing the appellate court for the administrative portion. Hence the Supreme Court lacks jurisdiction to review the administrative aspect of the Ombudsmans ruling which has attained finality.

2. NO, the Ombudsman did not commit grave abuse of discretion. Under Section 3(e) of Republic Act No 3019 and Article 286 of the Revised Penal Code probable cause requires evidence of manifest partiality evident bad faith or specific intent to coerce which mere bad judgment or disagreement with legal strategy does not constitute. Here the private respondent stopped the remittances not out of malice or for personal gain but to protect the funds amidst a leadership dispute within the association and the funds were reverted to the National Treasury rather than misappropriated. Hence the dismissal of the criminal charges was proper as there was no evidence of criminal intent or undue injury to the government or the association.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the instant original Petition for Certiorari is hereby DISMISSED for lack of merit. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Forgery must be proved by clear, positive, and convincing evidence, yet the courts are not bound by expert testimony and may independently determine authenticity through a visual comparison of the questioned signature against genuine specimens. Consequently, a deed of donation is properly declared void where a visual comparison reveals patent dissimilarities in signatures and the purported donees own acts, such as negotiating a lease for the same property, imply a recognition of the adverse parties ownership.
digest.facts: Respondent Buenaventura filed a complaint for sum of money and damages against the petitioners after they constructed a road on his property without his consent. While the parties initially negotiated a draft memorandum of agreement for the temporary use of the land, the Sangguniang Bayan rejected it, prompting the suit where petitioners claimed ownership based on a Deed of Donation allegedly executed by respondent in favor of the barangay. The Regional Trial Court dismissed the complaint ruling the notarized Deed of Donation valid, but the Court of Appeals reversed the decision declaring the deed forged based on signature variances and ordering the removal of the road and payment of rentals.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the Deed of Donation is valid and sufficient to support the petitioners construction on the subject premises.

2. Whether the respondent is entitled to the removal of the road and payment of rentals.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the Deed of Donation is not valid. Under the rule that forgery is established by clear and convincing evidence, a judge may conduct an independent visual comparison of questioned signatures and is not bound by expert testimony to determine authenticity. Here, a simple visual examination revealed patent dissimilarities between the respondents genuine signatures and the one on the deed, and the petitioners prior attempt to negotiate a lease via a Sangguniang Bayan resolution served as an implied recognition of the respondents ownership. Hence, the deed is void as the signature therein is forged and spurious.

2. NO, the respondent is not entitled to removal but to just compensation. Under established jurisprudence, when the return of the property is no longer feasible because a road has been constructed thereon, the remedy is the payment of just compensation to prevent irreparable injury to the public who rely on the access. Here, the road was already built and in use, making recovery of possession impossible without prejudicing the public interest. Hence, the order to remove the road is deleted and the petitioners are instead ordered to pay just compensation equivalent to the fair market value at the time of taking plus interest and exemplary damages.

digest.doctrine: Breach of trust and confidence as a just cause for termination requires clear and substantial proof that the employee holding a position of trust involving the custody of employer property willfully committed acts rendering them unworthy of such trust. Consequently a bank officer who repeatedly violates internal control policies regarding signature verification and transaction processing even if motivated by customer service and resulting in no financial loss validly breaches the trust reposed in her warranting dismissal given the extraordinary diligence required of banks in the selection and supervision of their employees.
digest.facts: Respondent Rogan a Branch Cash/Operations Officer at Citibank Savings Inc. was terminated for gross and habitual neglect and loss of trust and confidence after she allowed the Branch Account Officer to process several fund transfers for joint accounts without the required signature verification and callback procedures in violation of the banks Manually Initiated Fund Transfer policy and Separation of Functions rule. Rogan argued the transactions were safe First Party Transfers and that she acted for customer convenience but the bank cited her prior suspension for a cash count irregularity as aggravating the offense. The Labor Arbiter dismissed her illegal dismissal complaint finding valid grounds for termination a ruling affirmed by the National Labor Relations Commission which held she was a managerial employee who failed to safeguard bank processes. However the Court of Appeals reversed these findings and declared the dismissal illegal ruling that the lapses did not amount to willful breach of trust as there was no proof of bad faith or actual loss to the bank.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the respondent is guilty of gross and habitual neglect of duty.

2. Whether the respondent was validly dismissed for loss of trust and confidence.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the respondent is not guilty of gross and habitual neglect. Under established labor jurisprudence gross neglect implies a want of slight care or thoughtless disregard of consequences while habitual neglect implies a repeated failure to perform duties over a period of time. Here the transactions involved First Party Transfers which were generally deemed safe and Rogan exercised her prerogative to allow exception processing for customer convenience without evidence of bad faith or repeated reckless behavior during the relevant period. Hence the evidence failed to establish that her actions rose to the level of gross and habitual neglect.

2. YES, the dismissal was valid based on loss of trust and confidence. Under Article 297(c) of the Labor Code and the principle of extraordinary diligence required of banks a breach of trust occurs when an employee holding a fiduciary position or custody of property willfully violates company policies rendering them unworthy of the trust demanded by their position. Here Rogan occupied a sensitive position as a custodian of bank funds and her accumulated lapses in implementing signature verification and fund transfer policies coupled with a prior disciplinary infraction sufficiently established a breach of the trust reposed in her. Hence her dismissal is justified although she is awarded separation pay as financial assistance due to the absence of dishonesty or financial loss to the bank.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the present petition is PARTIALLY GRANTED. The May 16, 2014 Decision and the September 30, 2015 Resolution of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 122602 are hereby REVERSED and SET ASIDE. Judgment is hereby rendered ORDERING Citibank Savings, Inc. and/or its successors-in-interest to PAY Brenda L. Rogan separation pay as financial assistance, in the amount of one-half (1/2) months salary for every year of service. This case is hereby REMANDED to the Labor Arbiter for the proper computation of the amount of separation pay due to Brenda L. Rogan.

digest.doctrine: A contract to sell is a bilateral contract where the prospective seller reserves ownership until the full payment of the purchase price which acts as a positive suspensive condition the non-fulfillment of which prevents the obligation to convey title from arising. Consequently the remedy of rescission is unavailable in a contract to sell because the failure to pay the price is not a breach of contract but merely an event that renders the contract ineffective and without force and effect.
digest.facts: Petitioner De Guzman and respondents Spouses Santos entered into a Contract to Sell for a house and lot wherein respondents paid a down payment and took possession but subsequently failed to pay the agreed monthly installments and abandoned the property. Respondents filed a complaint for rescission and refund while the petitioner during the pendency of the case sold the property to a third party which prompted the Regional Trial Court to rescind the contract and order a refund due to the petitioners bad faith. The Court of Appeals affirmed the decision ruling that the petitioners act of selling the subject property to a third party rendered the enforcement of the contract moot and necessitated the return of the down payment in the interest of justice and equity.
digest.issue: Whether the respondents are entitled to the rescission of the Contract to Sell and the reimbursement of their down payment.
digest.ruling: NO, the respondents are not entitled to rescission or reimbursement. Under established jurisprudence a contract to sell is not subject to rescission because the non-payment of the purchase price is not a breach of contract but a failure of a positive suspensive condition that prevents the obligation to sell from acquiring obligatory force. Here the respondents failure to pay the installments prevented the petitioners obligation to convey title from arising and the contract expressly provided for automatic cancellation and forfeiture of payments upon default. Hence the Court of Appeals erred in ordering the reimbursement of the down payment as the contract was effectively cancelled and the payments forfeited pursuant to the parties agreement.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, premises considered, the Petition for Review on Certiorari is granted. The Decision dated December 18, 2014 and the Resolution dated February 18, 2016 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV No. 100706 are REVERSED and SET ASIDE.
