digest.doctrine: Extraterritorial service of summons by publication upon a non-resident defendant requires strict compliance with the order to send copies of the summons to the defendants last known correct address yet a defect in such service is cured by the defendants voluntary appearance in the action through the filing of a motion seeking affirmative relief. Consequently the subsequent voluntary submission of the defendant to the courts jurisdiction negates the need for dismissal of the complaint and instead warrants a remand of the case to the trial court to allow the defendant to participate in the proceedings and satisfy the hearing aspect of due process.
digest.facts: Salvador filed a complaint for quieting of title and annulment of free patent against Marivic involving a fishpond originally owned by their predecessors but titled to Marivic who resided in the USA. Salvador effected service of summons by publication but mailed the copy of the summons to Marivic's last known address in the Philippines instead of her US address as ordered by the court resulting in Marivic being declared in default. The Regional Trial Court rendered judgment nullifying Marivic's title and subsequently denied her Motion for New Trial which alleged fraud and defective service of summons. The Court of Appeals reversed the trial court and dismissed the complaint ruling that the failure to mail the summons to the correct foreign address was a fatal defect in the service of summons.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the extraterritorial service of summons on the non-resident defendant was valid.

2. Whether the defect in the service of summons was cured by the defendants voluntary appearance.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the service of summons was not valid. Under Section 15 of Rule 14 of the Rules of Court extraterritorial service by publication strictly requires that a copy of the summons and the court order be sent by registered mail to the last known address of the defendant. Here Salvador failed to comply with this mandatory requirement by mailing the documents to the defendants Philippine address despite having knowledge of her actual residence in the USA as indicated in the court order. Hence the failure to strictly comply with the requirements of the rules regarding the mailing of copies rendered the service of summons defective.

2. YES, the defect was cured by voluntary appearance. Under the Rules of Court and established jurisprudence a defendants voluntary appearance in the action such as filing a motion for new trial seeking affirmative relief is equivalent to service of summons and cures the jurisdictional defect. Here Marivic submitted herself to the jurisdiction of the Regional Trial Court by filing a Motion for New Trial to defend her interest in the property which satisfied the notice requirement of due process. Hence the case should be remanded for trial anew to satisfy the hearing aspect of due process rather than dismissed.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, premises considered, the Petition for Review on Certiorari is PARTLY GRANTED. The assailed Decision dated July 20, 2017 and Resolution dated October 23, 2017 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV No. 107226 are AFFIRMED with MODIFICATION in that the Complaint docketed as Civil Case No. OD-943 before the Regional Trial Court, Branch 82 of Odiongan, Romblon is hereby REINSTATED. Said court is DIRECTED to allow Marivic Solis-Laynes to file a responsive pleading in accordance with the Rules of Court and to participate in the trial of the case; and thereafter, for said trial court to resolve the case with utmost dispatch. Accordingly, the case is REMANDED to the trial court for further proceedings. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under Section 11 Rule 14 of the Rules of Court the list of officers authorized to receive summons for a domestic corporation is exclusive and strict compliance is required to acquire jurisdiction over the person of the defendant unless there is voluntary appearance. Consequently a service of summons upon a mere receiving officer is defective and the defendants filing of an Answer Ad Cautelam by way of special appearance to explicitly question such jurisdiction does not constitute voluntary submission to the courts authority provided no inconsistent affirmative relief is sought.
digest.facts: Petitioner Diversified obtained loans from All Asia and DBP secured by a Mortgage Trust Indenture MTI which were later assigned to respondent PI-One an SPV. PI-One filed a petition in the RTC of Makati to be appointed as trustee under the MTI alleging a vacancy but served the summons only on Diversifieds receiving officer rather than the specific officers enumerated in the Rules of Court. Diversified filed an Answer Ad Cautelam expressly questioning the jurisdiction due to improper service while PI-One argued that this constituted voluntary appearance. The Regional Trial Court granted the petition and appointed PI-One as trustee ruling that the jurisdictional defect was cured by the petitioners participation a decision affirmed by the Court of Appeals which held that the RTC had jurisdiction and that PI-One validly acquired the trustee rights through assignment.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the Regional Trial Court acquired jurisdiction over the person of the petitioner despite the defective service of summons.

2. Whether the respondent is qualified to be appointed as trustee under the Mortgage Trust Indenture.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the RTC did not acquire jurisdiction. Under Section 11 Rule 14 of the Rules of Court service of summons on a domestic corporation is restricted to specific officers and a special appearance to challenge jurisdiction does not constitute voluntary submission. Here the summons was served on a receiving officer who is not among those authorized by the rules and the petitioners filing of an Answer Ad Cautelam explicitly reserved its objection to the jurisdiction without seeking affirmative relief that would imply acquiescence. Hence the service was defective and the proceedings were void as the petitioner did not voluntarily submit to the courts authority.

2. NO, the respondent is not qualified to be trustee. Under the Civil Code rules on assignment of credits and the SPV Law an assignee is subrogated to the rights of the assignor but is bound by the same conditions and cannot acquire greater rights than what the assignor possessed. Here the assignment was invalid due to the failure to comply with the notice requirements of the SPV Law and the respondent failed to meet the specific contractual requirement of being an institution authorized to engage in the trust business. Hence the respondent cannot be appointed as trustee under the Mortgage Trust Indenture as it does not possess the necessary qualifications.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the Petition for Review on Certiorari dated March 15, 2018 filed by Diversified Plastic Film System, Inc. is GRANTED, and the Decision dated July 20, 2017 and the Resolution dated January 17, 2018 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV No. 107210 are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. The Petition for Appointment as Trustee in Special Proceedings No. M-7875 filed by Philippine Investment One (SPV-AMC), Inc. is hereby DISMISSED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: While parties to a contract have the right to stipulate terms and conditions including periods for legal action such right is not absolute and must be reasonable and not contrary to public policy otherwise the general provisions of the law on prescription will apply. Consequently a stipulation in government infrastructure bidding documents limiting the period for a contractor to refer a dispute to an arbiter to fourteen days is void for being unreasonably short and contrary to public policy thus the ten-year prescriptive period under the Civil Code applies to the contractors request for arbitration.
digest.facts: Petitioner awarded two road construction contracts to respondent which were completed but later found to have defects leading the petitioner to issue notices to rectify and subsequently decisions terminating the contracts. Respondent filed a request for arbitration with the Construction Industry Arbitration Commission claiming unpaid billings which petitioner moved to dismiss on grounds of lack of jurisdiction arguing there was no arbitration agreement and that the claim was time-barred for not being filed within the fourteen-day period stipulated in the bidding documents. The Construction Industry Arbitration Commission denied the motion and ruled in favor of respondent finding the projects completed and the termination invalid a decision affirmed with modification by the Court of Appeals which held that the arbitration clause was incorporated by reference and the claim was not time-barred.
digest.issue:
1. Whether there was a valid agreement between the parties for Construction Industry Arbitration Commission jurisdiction.

2. Whether the respondents Request for Arbitration was time-barred by the fourteen-day period in the bidding documents.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, there was a valid agreement for arbitration. Under the Revised Implementing Rules and Regulations of Republic Act No 9184 and established jurisprudence arbitration clauses in bidding documents are deemed incorporated into the contract agreement by reference and courts should liberally construe such clauses in favor of arbitration. Here the contract agreements expressly stated that the bidding documents formed part of the contract and the bidding documents specifically provided for arbitration of disputes. Hence the Construction Industry Arbitration Commission properly acquired jurisdiction over the controversy despite the absence of an explicit arbitration clause in the main contract document.

2. NO, the request was not time-barred. Under Article 1306 of the Civil Code contractual stipulations must not be contrary to public policy and jurisprudence dictates that contractual limitations on actions must be reasonable. Here the fourteen-day period stipulated in the bidding documents to refer a decision to an arbiter is unreasonably short and insufficient for an aggrieved contractor to prepare for arbitration making it void and contrary to public policy. Hence the general ten-year prescriptive period under Article 1144 of the Civil Code applies and the respondents claim was filed well within this period.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the instant Petition is hereby DENIED for lack of merit, and accordingly, the Decision dated February 28, 2018 and Resolution dated January 10, 2019 of the Court of Appeals 14th Division in CA-G.R. SP Nos. 143721 & 145399 are hereby AFFIRMED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: When an action is founded upon written instruments attached to the pleading the genuineness and due execution of such actionable documents are deemed admitted unless the adverse party specifically denies them under oath and sets forth the matters relied upon to support the denial. Consequently a sole proprietor who admits ownership of the business entity named in the invoices but issues only general denials regarding the transactions fails to properly contest the documents resulting in an implied admission of liability and the authority of the signatories under the doctrine of negative pregnant.
digest.facts: Petitioner Chevron filed a complaint for sum of money against respondent Alberto Looyuko and his co-respondents for unpaid purchases of petroleum products covered by 105 invoices issued to Noahs Ark Sugar Refinery. While Alberto denied in his Answer that he ever transacted with Chevron or authorized the purchases he contradictorily admitted that the refinery was a sole proprietorship registered in his name and failed to specifically deny the authority of the employees who received the deliveries. The Regional Trial Court rendered judgment in favor of Chevron finding Alberto liable as the owner of the refinery but the Court of Appeals reversed the decision ruling that there was no perfected contract of sale or proof of delivery.
digest.issue: Whether the respondent is liable for the unpaid purchases evidenced by the invoices despite his denial of knowledge and participation in the transactions.
digest.ruling: YES, the respondent is liable. Under the Rules of Court and established jurisprudence a denial is considered a negative pregnant if it denies only the qualification but admits the substantial facts or fails to specifically deny under oath the genuineness and due execution of actionable documents. Here the respondent admitted being the registered owner of the refinery named in the invoices and failed to specifically deny the authority of the employees who signed for the deliveries thereby impliedly admitting the validity of the transactions and his liability under the principle of agency by estoppel. Hence the Court reinstated the trial courts decision with modification as to the interest rates and attorneys fees.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the instant Petition is hereby GRANTED. The Decision dated July 20, 2017 and Resolution dated January 4, 2018 of the Court of Appeals Special 15th Division in CA-G.R. CV No. 107098 are accordingly REVERSED and SET ASIDE, and the Decision dated July 29, 2015 of the Regional Trial Court of Manila (Branch 10) in Civil Case No. 99-92415 is hereby REINSTATED with the following MODIFICATIONS: 1) Respondents principal indebtedness to petitioner Chevron Philippines, Inc. shall have an interest rate of 12% from August 21, 1998 (when petitioner Chevron Philippines, Inc.s formal Demand Letter was received) to June 30, 2013, and at six percent (6%) from July 1, 2013 onwards until fully paid; 2) The interest on respondents principal indebtedness covering the time from the generation of the last invoice up to January 25, 1999, which was when petitioner Chevron Philippines, Inc. judicially demanded the same when it filed its Complaint, shall be at six percent (6%) until fully paid, in accordance with Article 2212 of the Civil Code; and 3) 20% of respondents principal indebtedness shall be attorneys fees payable to petitioner Chevron Philippines, Inc. in accordance with the invoices conditions of sale, replacing the earlier award of the trial court of P1,020,846.17. FURTHER, the total monetary award shall also bear legal interest of six percent (6%) from finality of this Decision until full payment. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Just compensation for lands acquired under the Comprehensive Agrarian Reform Program must be determined based on the valuation factors enumerated in Section 17 of Republic Act No 6657 and the relevant DAR administrative orders existing at the time of taking. Consequently the valuation of corn lands acquired through a voluntary offer to sell under the said law must follow the formula prescribed in DAR Administrative Order No 5 Series of 1998 rather than the formula under Presidential Decree No 27 which applies to a different mode of acquisition.
digest.facts: Respondents the heirs of Tayko voluntarily offered their estate comprising sugar corn and coco lands for agrarian reform coverage under Republic Act No 6657 resulting in the transfer of titles to the Republic on December 30 2003. Petitioner Land Bank valued the property using 1997 data which respondents rejected prompting them to file for determination of just compensation where the Regional Agrarian Reform Adjudicator and subsequently the DARAB valued the corn lands using the formula under Presidential Decree No 27. The Regional Trial Court sitting as a Special Agrarian Court ruled in favor of respondents increasing the valuation but the Court of Appeals reversed this decision remanding the valuation for sugar lands while affirming the DARABs valuation for the corn lands based on the Presidential Decree No 27 formula.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the corn lands acquired under Republic Act No 6657 should be valued using the formula provided under Presidential Decree No 27.

2. Whether the imposition of legal interest on the unpaid balance of just compensation is proper.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the corn lands should not be valued under Presidential Decree No 27. Under Section 17 of Republic Act No 6657 and established jurisprudence the determination of just compensation for lands acquired under the Comprehensive Agrarian Reform Program must consider specific factors such as cost of acquisition current value nature actual use and income. Here the subject corn lands were acquired through a voluntary offer to sell under Republic Act No 6657 yet the lower tribunals erroneously applied the formula for rice and corn lands under Presidential Decree No 27. Hence the valuation must be set aside and remanded for recomputation using the formula in DAR Administrative Order No 5 Series of 1998 based on data at the time of taking.

2. YES, the imposition of legal interest is proper. Under established case law delay in the payment of just compensation is deemed an effective forbearance on the part of the State entitling the landowner to legal interest to ensure the compensation remains fair and substantial. Here the petitioner made an initial deposit that was rejected and the final just compensation remains to be determined and fully paid necessitating interest on the unpaid balance from the time of taking until full payment. Hence the petitioner is liable for interest at twelve percent per annum from December 30 2003 to June 30 2013 and six percent per annum thereafter.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, premises considered, the Petition for Review on Certiorari dated June 22, 2017 filed by petitioner Land Bank of the Philippines is PARTIALLY GRANTED. Accordingly, the Decision dated June 14, 2016 and the Resolution dated March 29, 2017 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 06198 are hereby AFFIRMED with MODIFICATIONS in that: (1) The award fixing just compensation for respondents 60.0932-hectare land planted with corn in the amount of P6,306,786.00 is hereby DELETED and Civil Case No. 2010-14471 is hereby REMANDED to the Regional Trial Court of Dumaguete City, Branch 32, for reception of evidence to determine with utmost dispatch the just compensation due to respondents strictly in accordance with the guidelines set forth in this Resolution. (2) Petitioner Land Bank of the Philippines is ORDERED to pay respondents legal interest on the unpaid balance of the just compensation at the interest rate of twelve percent (12%) per annum from the time of taking, on December 30, 2003 until June 30, 2013, and six percent (6%) per annum thereafter until fully paid.

digest.doctrine: An action for reconveyance based on the nullity of a void judgment or a void contract such as a forged deed of donation is imprescriptible and laches cannot be set up to resist its enforcement because a forged deed conveys no title and renders all subsequent transactions null and void. Consequently a petition to cancel an adverse claim cannot be granted on the ground of prescription when the underlying claim involves a forged instrument as the right to recover the property remains enforceable regardless of the lapse of time.
digest.facts: Petitioner Rosita Zamora and her late husband Jesus originally owned a parcel of land which was transferred to Zenaida Lazaro via an alleged Deed of Donation executed on the same day Jesus died. Years later Rosita filed an Affidavit of Adverse Claim on the title alleging forgery which prompted the respondents Lazaro's children who subsequently acquired the land to file a petition for cancellation of the adverse claim. The Regional Trial Court denied the petition finding that the deed was forged as evidenced by signature discrepancies and the impossibility of Jesus signing it on his deathbed but the Court of Appeals reversed this decision ruling that Rositas right to recover the property had already prescribed and was barred by laches.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the Court of Appeals erred in ruling that the action for reconveyance had prescribed.

2. Whether the adverse claim should be cancelled.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the Court of Appeals erred as the action is imprescriptible. Under established jurisprudence an action for reconveyance based on a void contract or a forged deed which is a nullity and conveys no title does not prescribe and cannot be barred by laches. Here the Deed of Donation was proven to be spurious with forged signatures of the spouses Zamora rendering the transfer to Lazaro and the subsequent sale to the Bagatsings null and void ab initio. Hence Rositas right to file an action for reconveyance remains valid and has not prescribed despite the lapse of time.

2. NO, the adverse claim should not be cancelled. Under the principles governing land registration an adverse claim is a measure designed to protect the interest of a claimant over real property by notifying third parties of a controversy over ownership. Here the Supreme Court found merit in Rositas adverse claim because the underlying Deed of Donation was a forgery thereby validating her continued interest in the property against the void title of the respondents. Hence the Regional Trial Court correctly denied the petition for cancellation of the adverse claim.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, premises considered, the petition is GRANTED. The Decision dated November 28, 2019 and the Resolution dated October 9, 2020 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV No. 111516, ordering the cancellation of the Notice of Adverse Claim, are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. The Decision of the Regional Trial Court of Pasay City, Branch 118 dated May 24, 2018 in LRC Case No. R-PSY-16-24198-CV is hereby REINSTATED, and respondents Ramon L. Bagatsing, Jr., Rosarito L. Bagatsing, Reynaldo L. Bagatsing, and Marilyn Bagatsing-Topacio's Petition for Cancellation of Annotation of Adverse Claim is DISMISSED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Violations of procurement laws and regulations do not automatically result in a finding of probable cause under Section 3(e) of Republic Act No 3019 as the prosecution must still establish the distinct elements of evident bad faith manifest partiality or gross inexcusable negligence and the causing of undue injury or giving of unwarranted benefits. Consequently a public officer who utilizes the alternative method of shopping to procure supplies from a sibling offering the lowest price does not commit graft where the specific disclosure requirement under the procurement law applies only to competitive bidding and the transaction yields the most advantageous price for the government.
digest.facts: Petitioner the Vice-Chairman of the Bids and Awards Committee of the Municipality of Palauig was charged with violation of Section 3(e) of Republic Act No 3019 for allegedly favoring a supplier owned by her sister in the procurement of office supplies via shopping. The Ombudsman found probable cause to indict the petitioner ruling that she acted with manifest partiality and evident bad faith by failing to disclose her relationship with the supplier as allegedly required by Section 47 of the Implementing Rules and Regulations of Republic Act No 9184 and for failing to comply with posting requirements. Petitioner filed a petition for certiorari arguing that the disclosure requirement applies only to competitive bidding and not to shopping and that the elements of the offense were not present.
digest.issue: Whether the Ombudsman gravely abused its discretion in finding probable cause against the petitioner for violation of Section 3(e) of Republic Act No 3019.
digest.ruling: YES, the Ombudsman gravely abused its discretion. Under Section 47 of Republic Act No 9184 the requirement to disclose relations constitutes a requisite for competitive bidding documents and does not apply to the alternative method of shopping where efficiency is paramount. Here the petitioner validly resorted to shopping and obtained the lowest price from fifteen quotations proving that the transaction was advantageous to the government and devoid of the manifest partiality or evident bad faith required for a graft indictment. Hence the finding of probable cause was legally baseless as the procedural lapse regarding posting did not equate to a criminal design to favor the supplier.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, premises considered, the Petition for Certiorari dated April 10, 2017 is hereby GRANTED. The Resolution dated June 30, 2016 and Order dated January 5, 2017 issued by the Office of the Ombudsman insofar as they found probable cause to indict petitioner Corazon C. Reyes for violating Section 3(e) of Republic Act No. 3019, are hereby REVERSED and SET ASIDE. Accordingly, the criminal Complaint for violation of Section 3(e) of Republic Act No. 3019, is DISMISSED for lack of probable cause. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Just compensation is determined as of the date of actual taking and presupposes that the claimant is the owner of the private property at the time the expropriator enters and devotes it to public use. Consequently, a claim for just compensation is properly denied where the subject property was still part of the public domain at the time the government constructed transmission lines thereon and was only acquired by the claimants predecessor through a free patent decades later.
digest.facts: Respondent National Grid Corporation of the Philippines instituted expropriation proceedings in 2014 involving a portion of a lot traversed by transmission lines to clear hazardous vegetation, depositing the zonal value of the property. Petitioners, heirs of the registered owner who obtained a free patent over the land only in 2012, claimed just compensation reckoned from the 2014 filing, arguing that the original entry by the National Power Corporation in 1978 was illegal. The Regional Trial Court ruled in favor of the petitioners and awarded substantial just compensation, but the Court of Appeals modified the decision by deleting the monetary award, holding that the taking occurred in 1978 when the land was still public domain and subject to a statutory easement.
digest.issue: Whether the petitioners are entitled to just compensation.
digest.ruling: NO, the petitioners are not entitled to just compensation. Under the principles of eminent domain and established jurisprudence, just compensation is reckoned from the date of actual taking, which occurs when the expropriator enters the property for a permanent public purpose, and requires the claimant to be the owner at that time. Here, the taking occurred in 1978 upon the construction of the transmission lines when the property was still part of the public domain and owned by the State, as petitioners predecessor only acquired the free patent in 2012. Hence, the petitioners have no right to compensation for the land and must return the amount provisionally deposited by the respondent under the principle of solutio indebiti.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, premises considered, the July 26, 2019 Decision and August 4, 2020 Resolution of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV No. 05180-MIN are AFFIRMED with MODIFICATION. Petitioners Heirs of Raisa Dimao are hereby ORDERED to RETURN to respondent National Grid Corporation of the Philippines the amount of P1,756,400.00. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: The general rule that the negligence of counsel binds the client is not absolute and admits of exceptions such as when the reckless or gross negligence of counsel deprives the client of due process of law or results in the outright deprivation of liberty. Consequently where a lawyer fails to file an appeal despite promising to do so and misrepresents to the client that the appeal has been filed such acts constitute gross negligence that warrants the relaxation of procedural rules to recall an entry of judgment and allow the accused to pursue their appeal to prevent a miscarriage of justice.
digest.facts: Petitioner Conche was convicted by the Regional Trial Court for violation of the Comprehensive Dangerous Drugs Act a decision affirmed by the Court of Appeals in September 2015. His counsel Atty. Gutierrez received the decision but failed to file an appeal or motion for reconsideration causing the judgment to become final and executory while simultaneously misrepresenting to the petitioner and his wife that she had already filed an appeal to the Supreme Court. Upon discovering the deception years later through the assistance of a paralegal group the petitioner secured the services of the Public Attorneys Office which filed a Motion to Recall Entry of Judgment and Notice of Appeal alleging gross negligence of the previous counsel. The Court of Appeals denied the motion ruling that the negligence of counsel binds the client and finding no compelling reason to reopen the case.
digest.issue: Whether the gross negligence and misrepresentation of the petitioners counsel warrants the recall of the entry of judgment and the reinstatement of the right to appeal.
digest.ruling: YES, the recall of the entry of judgment is warranted. Under established jurisprudence the rule that the negligence of counsel binds the client does not apply when such negligence is so gross that it deprives the accused of due process or results in the outright deprivation of liberty. Here the petitioners counsel not only failed to file the appeal but also deceived the petitioner into believing it had been filed thereby preventing him from seeking timely legal recourse while he remained diligent in following up his case. Hence the Court ruled that the petitioner should not be bound by his counsels gross negligence and must be allowed to exercise his statutory right to appeal to satisfy the demands of substantial justice and due process.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the petition is GRANTED. The Resolution dated January 18, 2019 and the Resolution dated August 20, 2020 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CR HC No. 05710 are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. The Entry of Judgment in Criminal Case No. 09-1288 issued by the Court of Appeals is RECALLED. The Court of Appeals is DIRECTED to give due course to Rodrigo Conche y Obilos appeal and is ORDERED to elevate the records of the case for this purpose. Let a copy of this Decision be furnished to the Commission on Bar Discipline of the Integrated Bar of the Philippines, which is hereby DIRECTED to investigate Atty. Evelyn Gutierrez for her administrative liability as a member of the Bar. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under Article 334 of the Revised Penal Code concubinage may be committed by a husband cohabiting with a woman who is not his wife in any other place which constitutes the third mode of commission distinct from keeping a mistress in the conjugal dwelling. Consequently an Information charging the accused with cohabiting in a private dwelling sufficiently alleges the elements of this third mode because the term private dwelling necessarily includes any place other than the conjugal abode where the illicit couple dwells together as husband and wife.
digest.facts: Petitioner Ariel and his mistress petitioner Genivieve were charged with concubinage for willfully cohabiting and having a child together despite Ariels subsisting marriage to the private complainant Consanita. The prosecution presented evidence including testimonies of neighbors showing that Ariel introduced Genivieve as his new wife and that they lived together in various places while Genivieve herself admitted in open court that they dwelt together in Mindanao and Negros during her pregnancy. The Municipal Trial Court in Cities convicted the petitioners of concubinage a decision affirmed by the Regional Trial Court and the Court of Appeals which rejected the defense argument that the Information was defective for using the term private dwelling instead of conjugal dwelling.
digest.issue: Whether the Court of Appeals erred in affirming the conviction of the petitioners for the crime of concubinage.
digest.ruling: NO, the Court of Appeals did not err. Under Article 334 of the Revised Penal Code and established jurisprudence concubinage is committed when a husband cohabits with a woman who is not his wife in any other place which entails dwelling together as husband and wife for a period of time. Here the Information effectively charged this offense by alleging cohabitation in a private dwelling which falls under the third mode of committing the crime and the prosecution successfully proved beyond reasonable doubt that the petitioners lived together in Mindanao and Negros. Hence the conviction is proper as the specific term used in the Information is immaterial provided the elements of the crime are sufficiently alleged and proven.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the petition is DENIED for lack of merit. The Decision dated May 18, 2021 and the Resolution dated June 21, 2022 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 13876 are hereby AFFIRMED with MODIFICATION. Petitioners Ariel Cadayday Singgit and Genivieve Mayondo But-ay are both found GUILTY beyond reasonable doubt of the crime of concubinage. Petitioner Ariel Cadayday Singgit is sentenced to suffer the penalty of arresto mayor or imprisonment for two (2) months and one (1) day, as minimum, to six (6) months, as maximum. On the other hand, petitioner Genivieve But-ay shall suffer the penalty of destierro. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under Section 7 Rule 3 of the Rules of Court an indispensable party is one whose interest in the subject matter is so inextricably intertwined with the other parties that their legal presence is an absolute necessity such that their absence renders all subsequent actuations of the court null and void. Consequently the administrator of an unliquidated conjugal partnership or estate where no probate or intestate proceedings have been commenced is not an indispensable party but merely a necessary party to a suit for specific performance regarding a property sold by the heirs as the administrators interest is separable from the contractual obligations of the heirs.
digest.facts: Petitioners entered into a Contract to Sell with respondent Kinsonic over a parcel of land receiving partial payments but later refused the balance alleging the contract was cancelled due to late payment. Respondent filed a complaint for specific performance which led to a summary judgment in its favor ordered by the Court of Appeals in a previous petition. Upon remand the Regional Trial Court rendered judgment ordering petitioners to pay damages which petitioners appealed arguing for the first time that the proceedings were void for failure to join the administrator of the estate as an indispensable party. The Court of Appeals affirmed the trial courts decision ruling that the administrator was not an indispensable party and that petitioners were barred by estoppel from raising new issues on appeal.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the administrator of the estates or conjugal partnership is an indispensable party to the proceedings.

2. Whether the petitioners are barred by estoppel from raising the issue of non-joinder of the administrator.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the administrator is not an indispensable party. Under Section 7 Rule 3 of the Rules of Court and established jurisprudence an indispensable party must be joined under all conditions while a necessary party should be joined whenever possible but their non-inclusion does not prevent the court from proceeding. Here there were no letters of administration issued nor any intestate proceedings commenced meaning the administrator was a non-existent officer whose interest was at best that of a necessary party separable from the interest of the heirs who signed the contract. Hence the trial court retained jurisdiction and the proceedings were valid despite the non-joinder of the administrator.

2. YES, the petitioners are barred by estoppel. Under the principle of estoppel and the rule on changing theories on appeal points of law and arguments not brought to the attention of the trial court cannot be raised for the first time on appeal as it violates basic considerations of due process. Here the petitioners submitted to the jurisdiction of the trial court and profited from the payments made by the respondent without raising the lack of an administrator in their Answer or during the trial. Hence they are barred from raising this new issue to evade their contractual obligations after an adverse judgment.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the instant Petition is DENIED, and both the Decision dated November 13, 2013 and Resolution dated August 29, 2014 of the Court of Appeals Fifth Division in CA-G.R. CV No. 93799 are hereby AFFIRMED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Article 1897 of the Civil Code provides that an agent who acts as such is not personally liable to the party with whom he contracts unless he expressly binds himself or exceeds the limits of his authority without giving such party sufficient notice of his powers. Consequently a bank acting as an insurance agent that offers an insurance policy to borrowers for a loan type not covered by such policy and deducts premiums while knowing the application will be denied exceeds its authority and is liable for moral damages for the resulting injury to the borrowers.
digest.facts: Respondent Miranda and her co-borrowers obtained a loan from petitioner Land Bank which offered them Mortgage Redemption Insurance and deducted the premium from the loan proceeds leading them to believe they were insured. Upon the death of a co-borrower Miranda stopped paying assuming the insurance covered the balance but Land Bank foreclosed the mortgage arguing no insurance was perfected as no application was filed and the policy did not cover business loans. The Regional Trial Court ruled that while no insurance contract was perfected Land Bank was liable for damages for acting beyond its authority as an agent. The Court of Appeals affirmed the decision in toto finding that Land Banks misrepresentations caused mental anguish to the respondent.
digest.issue:
1. Whether a Mortgage Redemption Insurance contract was perfected between the parties.

2. Whether Land Bank is liable for moral damages for acting beyond the scope of its authority.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, there was no perfected Mortgage Redemption Insurance contract. Under the Insurance Code and established jurisprudence a contract of insurance requires the consent of the parties which is not given until the insurer issues a corresponding policy to the applicant. Here Miranda failed to submit the application form and the insurer never accepted the premium or issued a policy because the loan was for a business undertaking not covered by the insurance. Hence the loan obligation was not extinguished upon the death of the co-borrower and the foreclosure was valid.

2. YES, Land Bank is liable for moral damages. Under Article 1897 of the Civil Code an agent who exceeds the limits of his authority without giving sufficient notice of his powers is personally liable for damages especially when coupled with violations of Articles 19 and 21 on human relations. Here Land Bank acted as an agent for the insurer and offered a policy knowing it did not cover the borrowers loan type yet deducted premiums and misled them into believing they were insured. Hence Land Bank is liable for the mental anguish suffered by the respondent due to its wrongful acts and misrepresentations.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the foregoing premises considered, the Decision dated February 24, 2015 and the Resolution dated September 28, 2015 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV No. 97099 are hereby AFFIRMED with MODIFICATION in that the monetary awards due to Maria Josefina G. Miranda shall earn legal interest at the rate of six percent (6%) per annum from the date of finality of this Decision until fully paid by Land Bank of the Philippines.

digest.doctrine: Parties are free to stipulate interest rates and terms provided they are not contrary to law, morals, good customs, public order, or public policy, and courts will only intervene to reduce such rates if they are found to be iniquitous or unconscionable based on the specific circumstances and the relative bargaining power of the parties. Consequently, stipulated interest rates of five to eight percent per month and substantial penalty charges are valid and binding when freely agreed upon by experienced businesspersons standing on equal footing, where the borrower was not in dire need or under undue pressure but entered the short-term transaction as a calculated business risk.
digest.facts: Respondent Sabnani, a British businessman, obtained a short-term loan of PHP 7,450,000.00 from petitioner Pabalan, secured by a real estate mortgage and promissory notes stipulating interest rates of five to eight percent per month plus penalties. After Sabnani defaulted, Pabalan foreclosed on the property, prompting Sabnani to file a complaint for annulment claiming the rates were unconscionable and that he received no benefit as he merely accommodated a business partner. The Regional Trial Court dismissed the complaint and upheld the validity of the foreclosure and the stipulated rates. However, the Court of Appeals affirmed the validity of the loan but reduced the interest and penalty rates to one percent per month and ordered Pabalan to return the excess bid price.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the Court of Appeals erred in reducing the stipulated rates of interest, penalty charges, liquidated damages, and attorneys fees.

2. Whether the petitioner is liable to return the alleged surplus from the foreclosure bid price.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the Court of Appeals erred. Under the principle of autonomy of contracts and established jurisprudence, parties may stipulate interest rates provided they are not iniquitous or unconscionable, which is determined by examining if the parties stood on equal footing or if one was disadvantaged. Here, the respondent was an experienced businessman who voluntarily agreed to the high rates as a calculated risk to accommodate a partner, was not in financial distress, and even secured counter-checks to cover his liability, proving he understood and accepted the terms. Hence, the stipulated rates are valid and binding, and the Court must not intervene in the parties freedom to contract.

2. NO, the petitioner is not liable to return any surplus. Under the principles of foreclosure proceedings, a surplus arises only when the bid price exceeds the total outstanding obligation computed based on the valid terms of the mortgage contract. Here, because the stipulated interest rates and penalties were found to be valid and binding given the equal footing of the parties, the petitioners winning bid correctly corresponded to the actual debt due. Hence, there is no excess amount to be returned to the respondent as the computation of the debt was legally correct.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the instant Petition for Review on Certiorari is GRANTED. The Decision dated November 28, 2012 and the Resolution dated February 12, 2014 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV No. 91169 are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. The ruling of the Court of Appeals decreasing the interest and penalty rates, and other damages stipulated between the parties, and ordering petitioner Estrella Pabalan to return to respondent Vasudave Sabnani the excess of the bid price, with legal interest, and costs of the sale, are DELETED. The Decision dated March 28, 2005 of the Regional Trial Court of Makati City, Branch 59, in Civil Case No. 99-1361, is REINSTATED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: An escalation clause that grants a creditor an unbridled right to adjust interest rates independently and upwardly completely depriving the debtor of the right to assent to an important modification violates the principle of mutuality of contracts and is void. Consequently a lease provision authorizing the lessor to unilaterally determine and impose common area dues escalation rates based on its own assessment of inflation without the lessees consent is potestative and void requiring the restitution of amounts collected under the invalid stipulation.
digest.facts: Respondent Victor Cua entered into lease contracts with petitioner Gotesco Properties for commercial units agreeing to pay common area and aircon dues subject to an annual escalation clause of eighteen percent or a rate determined by the lessor if insufficient to meet inflation. From 1997 to 2003 Gotesco unilaterally imposed varying escalation costs amounting to over two million pesos citing the Asian currency crisis and rising utility costs which prompted Cua to file a complaint for injunctive relief and restitution arguing the imposition lacked factual basis and violated mutuality of contracts. The Regional Trial Court ruled in favor of Cua invalidating the escalation costs and ordering the return of collected amounts plus attorneys fees. The Court of Appeals partly granted the appeal by upholding the fixed eighteen percent rate while invalidating the discretionary rate portion and deleting the award of attorneys fees.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the escalation clause on common area and aircon dues is valid.

2. Whether the respondent is entitled to attorneys fees.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the escalation clause is invalid. Under Article 1308 of the Civil Code and established jurisprudence an escalation clause that grants one party the unbridled right to adjust rates independently violates the principle of mutuality of contracts and is void. Here the subject clause was wholly potestative as it allowed Gotesco to unilaterally impose any rate it desired based on its own determination of inflation without the lessees consent or proven factual basis effectively leaving the modification of the contract to the sole will of the lessor. Hence the entire escalation clause is void and Gotesco must return the collected escalation costs to the respondent.

2. YES, the respondent is entitled to attorneys fees. Under Article 2208 of the Civil Code attorneys fees may be awarded when the defendants act or omission has compelled the plaintiff to litigate or incur expenses to protect his interest. Here Gotescos unjustified insistence on enforcing a void escalation clause and the protracted litigation lasting over nine years forced the respondent to hire counsel to protect his rights against baseless collections. Hence the Court reinstated the award of attorneys fees but reduced the amount to what is just and reasonable under the circumstances.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, premises considered, the petition in G.R. No. 228552 entitled Victor C. Cua v. Gotesco Properties, Inc. is GRANTED, while the petition in G.R. No. 228513 entitled Gotesco Properties, Inc. v. Victor C. Cua is DENIED for lack of merit. Accordingly, the March 29, 2016 Decision and the November 29, 2016 Resolution of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV No. 100311 are AFFIRMED with the following MODIFICATIONS: (i) The Common Area and Aircon Dues (CAAD) Escalation Clause is hereby invalidated. Gotesco Properties, Inc. is ORDERED to return to Victor C. Cua the amount of P2,269,735.64; (ii) The case is REMANDED to the Regional Trial Court Branch 41 for the proper computation of the CAAD pursuant to the first paragraph of Clause 17 of the Contracts of Lease; and (iii) Victor C. Cua is awarded attorneys fees equivalent to P100,000.00. The amount returned by Gotesco Properties, Inc. and the attorneys fees shall be subject to an interest rate of six percent (6%) per annum reckoned from the finality of this Courts Decision until full satisfaction. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under Section 3 Rule 13 of the Rules of Court the date of mailing of motions pleadings and other court submissions as shown by the post office stamp on the envelope or the registry receipt shall be considered as the date of their filing in court. Consequently a petition for review filed via registered mail on the last day of the reglementary period is deemed timely filed and the appellate courts failure to verify the registry receipts constitutes grave abuse of discretion warranting the reversal of the order of dismissal.
digest.facts: Petitioner Caballes filed a complaint against private respondents regarding agrarian reform coverage winning before the RARAD but losing on appeal to the DARAB. After the DARAB denied his motion for reconsideration petitioner filed a petition for review with the Court of Appeals via registered mail on the last day of the reglementary period February 26 2021. However the Court of Appeals outrightly dismissed the petition for allegedly being filed three days late and for various procedural defects such as failure to attach certified true copies of the decision lack of material dates and failure to attach competent evidence of identity. Despite petitioners motion for reconsideration submitting the registry receipts to prove timely filing and an amended petition correcting the technical defects the Court of Appeals denied the motion insisting the petition was filed out of time.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the Court of Appeals committed grave abuse of discretion in ruling that the petition for review was belatedly filed.

2. Whether the procedural defects cited by the Court of Appeals justified the outright dismissal of the petition.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the Court of Appeals committed grave abuse of discretion. Under Section 3 Rule 13 of the Rules of Court the date of mailing of pleadings as shown by the post office stamp or registry receipt is considered the date of filing. Here the registry receipts clearly showed that the petitioner mailed the petition on February 26 2021 which was the last day of the fifteen-day reglementary period making the filing timely. Hence the appellate courts failure to acknowledge the date of mailing despite the evidence presented constitutes a whimsical and arbitrary exercise of power.

2. NO, the procedural defects did not justify outright dismissal. Under established jurisprudence and the principle of substantial justice rigid application of technical rules should be relaxed when the petitioner has substantially complied and rectified minor defects such as the failure to attach certified true copies or updated IBP receipts in a subsequent motion for reconsideration. Here the petitioner immediately corrected the alleged errors in his motion for reconsideration and amended petition including the submission of material dates and valid identification which were not even strictly required to be attached under the rules. Hence the dismissal on mere technicalities was unwarranted as it defeated the ends of substantial justice.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the petition is GRANTED. The Minute Resolution dated March 25, 2021 and the Resolution dated June 24, 2022 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 10226-MIN are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. The case is REMANDED to the Court of Appeals for the resolution of petitioner Jesus Caballes petition for review. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Forum shopping exists when a party files multiple suits involving the same parties for the same cause of action to obtain a favorable judgment where the elements of litis pendentia are present or where a final judgment in one case would amount to res judicata in the other requiring a willful and deliberate intent to manipulate court processes. Consequently the filing of identical complaints in different venues due to genuine uncertainty regarding the corporate principal place of business followed by the immediate withdrawal of the other cases upon clarification negates forum shopping as there is no intent to secure a favorable ruling through multiple fora or cause conflicting decisions.
digest.facts: Respondents filed three separate complaints in Pasig Manila and Makati against petitioners to nullify a stockholders meeting due to conflicting corporate records regarding Pacifica Inc.s principal place of business while simultaneously seeking clarification from the SEC. Upon receiving the SECs confirmation that the principal place of business was in Makati respondents immediately withdrew the Pasig and Manila cases before any responsive pleadings were filed leaving only the Makati case to proceed where the Regional Trial Court eventually rendered a default judgment. The Court of Appeals reversed the trial courts order due to improper service of summons but ruled that respondents did not commit forum shopping finding their actions justified by the confusion over the venue and lacking willful intent to vex the courts.
digest.issue: Whether the respondents are guilty of forum shopping.
digest.ruling: NO, the respondents are not guilty of forum shopping. Under established jurisprudence forum shopping exists only when there is a willful and deliberate intent to file multiple suits to increase the chances of a favorable judgment creating the danger of conflicting decisions which arises when the elements of litis pendentia or res judicata are present. Here the respondents filed multiple cases solely due to uncertainty regarding the proper venue and immediately withdrew the Pasig and Manila cases upon clarification from the SEC before any responsive pleadings were filed ensuring that only the Makati case remained and eliminating any possibility of conflicting decisions. Hence the Court ruled that there was no forum shopping as the actions were not malicious but were taken to preserve remedies amidst ambiguity.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the Petition for Review on Certiorari dated August 2, 2010 is DENIED. The Decision dated January 27, 2010 and the Resolution dated July 6, 2010 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 109312 are AFFIRMED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: A levy on execution merely creates a lien in favor of the judgment obligee and does not divest the judgment debtor of ownership until a subsequent sale on execution and the expiration of the redemption period. Consequently a public official who fails to declare levied properties in their Statement of Assets Liabilities and Net Worth due to a mistaken belief that the levy divested them of ownership does not possess the malicious or deliberate intent required to sustain a criminal charge for unexplained wealth or perjury.
digest.facts: Petitioner filed criminal and administrative complaints against respondent Mayor and his wife for alleged unexplained wealth and failure to file true 2010 to 2013 SALNs claiming they failed to declare various real properties vehicles and business interests. The respondents argued that certain properties were already levied upon by a bank or sold to third parties business interests were divested and other assets belonged to emancipated relatives. The Ombudsman dismissed the complaints finding that the levied properties were in custodia legis other properties were validly transferred or waived and there was no evidence of ownership regarding the vehicles a ruling petitioner challenged via certiorari before the Supreme Court.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the petition for certiorari before the Supreme Court is the proper remedy to assail the dismissal of the administrative charges.

2. Whether the Ombudsman committed grave abuse of discretion in dismissing the criminal complaint for lack of probable cause.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the petition is not the proper remedy for the administrative aspect. Under established jurisprudence and the Ombudsman Rules the dismissal of administrative charges is final and unappealable but if tainted with grave abuse of discretion the correct procedure is to file a petition for certiorari before the Court of Appeals not the Supreme Court. Here the petitioner filed a Rule 65 petition directly with the Supreme Court to question the Joint Resolution dismissing both criminal and administrative cases which is a procedural error regarding the administrative portion. Hence the dismissal of the administrative charges had already attained finality and cannot be reviewed by the Court.

2. NO, the Ombudsman did not commit grave abuse of discretion. Under the Anti-Graft and Corrupt Practices Act and the Code of Conduct and Ethical Standards while a levy on execution does not transfer ownership and such properties should still be declared criminal liability requires a malicious or deliberate intent to conceal the truth. Here the respondent Mayor failed to declare levied properties based on a mistaken but plausible belief that he had lost beneficial ownership due to the bank levy and he successfully proved the divestment or non-ownership of the other assets through deeds of sale waivers and lack of registration evidence. Hence the omission was not done with malicious intent to conceal unexplained wealth justifying the dismissal of the criminal complaint.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, premises considered, the Petition for Certiorari dated October 27, 2017 is hereby DENIED for lack of merit. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: The factors listed under Section 17 of RA 6657 and the resulting DAR formulas provide a mandatory uniform framework for computing just compensation which courts must consider unless a reasoned deviation is supported by evidence. Consequently the appellate courts affirmation of a valuation that disregarded the mandatory formula without sufficient justification is invalid necessitating a remand to the trial court to determine the presence of factors like comparable sales or to justify the use of alternate formulas.
digest.facts: Respondents voluntarily offered two parcels of land in Iloilo for agrarian reform coverage which petitioner Land Bank valued using an alternate formula excluding comparable sales while respondents sought a higher valuation based on their offer price. The Regional Trial Court fixed the just compensation by considering various factors but without strictly following the DAR formula and awarded interest which petitioner appealed. The Court of Appeals affirmed the decision with modification increasing the valuation based on the premise that the DAR formula is not mandatory and deleting the interest award.
digest.issue: Whether the Court of Appeals erred in affirming the Regional Trial Courts valuation which deviated from the mandatory DAR formula.
digest.ruling: YES, the Court of Appeals erred. Under Section 17 of RA 6657 and established jurisprudence courts must apply the DAR formulas in determining just compensation unless a deviation is supported by a reasoned explanation grounded on evidence. Here the lower courts failed to justify the deviation from the standard formula while the petitioner failed to prove why the comparable sales factor was inapplicable to warrant the use of an alternate formula. Hence the case was remanded to the trial court for the reception of further evidence to determine the proper just compensation in accordance with the mandatory guidelines.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the Decision dated March 15, 2013 and the Resolution dated June 17, 2014 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 03197 are hereby REVERSED and SET ASIDE. Civil Case No. 02-27157 is REMANDED to the Regional Trial Court of Iloilo City, Branch 34, for reception of evidence on the issue of just compensation in accordance with this ruling. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: The classification of public lands is an exclusive prerogative of the Executive Department and courts must accord great respect to the factual findings of administrative agencies regarding the legal character of land. Consequently where the Department of Environment and Natural Resources has classified a disputed property as forest land through the issuance of a Forest Land Use Agreement for Tourism a civil action for recovery of possession based on an alleged preferential right over foreshore land fails to state a cause of action and must be dismissed.
digest.facts: Respondent ATOM filed a complaint for recovery of possession and injunction against petitioner Aquino regarding a seaside lot in Boracay claiming it was foreshore land over which ATOM had a preferential right as the adjacent owner and a foreshore lease applicant. Aquino opposed arguing the property was forest land situated on a cliff without a shoreline and presented a Forest Land Use Agreement for Tourism issued by the DENR in his favor. The Regional Trial Court issued a writ of preliminary injunction to stop Aquinos construction citing environmental concerns and upheld its jurisdiction over the possessory action. The Court of Appeals affirmed the issuance of the writ treating it as a Temporary Environmental Protection Order exempt from a bond and ruled that the DENR jurisdiction did not preclude the court from resolving the issue of possession.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the issuance of the writ of preliminary injunction was proper.

2. Whether the civil case for recovery of possession should be dismissed.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the issuance of the writ was improper. Under the Rules of Court and established jurisprudence a preliminary injunction requires the applicant to establish a clear and unmistakable legal right to be protected. Here ATOM failed to prove a clear legal right because its claim was premised on the lot being foreshore land which was contradicted by the DENR classification of the area as forest land covered by a tenure instrument in favor of Aquino. Hence the injunction was dissolved as ATOM lacked the requisite clear legal right to possession.

2. YES, the civil case should be dismissed. Under the doctrine of primary jurisdiction and the Public Land Act the classification of public lands belongs to the Executive Department and courts must defer to the technical expertise of the DENR which has ruled out the possibility of the lot being foreshore land. Here the DENR explicitly found the property to be forest land situated on a cliff with no beachfront effectively negating the factual basis of ATOMs claim for a preferential right over foreshore land. Hence the complaint was dismissed for lack of cause of action as the administrative findings foreclosed ATOMs legal claim.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the present petition is GRANTED. Civil Case No. 8577 before the Regional Trial Court of Kalibo, Aklan, Branch 5, is hereby DISMISSED, and the August 31, 2010 writ of preliminary injunction issued therein is DISSOLVED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine:
Under Section 3 Rule 13 of the Rules of Court the date of mailing of motions pleadings or other papers as shown by the post office stamp on the envelope or the registry receipt shall be considered as the date of their filing in court. Consequently a petition for certiorari filed via registered mail on the next working day following a deadline that falls on a weekend is deemed timely filed regardless of when the court actually receives the mailed pleading.

Section 4(a) of RA 9208 as amended punishes the act of hiring or receiving a person for the purpose of prostitution or sexual exploitation distinct from the act of recruiting and does not require conspiracy with the recruiter to establish liability especially when the victim is a minor. Consequently a trial court judge commits grave abuse of discretion amounting to lack of jurisdiction by dismissing a case for lack of probable cause against a bar owner who hired and received a minor for prostitution on the ground of lack of conspiracy with the recruiters as the evidence sufficiently establishes the elements of Qualified Trafficking.
digest.facts: A minor named Jelyn filed a complaint for Qualified Trafficking against respondent Marivic Lobiano owner of Sampaguita Bar alleging she was recruited by a friend to work there as a guest relations officer involving prostitution and debt bondage. The Office of the Provincial Prosecutor found probable cause to indict Marivic for Qualified Trafficking for receiving and hiring a minor for prostitution but the Regional Trial Court dismissed the case for lack of probable cause citing a lack of proof of conspiracy between Marivic and the recruiters. The Provincial Prosecutor filed a Petition for Certiorari via registered mail on the next working day after the deadline fell on a Saturday but the Court of Appeals dismissed it for being filed out of time based on the date of receipt and for being the wrong remedy.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the Court of Appeals erred in dismissing the Petition for Certiorari for being filed out of time.

2. Whether the Regional Trial Court committed grave abuse of discretion in dismissing the case for lack of probable cause.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the Court of Appeals erred. Under Section 3 Rule 13 of the Rules of Court and established jurisprudence the date of mailing as shown by the post office stamp or registry receipt is considered the date of filing when a pleading is filed by registered mail. Here the petitioner proved via certification from the post office that the petition was mailed on the next working day following the Saturday deadline making the filing timely despite the appellate court receiving it days later. Hence the dismissal based on untimeliness was incorrect.

2. YES, the Regional Trial Court committed grave abuse of discretion. Under Section 4(a) of RA 9208 as amended the act of hiring or receiving a person for prostitution is a distinct criminal act that does not require conspiracy with the recruiter especially when the victim is a minor under Section 6(a). Here the evidence showed Marivic hired and received the minor Jelyn for sexual exploitation which sufficiently established probable cause for Qualified Trafficking regardless of her connection to the recruiters. Hence the trial courts dismissal of the case was a patent nullity and the criminal information must be reinstated.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the Petition for Review on Certiorari dated May 16, 2016 is GRANTED. The July 10, 2015 and April 15, 2016 Resolutions of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 139320, as well as the Order dated November 13, 2014 issued by the Regional Trial Court of Legazpi City, Branch 9, dismissing Criminal Case No. FC-14-1646 are SET ASIDE. The Criminal Information for Qualified Trafficking filed against Marivic Lobiano is hereby REINSTATED. Accordingly, the trial court is directed to proceed with the arraignment of the accused and the trial of the case with dispatch. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Administrative liability is separate and distinct from criminal liability and proceedings before the Commission on Audit such that acquittal in a criminal case or lack of finality in audit proceedings does not absolve a public officer from administrative sanctions. Consequently public officials found by substantial evidence to have flagrantly disregarded procurement laws by foregoing public bidding are guilty of grave misconduct and subject to dismissal from service regardless of their acquittal in the Sandiganbayan or the status of audit notices.
digest.facts: Petitioners Suyat Aban and Endi were municipal officials of Buguias Benguet who were charged administratively for procuring farm inputs worth over one million pesos through personal canvass instead of public bidding allegedly due to the suspension of the Bids and Awards Committee. The Office of the Ombudsman found them guilty of grave misconduct for violating Republic Act No 9184 and ordered their dismissal which prompted them to appeal to the Court of Appeals arguing denial of due process in the Commission on Audit proceedings. The Court of Appeals affirmed the Ombudsmans decision ruling that the lack of public bidding was inexcusable and that petitioners failure to follow the law constituted grave misconduct.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the petitioners availed of the correct mode of review to assail the decision of the Court of Appeals.

2. Whether the petitioners are administratively liable despite their acquittal in the criminal case.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the petitioners did not avail of the correct mode of review. Under Section 1 of Rule 45 of the Rules of Court judgments of the Court of Appeals are appealable via a petition for review on certiorari within fifteen days whereas a Rule 65 petition is only available when there is no appeal or plain remedy. Here petitioners filed a Rule 65 petition after the period to file a Rule 45 appeal had lapsed effectively trying to substitute a lost appeal with a certiorari petition which renders the appellate decision final and executory.

2. YES, the petitioners are administratively liable. Under the substantial evidence rule administrative proceedings are independent from criminal cases meaning acquittal in a criminal case does not preclude administrative liability if substantial evidence exists. Here the records showed substantial evidence that petitioners flagrantly disregarded Republic Act No 9184 by using personal canvass without valid justification committing grave misconduct regardless of the criminal acquittal. Hence the finding of administrative liability and the penalty of dismissal are affirmed.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the instant Joint Petition for Certiorari is hereby DISMISSED. The Decision dated August 15, 2019 and the Resolution dated December 19, 2019 of the Court of Appeals Special 16th Division in CA-G.R. SP Nos. 150503-05 are hereby AFFIRMED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Article 45 of the Revised Penal Code applies suppletorily to Section 68 of Presidential Decree No 705 regarding judicial confiscation such that instruments or tools of a crime may not be forfeited if they belong to a third person not liable for the offense. Consequently a trial court violates due process when it orders the forfeiture of a vehicle used to transport illegal forest products without affording the third-party owner an opportunity to prove ownership and lack of knowledge or participation in the crime requiring a remand for the reception of evidence.
digest.facts: Two accused pleaded guilty to violating Section 77 of Presidential Decree No 705 for transporting illegal lumber using a truck owned by respondent Eastern Island Shipping Lines which the trial court ordered confiscated despite the prosecutors initial agreement to allow the owner to prove lack of knowledge. Respondent filed an omnibus motion to reopen the trial claiming lack of knowledge and participation but the Regional Trial Court denied it ruling that the special law prevails over the Revised Penal Code and mandates confiscation regardless of ownership. The Court of Appeals nullified the trial courts order and directed the release of the truck holding that Article 45 of the Revised Penal Code protects third-party owners and that the respondents due process rights were violated.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the judicial confiscation of the conveyance under Section 68 of Presidential Decree No 705 is subject to the limitations of Article 45 of the Revised Penal Code regarding third-party ownership.

2. Whether the Court of Appeals erred in ordering the outright release of the vehicle to the respondent.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, Article 45 applies suppletorily. Under Article 10 of the Revised Penal Code and established jurisprudence the Code applies suppletorily to special laws like Presidential Decree No 705 when the latter is silent on a particular matter such as the judicial confiscation of conveyances owned by third parties. Here the trial court erred in ruling that the special law absolutely overrides the protection for third-party owners effectively depriving the respondent of its property without due process. Hence the case must be remanded to allow the third-party claimant to prove ownership and lack of participation in the offense.

2. YES, the Court of Appeals erred in ordering outright release. Under the requirements of due process factual matters such as ownership and lack of knowledge in the commission of a crime must be established through the formal presentation of evidence which the adverse party has the right to examine and refute. Here the appellate court relied solely on documents attached to a motion which were not formally offered or proven in the trial court thereby denying the petitioners their right to due process. Hence the proper remedy is to remand the case to the trial court for the reception of evidence regarding the third-party claim.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, premises considered, the Decision dated February 19, 2020 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 157075 is AFFIRMED with MODIFICATION in that the confiscation aspect of Criminal Case No. 6531, relative to the Isuzu dump truck with plate no. ACO 1836, is REMANDED to the Regional Trial Court, Branch 42 (Virac, Catanduanes) for further proceedings. Said trial court is enjoined to resolve the third-party claim of Eastern Island Shipping Lines Corporation with dispatch. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine:
A certificate of live birth purportedly identifying the putative father is not competent evidence of paternity when there is no showing that the putative father had a hand in the preparation of said certificate such as by signing it or supplying the information therein. Consequently a reconstructed birth certificate that lacks the signature or intervention of the alleged father is null and void as proof of voluntary acknowledgment and cannot be used to establish illegitimate filiation.

The right to claim illegitimate filiation is strictly personal to the child and may only be transferred to the heirs if the child dies during minority or in a state of insanity. Consequently the heirs of an alleged illegitimate child who died as an adult have no standing to institute an action to establish filiation and claim inheritance from the putative father.
digest.facts: Respondents filed a complaint for the nullification of an extrajudicial settlement executed by the heirs of Constancio regarding the estate of Ireneo Vizcarra claiming rights as heirs of Silvestre whom they alleged was Ireneos illegitimate son. To prove filiation respondents presented an NSO Certificate of Birth reconstructed from a 1978 Certification and a marriage contract both indicating Ireneo as Silvestres father but petitioners challenged these arguing the certificate was suspect and lacked Ireneos intervention. The Regional Trial Court ruled in favor of respondents declaring the settlement void and ordering reconveyance of the property. The Court of Appeals affirmed the decision ruling that the NSO Certificate was a valid reconstruction and sufficient proof of filiation.
digest.issue: Whether the respondents established the filiation of Silvestre to Ireneo so as to entitle them to a share in the estate.
digest.ruling: NO, the respondents failed to establish filiation. Under Article 172 of the Family Code and established jurisprudence a birth certificate is not competent evidence of paternity if the putative father did not intervene in its preparation or sign it and under Article 173 the right to claim filiation is not transmissible unless the child died during minority or insanity. Here the NSO Certificate was a reconstruction lacking Ireneos signature or intervention and Silvestre died as an adult meaning the right to claim filiation was not transferred to the respondents. Hence the respondents lacked standing and the evidence presented was insufficient to prove filiation warranting the dismissal of the complaint.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the Petition for Review on Certiorari dated March 4, 2013 is GRANTED. The assailed Decision dated October 4, 2012 and the Resolution dated January 14, 2013 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV. No. 97945 are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. The Decision dated September 22, 2011 of the Regional Trial Court of ParaÃ±aque City, Branch 274 in Civil Case No. 07-0313 is VACATED. A new one is entered DISMISSING the Complaint dated September 1, 2007. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Section 2 Article XII of the Constitution restricts the exploration development and utilization of natural resources to the State directly or through agreements with Filipino citizens or corporations with at least sixty percent Filipino capital or via agreements entered into by the President with foreign-owned corporations involving technical or financial assistance. Consequently a tripartite agreement involving foreign corporations for joint marine seismic undertakings that allows the sharing of valuable data and information regarding natural resources without the Presidents participation or strict adherence to constitutional safeguards constitutes an illegal surrender of the States full control and supervision and is therefore void.
digest.facts: Petitioners legislators and taxpayers challenged the constitutionality of the Joint Marine Seismic Undertaking or JMSU executed by the Philippine National Oil Company with China National Offshore Oil Corporation and Vietnam Oil and Gas Corporation covering an area in the South China Sea. The agreement aimed to conduct seismic surveys to determine the petroleum resource potential of the area which respondents claimed was merely pre-exploration and thus not subject to strict constitutional restrictions while also arguing mootness due to the agreements expiration in 2008. The Supreme Court previously declared the JMSU unconstitutional for violating Section 2 Article XII of the Constitution prompting respondents to file a Motion for Reconsideration asserting that the Court encroached on executive prerogatives and that the activity did not constitute exploration.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the Court correctly took cognizance of the petition despite the expiration of the agreement.

2. Whether the JMSU is unconstitutional for violating Section 2 Article XII of the Constitution.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the Court correctly took cognizance of the petition. Under established jurisprudence the Court may decide moot cases when there is a grave violation of the Constitution paramount public interest is involved and the issue is capable of repetition yet evading review. Here the Court ruled that the JMSU involved the exploration of the countrys natural resources which is of exceptional character and paramount interest requiring the formulation of controlling principles to guide future government agreements hence the expiration of the contract did not preclude judicial review.

2. YES, the JMSU is unconstitutional. Under Section 2 Article XII of the Constitution the exploration of natural resources must be under the full control and supervision of the State and may only be undertaken directly or through specific modes including agreements with foreign corporations only for technical or financial assistance signed by the President. Here the JMSU constituted exploration as it involved the search for petroleum resources but was not executed by the President and impermissibly allowed wholly-owned foreign corporations to participate in exploration and share in the ownership of the resulting data effectively bargaining away the States full control over the information.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the motion is DENIED with FINALITY. The Decision dated January 10, 2023 declaring the Tripartite Agreement for Joint Marine Seismic Undertaking in the Agreement Area in the South China Sea By and Among China National Offshore Oil Corporation and Vietnam Oil and Gas Corporation and Philippine National Oil Company unconstitutional and void is AFFIRMED.

digest.doctrine: Under Article 35(3) in relation to Article 34 of the Family Code the absence of a valid marriage license renders a marriage void ab initio unless the parties have lived together as husband and wife for at least five years and have no legal impediment to marry which requires exclusivity and continuity of cohabitation.
