Consequently a marriage solemnized without a license where the parties had only been in a relationship for one month prior to the ceremony fails to meet the five-year cohabitation requirement and is therefore void from the beginning due to the absence of a formal requisite.
digest.facts: Petitioner Sue Ann and respondent Joseph entered into a marriage in 1996 without a marriage license claiming exemption under Article 34 of the Family Code despite having only become a couple a month prior. Sue Ann later filed a petition for declaration of nullity of marriage asserting Josephs psychological incapacity due to his drug addiction gambling and irresponsibility and also raised the lack of a valid marriage license. The Regional Trial Court granted the petition based on psychological incapacity but the Court of Appeals reversed the decision finding the evidence insufficient to prove incapacity while ignoring the issue regarding the absence of a marriage license.
digest.issue:
1. Whether Sue Ann established the psychological incapacity of Joseph.

2. Whether the marriage is void ab initio for lack of a valid marriage license.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, Sue Ann failed to establish psychological incapacity. Under the guidelines set in Tan-Andal v Andal psychological incapacity must be characterized by gravity juridical antecedence and incurability in the legal sense requiring proof that the personality disorder renders the party truly incognitive of the basic marital covenants. Here the evidence merely showed Joseph was a gambler drunkard and womanizer without independent proof that these were manifestations of a disorder rooted in his history or that he was incapable of assuming marital obligations. Hence the claim for nullity based on Article 36 was correctly rejected as the allegations constituted refusal rather than incapacity.

2. YES, the marriage is void ab initio. Under Article 35(3) and Article 4 of the Family Code a marriage solemnized without a license is void from the beginning unless it falls under the exception in Article 34 which requires a five-year cohabitation period. Here the record undisputedly showed the parties only became a couple one month before the wedding making it impossible to satisfy the five-year cohabitation requirement to be exempt from the license requirement. Hence the marriage is declared void for lack of the essential requisite of a marriage license.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, in view of the foregoing, the Petition for Review on Certiorari is GRANTED. Consequently, the Decision dated October 30, 2013 and the Resolution dated September 19, 2014, of the Court of Appeals in Civil Case No. CA-G.R. CV No. 03656 are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. The Decision dated February 1, 2010 of the Regional Trial Court, Branch 59, Toledo City in Civil Case No. T-1897 declaring the marriage between petitioner and respondent NULL and VOID is hereby REINSTATED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Stipulations in contracts such as those prohibiting the assignment of rights or obligations without the written consent of the counterparty have the force of law between the contracting parties and their assigns under the principle of relativity of contracts provided they are not contrary to law morals good customs public order or public policy. Consequently an assignee cannot validly demand performance from an obligor if the assignment was made in violation of a contractual stipulation requiring the obligors written consent which was never obtained rendering the assignment unenforceable against the obligor.
digest.facts: Petitioner Fort Bonifacio Development Corporation entered into a Trade Contract with MS Maxco for a condominium project which authorized the petitioner to withhold retention money and expressly prohibited MS Maxco from assigning any rights or obligations without the petitioners written consent. MS Maxco assigned a portion of its receivables to respondent Domingo via a Deed of Assignment but the petitioner refused to recognize the claim citing the lack of written consent and the exhaustion of the retention money due to garnishments by other creditors and rectification costs. The Regional Trial Court ruled in favor of Domingo ordering the petitioner to pay the assigned amount. The Court of Appeals affirmed the decision holding the petitioner liable to Domingo despite the absence of consent to the assignment.
digest.issue: Whether the petitioner is liable to pay the respondent the amount representing the portion of the retention money assigned by the contractor.
digest.ruling: NO, the petitioner is not liable. Under Articles 1159 and 1311 of the Civil Code contractual stipulations have the force of law between parties and their assigns and an assignee is bound by the exact same conditions as the assignor including prohibitions on assignment without consent. Here the Trade Contract explicitly prohibited MS Maxco from assigning its rights without the petitioners written consent which MS Maxco failed to secure thereby rendering the Deed of Assignment unenforceable against the petitioner. Hence the petitioner cannot be compelled to pay the respondent particularly because the retention money had already been exhausted by valid obligations to other creditors.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the petition is GRANTED. The Decision dated November 20, 2014 and the Resolution dated May 21, 2015 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV No. 96338, affirming the Decision dated December 18, 2009 of the Regional Trial Court of Pasay City, Branch 109 in Civil Case No. 06-0200cfm are hereby REVERSED and SET ASIDE. Likewise, the award of money amounting to Eight Hundred Four Thousand Sixty-Eight and 21/100 (P804,068.21) in favor of Manuel Domingo with legal interest from the date of the finality of this Decision until fully paid as and by way of actual or compensatory damages is DELETED without prejudice to the filing of a separate civil action against the proper party. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Public officials who certify or approve disbursements in reliance on local ordinances are shielded from civil liability for disallowances when they had no participation in the enactment of the invalid legislation and acted in the honest belief that such issuances were legal. Consequently subordinate administrative officers who merely implemented a local separation incentive program declared ultra vires are absolved of the obligation to refund the disallowed amounts unlike the local legislators whose liability requires further determination regarding their good faith in enacting the void measure.
digest.facts: Petitioners filed a motion for reconsideration challenging the decision which affirmed the Commission on Audits disallowance of the Early and Voluntary Separation Incentive Program of Puerto Princesa City and declared the enabling local ordinance and resolution void for being ultra vires. Petitioners argued that the disallowance constituted an invalid collateral attack on the ordinance and presented DBM letters to prove their good faith reliance on the presumption of validity. The Commission on Audit previously affirmed the notices of disallowance finding the program illegal and forwarded the records to the Ombudsman.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the disallowance constituted an invalid collateral attack on the local ordinance.

2. Whether the petitioners are liable to refund the disallowed amounts.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the disallowance was not an invalid collateral attack. Under the plenary auditing power of the Commission on Audit it has the authority to disallow disbursements of government funds that contravene national laws including those based on local ordinances that violate statutory prohibitions. Here the Commission correctly disallowed the expenditures for being illegal supplementary retirement benefits and its observation regarding the nullity of the ordinance was a valid exercise of its mandate to ensure legal compliance. Hence the disallowance was proper and the local legislation was correctly treated as having no legal basis.

2. NO, regarding the subordinate officials but the determination is deferred for the local legislators. Under the doctrine of good faith approving and certifying officers are shielded from civil liability if they relied on the apparent validity of ordinances they did not enact and had no hand in passing. Here petitioners Herrera and Atienza were merely subordinate employees who performed their duties in implementing the program without participation in the adoption of the ultra vires ordinance. Hence they are absolved of monetary liability while the liability of the petitioners who were members of the local legislative body remains subject to proceedings before the Ombudsman.
digest.dispositive: ACCORDINGLY, the instant Motion for Reconsideration is PARTIALLY GRANTED. Petitioners Roberto D. Herrera and Mylene J. Atienza are hereby ABSOLVED of any monetary liability relative to the refunding of the amounts covered by the Notices of Disallowance subject of respondent Commission on Audits Decision No. 2020-100 dated January 16, 2020. The rest of the Courts Decision dated November 29, 2022 STANDS. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under Section 2(a) and Section 3 of Rule 41 of the Rules of Court appeals in special proceedings and other cases of multiple or separate appeals require the filing of both a notice of appeal and a record on appeal within thirty days from notice of the judgment or final order. Consequently a trial court commits grave abuse of discretion when it disapproves a timely filed record on appeal in a settlement of estate case on the ground that the case was fully disposed of as the clear procedural requirement for a record on appeal entitles the appellant to the thirty-day reglementary period.
digest.facts: Petitioner filed a petition for probate of a will which was allowed by the Regional Trial Court leading to the issuance of a Partial Distribution Order that respondents appealed via record on appeal. While that appeal was pending the trial court issued a Final Distribution Order disposing of the remainder of the estate prompting respondents to file a Notice of Appeal and Record on Appeal twenty-nine days after the denial of their motion for reconsideration. The Regional Trial Court disapproved the appeal for being filed out of time ruling that since the case was fully disposed of the proper remedy was an ordinary appeal filed within fifteen days. The Court of Appeals reversed this ruling and ordered the approval of the appeal holding that the thirty-day period for multiple appeals applied to the special proceeding.
digest.issue: Whether a record on appeal is required in special proceedings even when the trial court has issued a final order purportedly disposing of the entire case.
digest.ruling: YES, a record on appeal is required. Under Section 2(a) and Section 3 of Rule 41 of the Rules of Court appeals in special proceedings generally require a record on appeal to be filed within thirty days regardless of whether the order appeals a particular part or the entire case. Here the settlement of the estate is a special proceeding inherently allowing multiple appeals and the issuance of a final distribution order does not automatically dispense with the mandatory requirement of a record on appeal or shorten the appeal period to fifteen days. Hence the respondents correctly followed the rules by filing their record on appeal within the thirty-day period and the appellate court correctly reversed the trial courts disapproval.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the Petition for Review on Certiorari dated September 30, 2020 filed by Ana Maria C. Manguerra is DENIED. The Decision dated June 17, 2019 and the Resolution dated September 8, 2020 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 151780 are AFFIRMED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: The power conferred upon the Court of Appeals to dismiss an appeal for failure to file an appellants brief is discretionary and directory rather than ministerial or mandatory allowing the court to relax the rules when strict application would result in the outright deprivation of property or where the interests of justice so require. Consequently the dismissal of an appeal based on a procedural lapse is improper when it would cause the appellant to lose their home without a hearing on the merits regarding their defense of ownership and payment effectively suppressing substantial justice for the sake of technicalities.
digest.facts: Respondent Purence Realty Corporation filed an action for recovery of possession and quieting of title against petitioner Nolasco regarding a subdivision lot in Laguna claiming ownership via Transfer Certificates of Title while Nolasco claimed his parents had fully paid for the property. The Regional Trial Court declared Nolasco in default for filing a late answer and subsequently ruled in favor of Purence ordering Nolasco to vacate the premises. Nolasco appealed to the Court of Appeals but failed to file his appellants brief within the reglementary period prompting the appellate court to consider the appeal abandoned and dismiss the case despite subsequent motions for extension filed by his counsel.
digest.issue: Whether the Court of Appeals erred in dismissing the appeal for failure to file the appellants brief.
digest.ruling: YES, the Court of Appeals erred. Under Section 1(e) of Rule 50 of the Rules of Court and established jurisprudence the power to dismiss an appeal for failure to file a brief is discretionary and may be relaxed when strong considerations of equity justify an exception particularly where the application of the rule would result in the outright deprivation of property. Here the petitioner faced the loss of his home based on a mere technicality without having his defense of payment and ownership heard in either the trial or appellate courts due to procedural lapses. Hence the appeal must be reinstated to serve the ends of substantial justice and prevent the deprivation of property without a full determination of the merits.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the petition is PARTLY GRANTED. The Resolutions dated August 30, 2019 and June 10, 2020 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV No. 112755 are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. Petitioners appeal is REINSTATED. The case is REMANDED to the Court of Appeals for proper resolution of the case on its merits. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine:
The condonation doctrine applies exclusively to elective public officials who are re-elected to public office and does not extend to appointive officials or those designated to positions. Consequently an appointive official designated as a member of the Bids and Awards Committee cannot invoke subsequent election to a legislative post to extinguish administrative liability for acts committed during the appointive tenure.

Violations of procurement laws and regulations constitute simple misconduct when there is no proof of corruption willful intent to violate the law or a flagrant disregard of established rules. Therefore public officers who participate in irregular procurement proceedings without evidence of corruption or deliberate intent to violate the law are liable only for simple misconduct rather than grave misconduct.
digest.facts: Petitioners Cabrales and Gozalo were members of the Bids and Awards Committee of the Municipality of Tukuran charged with grave misconduct regarding the irregular procurement of a motor grader which involved specifying a brand name non-publication in a nationwide newspaper and awarding the contract to a bidder lacking eligibility documents. Cabrales was a regular member while Gozalo was an alternate chairperson who attended meetings despite the presence of the regular chairperson. The Office of the Ombudsman found them guilty of grave misconduct and ordered their dismissal from service citing the flagrant irregularities in the bidding process. The Court of Appeals affirmed the decision ruling that the condonation doctrine did not apply to Gozalo and that the petitioners active participation in the rigged bidding warranted the finding of grave misconduct.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the condonation doctrine applies to petitioner Gozalo.

2. Whether the petitioners are guilty of grave misconduct.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the condonation doctrine does not apply to Gozalo. Under established jurisprudence the condonation doctrine only applies to elective officials who are re-elected and not to appointive officials or those designated to positions like the Bids and Awards Committee. Here Gozalo committed the offense while serving in an appointive capacity as an alternate BAC member hence his subsequent election as a Sangguniang Bayan member does not absolve him of administrative liability.

2. NO, the petitioners are guilty only of simple misconduct. Under the Civil Service rules and jurisprudence violations of procurement regulations without proof of corruption willful intent to violate the law or flagrant disregard of rules constitute simple misconduct rather than grave misconduct. Here the prosecution failed to prove overpricing or corrupt intent and Gozalos participation was limited as an alternate member who did not sign the pertinent documents while Cabrales participation lacked specific proof of willful violation beyond collective BAC action. Hence the penalty is reduced to suspension for three months.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the present petition is PARTIALLY GRANTED. The August 30, 2019 Decision and the August 10, 2020 Resolution of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 08750-MIN are hereby REVERSED and SET ASIDE insofar as these affirmed the dismissal of petitioners Rogelim A. Cabrales and Noe Cabrido Gozalo from the government service, together with its accessory penalties. Rogelim A. Cabrales and Noe Cabrido Gozalo are hereby found GUILTY of Simple Misconduct and PENALIZED with suspension for three (3) months without pay, or a fine equivalent to three (3) months salary deductible from whatever benefits may be due them, whichever is applicable under the Rules on Administrative Cases in the Civil Service. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine:
The payment of docket fees is a jurisdictional requirement such that the court acquires jurisdiction over the case only upon the payment of the prescribed fees and failure to do so without a valid excuse warrants the outright dismissal of the petition. Consequently a petition for certiorari filed without the requisite docket fees and certification against forum shopping is considered a mere scrap of paper and cannot be remedied by a belated submission or a plea for liberality when the petitioner had the opportunity to comply.

Under Department of Justice Circular No 70-A resolutions of Regional State Prosecutors in cases cognizable by first-level trial courts are final and unappealable to the Secretary of Justice making the special civil action for certiorari the proper remedy upon denial of a motion for reconsideration. Consequently the Court of Appeals errs in ruling that a petitioner failed to exhaust administrative remedies for bypassing the Secretary of Justice when the offense charged falls within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Municipal Trial Court based on the amended amounts under Republic Act No 10951.
digest.facts: Petitioners filed complaints for Estafa and Falsification against private respondents for offering a Cruise Ship Management Course without TESDA authority which the City Prosecutor found probable cause for but was reversed by the Regional Prosecutor due to lack of proof of bad faith and payment. Petitioners filed a petition for certiorari with the Court of Appeals which dismissed it outright for failure to pay docket fees attach verification and certification against forum shopping and indicate actual addresses. The Court of Appeals also ruled that petitioners failed to exhaust administrative remedies by not appealing the Regional Prosecutors resolution to the Secretary of Justice.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the Court of Appeals correctly dismissed the petition for failure to pay docket fees and other procedural defects.

2. Whether the Court of Appeals erred in ruling that petitioners failed to exhaust administrative remedies.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the dismissal was correct. Under established jurisprudence and Rule 46 of the Rules of Court the payment of docket fees is jurisdictional and the submission of a certification against forum shopping is mandatory such that non-compliance warrants the dismissal of the case. Here petitioners failed to pay the docket fees upon filing and did not attach the required certification offering invalid excuses regarding the pandemic and their counsels age which did not justify their negligence. Hence the petition was properly dismissed as the court did not acquire jurisdiction and the defects were fatal.

2. YES, the Court of Appeals erred on this ground. Under Department of Justice Circular No 70-A as amended resolutions of Regional Prosecutors in cases cognizable by first-level courts are final and not appealable to the Secretary of Justice. Here the amounts involved in the Estafa case fell within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Municipal Trial Court under Republic Act No 10951 meaning the Regional Prosecutors decision was final and the proper remedy was certiorari to the Court of Appeals. Hence the appellate court was incorrect in requiring an appeal to the Secretary of Justice although the dismissal stands on procedural grounds.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the instant Petition is DENIED. The Resolution dated November 20, 2020 of the Court of Appeals 2nd Division in CA-G.R. SP No. 165836 is hereby AFFIRMED, whereas the same Division's Resolution dated June 14, 2021 is hereby REVERSED and SET ASIDE. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: A Torrens certificate of title is indefeasible and immune from collateral attacks such that its validity cannot be challenged in a summary ejectment proceeding where the sole issue is physical possession. Consequently a defendant in a forcible entry case cannot defeat the registered owners right to possession by alleging that the title was fraudulently issued as this constitutes a prohibited collateral attack that must be raised in a direct proceeding instituted for that purpose.
digest.facts: Petitioner Rivera filed a complaint for forcible entry against respondent Velasco alleging that he used strategy and stealth to occupy a portion of her property covered by Torrens titles and constructed a house thereon. Respondent countered that he was the lawful owner and possessor since 1995 and that Petitioners titles were obtained through fraud which prompted him to file a protest with the DENR. The Municipal Trial Court ruled in favor of Petitioner finding prior possession and valid titles a decision affirmed by the Regional Trial Court which rejected the collateral attack on the titles. However the Court of Appeals reversed the lower courts and dismissed the complaint ruling that the case involved a complex ownership issue better resolved in an accion reivindicatoria given the pending protest and reconveyance cases.
digest.issue: Whether the Court of Appeals erred in dismissing the forcible entry complaint by allowing a collateral attack on the petitioner's Torrens titles.
digest.ruling: YES, the Court of Appeals erred. Under Section 48 of Presidential Decree No 1529 and established jurisprudence a Torrens certificate of title is indefeasible and cannot be collaterally attacked in an ejectment suit where the only issue is physical possession. Here the respondent's defense challenging the validity of the petitioner's free patent and title constituted an impermissible collateral attack and the petitioner's registered title entitled her to possession against the respondent's intrusion. Hence the Court of Appeals incorrect reliance on the ownership dispute to dismiss the summary ejectment action is reversed and the Municipal Trial Courts decision reinstating possession to the titled owner is restored.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the petition is GRANTED. The Decision dated February 15, 2018 and the Resolution dated September 17, 2018 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 151231 are hereby REVERSED and SET ASIDE. The Decision dated July 6, 2015 of the Municipal Trial Court of General Tinio, Nueva Ecija in Civil Case No. 1017 is hereby REINSTATED with MODIFICATION in that legal interest of six percent (6%) per annum is imposed on the total monetary award due petitioner Eufrocina Rivera, reckoned from the time of finality of this Decision until its full satisfaction. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: The recruitment, transportation, transfer, harboring, or receipt of a child for the purpose of exploitation shall be considered as trafficking in persons even if it does not involve any of the means set forth in the law, such as threat, use of force, or coercion. The consent of the minor victim is immaterial and cannot be raised as a defense. The crime is classified as Qualified Trafficking in Persons when the offender is a relative of the victim within the fourth civil degree of consanguinity or affinity, as the relationship entails a higher degree of trust that, when betrayed, aggravates the offense.
digest.facts: The case stemmed from a referral by the Australian Federal Police to the Philippine National Police regarding an online personality trafficking a Filipino minor. An undercover police officer communicated with the suspect via email, where the suspect offered his ten-year-old daughter for sexual services, specifically oral sex and intercourse, in exchange for money. An entrapment operation was conducted at a mall in Mandaluyong City where the accused-appellant met with the undercover team, accepted the marked money, and offered the minor for sexual acts. The minor victim, who was actually the niece of the accused-appellant, testified that her uncle forced her to perform sexual acts on foreigners and on himself for practice. The accused-appellant denied the charges, claiming he was merely meeting a friend to return a bag containing personal items, but his defense was rejected by the trial court.
digest.issue: Whether the accused-appellant is guilty beyond reasonable doubt of Qualified Trafficking in Persons.
digest.ruling: YES. The Supreme Court affirmed the conviction, ruling that all elements of the crime were present. The accused-appellant knowingly recruited and harbored his minor niece for the purpose of sexual exploitation. The testimony of the child victim was found categorical, consistent, and credible, sufficient to overcome the defense of denial. The relationship of the accused-appellant as the uncle of the victim qualified the offense, warranting the imposition of the maximum penalty.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, premises considered, the Decision dated October 15, 2019 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CR-HC No. 11715 is AFFIRMED. Accused-appellant XXX is hereby found GUILTY beyond reasonable doubt of the crime of Qualified Trafficking in Persons, under Section 4(e) in relation to Section 6(a) of Republic Act No. 9208, as expanded by Republic Act No. 10364. Accordingly, accused-appellant XXX is SENTENCED to suffer the penalty of life imprisonment and to pay a fine in the amount of P2,000,000.00. He is DIRECTED to pay AAA the amounts of P500,000.00 as moral damages and P100,000.00 as exemplary damages. All damages awarded shall earn legal interest at the rate of six percent (6%) per annum from the date of finality of this Decision until full satisfaction. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under Article 172 of the Family Code and established jurisprudence a certificate of live birth purportedly identifying the putative father is not competent evidence of paternity when there is no showing that the putative father had a hand in the preparation of said certificate. Consequently a reconstructed birth certificate that bears a different name for the father and lacks the signature or any indication of intervention by the alleged parent has no probative value to prove illegitimate filiation and cannot support a claim for inheritance by the alleged heirs.
digest.facts: Petitioners who are the heirs of Constancio Vizcarra executed an extrajudicial settlement of the estate of Ireneo Vizcarra leading to the issuance of new titles in their names. Respondents filed a complaint to nullify the settlement claiming to be heirs of Silvestre Vizcarra whom they alleged was an illegitimate son of Ireneo based on a reconstructed NSO Certificate derived from a 1978 Local Civil Registrar certification and a marriage contract. The Regional Trial Court ruled in favor of respondents declaring the settlement void upon finding the NSO Certificate sufficient proof of filiation. The Court of Appeals affirmed the decision holding that the NSO Certificate was a valid reconstruction enjoying the presumption of regularity despite the absence of the original 1920 Record Book.
digest.issue: Whether the respondents established the filiation of Silvestre to the decedent Ireneo to entitle them to a share in the estate.
digest.ruling: NO, the respondents failed to establish filiation. Under Article 172 of the Family Code and relevant jurisprudence a birth certificate is not competent evidence of paternity if the putative father had no hand in its preparation such as signing it or supplying information. Here the NSO Certificate presented by respondents showed a discrepancy in the fathers name and crucially lacked any signature or indication that Ireneo intervened in its preparation or the registration of Silvestres birth. Hence the certificate has no probative value to prove filiation and the complaint for nullity of the settlement must be dismissed for lack of evidence supporting the respondents status as heirs.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the Petition for Review on Certiorari dated March 4, 2013 is GRANTED. The assailed Decision dated October 4, 2012 and the Resolution dated January 14, 2013 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV. No. 97945 are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. The Decision dated September 22, 2011 of the Regional Trial Court of ParaÃ±aque City, Branch 274 in Civil Case No. 07-0313 is VACATED. A new one is entered DISMISSING the Complaint dated September 1, 2007. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under Sections 6(A) and 13 of the National Internal Revenue Code and relevant revenue memorandum orders a Revenue Officer must be authorized by a valid Letter of Authority to conduct an examination of a taxpayer and any reassignment of such investigation to a different officer requires the issuance of a new Letter of Authority by the Commissioner or a duly authorized representative. Consequently an assessment resulting from an investigation conducted by a revenue officer who was merely designated through a memorandum referral signed by a Revenue District Officer without a new Letter of Authority is void and bears no valid fruit due to lack of statutory authority.
digest.facts: Respondent Robiegie Corporation was issued a Letter of Authority authorizing Revenue Officer David to examine its books for the taxable year 2008 but the investigation was subsequently reassigned to Revenue Officer Dy through a Memorandum Referral signed only by the Revenue District Officer. Based on Dys investigation the Bureau of Internal Revenue issued deficiency tax assessments against the respondent which led to a collection case filed by the petitioner Republic. The Court of Tax Appeals Second Division dismissed the complaint ruling that the assessments were void because Revenue Officer Dy lacked the requisite Letter of Authority to conduct the investigation as the memorandum referral was insufficient. The Court of Tax Appeals En Banc affirmed this decision holding that a Letter of Authority is mandatory for a valid audit and the memorandum referral signed by a mere Revenue District Officer could not vest the necessary authority.
digest.issue: Whether the tax assessments issued against the respondent are valid despite the investigation being conducted by a revenue officer not named in the Letter of Authority but merely designated through a memorandum referral.
digest.ruling: NO, the assessments are invalid. Under Sections 6(A) and 13 of the National Internal Revenue Code and Revenue Memorandum Order No 43-90 the power of a revenue officer to examine a taxpayer flows exclusively from a valid Letter of Authority issued by the Commissioner or a duly authorized representative and any reassignment of cases requires a new Letter of Authority. Here the investigation was conducted by Revenue Officer Dy who was not named in the original Letter of Authority and was only designated via a Memorandum Referral signed by a Revenue District Officer who lacked the authority to issue Letters of Authority. Hence the assessment is void for being based on an unauthorized investigation as the revenue officer acted without the requisite statutory authority.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the present petition is DENIED. The December 2, 2021 Decision and the April 8, 2022 Resolution of the Court of Tax Appeals in CTA EB No. 2339 (CTA OC No. 023) are hereby AFFIRMED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Under Sections 9 and 10 of the Revised Rules on Summary Procedure parties are required to submit the affidavits of their witnesses and other evidence within ten days from receipt of the order issued after the preliminary conference and the court shall not resort to clarificatory procedures merely to gain time for the rendition of judgment. Consequently an appellate court commits reversible error when it admits and relies upon second judicial affidavits containing recantations that were filed only after the trial court had already rendered its decision and without a court order for clarification as such irregular submissions violate the rule against piecemeal presentation of evidence and deprive the trial court of the opportunity to assess witness credibility.
digest.facts: Respondents filed complaints for forcible entry claiming that petitioners by force and stealth entered the accretion portions of their respective lots in 2013 while petitioners countered that they were farm helpers of Vitaliano Ganado who had been in actual physical possession of the disputed property since 1967. The Municipal Trial Court in Cities dismissed the complaints finding that respondents failed to prove prior physical possession and gave weight to the affidavits of BARC Chairpersons who testified that petitioners had long been tilling the land which the Regional Trial Court affirmed in toto. However the Court of Appeals reversed the lower courts and ordered petitioners to vacate relying on second judicial affidavits executed by the BARC Chairpersons which recanted their earlier testimonies and were submitted to the trial court only after it had rendered its decision and the respondents had filed a notice of appeal.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the Court of Appeals correctly considered the second judicial affidavits submitted after the trial court rendered its decision.

2. Whether the respondents proved by preponderance of evidence their prior physical possession of the contested property.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the Court of Appeals erred in considering the late evidence. Under the Revised Rules on Summary Procedure parties must submit all affidavits and evidence within ten days from the preliminary conference order and additional evidence is generally only allowed upon the courts specific order to clarify material facts. Here the second judicial affidavits were filed only after the Municipal Trial Court had already rendered its decision and without any clarificatory order constituting a malicious and irregular scheme to introduce recanted testimony on appeal. Hence the appellate court should have disregarded the belatedly filed affidavits and relied solely on the evidence properly submitted during the trial proceedings.

2. NO, the respondents failed to prove prior physical possession. Under Section 1 Rule 133 of the Revised Rules on Evidence and established jurisprudence regarding forcible entry the plaintiff must prove prior de facto physical possession by a preponderance of evidence rather than ownership or title. Here respondents evidence focused on their ownership of the adjoining lots without detailing acts of actual possession over the accretion while petitioners provided consistent testimony supported by the original affidavits of neutral witnesses regarding their farming of the land on behalf of Ganado since the 1970s. Hence the Supreme Court reinstated the trial courts dismissal of the complaints as petitioners evidence of prior possession preponderated over respondents claims.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the Petition is GRANTED. The Decision dated November 29, 2016 and the Resolution dated March 31, 2017 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 144897 are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. The Joint Decision dated November 7, 2014 of the Municipal Trial Court in Cities, Branch 1, San Jose City, as affirmed by the Regional Trial Court, Branch 38, San Jose City in its Joint Decision dated May 11, 2015, is REINSTATED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: In illegal termination cases where the employee fails to prove the fact of dismissal and the employer concurrently fails to prove abandonment the equitable remedy is reinstatement without backwages as each party must bear their own loss unless reinstatement is no longer feasible due to the lapse of time in which case separation pay is awarded. Consequently an employee who stops reporting for work without a clear intent to sever the relationship is entitled to separation pay in lieu of reinstatement when the employer cannot substantiate the claim of abandonment with proof of overt acts.
digest.facts: Petitioner was hired as a delivery boy and dishwasher at a restaurant allegedly owned by respondent spouses but registered as a sole proprietorship of another respondent and his salary was later coursed through a manpower agency before he was allegedly barred from the premises. He filed a complaint for illegal dismissal but the respondents claimed he abandoned his work and was an employee of the agency rather than the restaurant. The Labor Arbiter dismissed the complaint against the restaurant finding the agency to be the employer but the National Labor Relations Commission reversed this ruling declaring petitioner a regular employee of the respondents who was illegally dismissed. The Court of Appeals affirmed the employer-employee relationship but ruled that there was neither illegal dismissal nor abandonment deleting the awards for backwages and separation pay.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the petitioner was illegally dismissed or abandoned his employment.

2. Whether the respondent spouses are solidarily liable with the registered owner of the sole proprietorship.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, to both illegal dismissal and abandonment. Under established jurisprudence the employee bears the burden of proving the fact of dismissal by substantial evidence while the employer must prove abandonment through overt acts showing a clear intention to sever the relationship. Here the petitioner failed to substantiate his claim of being barred from the premises and the respondents failed to prove that the petitioners absence was accompanied by a manifest desire to end his employment. Hence the equitable remedy is reinstatement without backwages but given the passage of time rendering reinstatement impracticable separation pay is awarded instead.

2. NO, the respondent spouses are not solidarily liable. Under the law a sole proprietorship does not possess a juridical personality separate from its owner and the registered proprietor is personally liable for the debts and obligations of the business. Here the restaurant was registered solely in the name of respondent Velasquez and there was no credible proof that the respondent spouses acted in bad faith regarding the petitioners employment status. Hence only the registered owner Velasquez is liable for the monetary claims and attorney's fees.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the petition is PARTLY GRANTED. The June 28, 2012 Decision and the January 21, 2013 Resolution of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 114946 are AFFIRMED with the following MODIFICATIONS. 1. In lieu of an order of reinstatement without backwages, respondents are ORDERED to pay petitioner George S. Galbinez, Jr. separation pay computed at one (1) month salary for every year of service until petitioner stopped working for respondents in 2007. 2. Respondent Gerry Velasquez is ORDERED to pay petitioner attorney's fees equivalent to ten percent (10%) of the total monetary award; 3. All amounts due shall earn interest at the rate of six percent (6%) per annum from date of finality of this Decision until fully paid. The case is hereby REMANDED to the Labor Arbiter for an immediate re-computation of the monetary benefits due the petitioner George S. Galbinez, Jr. which respondent Gerry Velasquez, should pay without delay. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Novation takes place when the contracting parties expressly disclose that their object in making the new contract is to extinguish the old contract or when the old and new obligations are on every point incompatible with each other such that the change in the object is essential rather than merely accidental. Consequently where a second construction agreement involves a revised plan that is substantially different from and incompatible with the original plan under a first agreement an objective novation occurs preventing the contractor from recovering payment under the superseded contract except for the actual work accomplished prior to the novation to prevent unjust enrichment.
digest.facts: Petitioner entered into a construction agreement with respondent for electrical works which was suspended before the parties executed a second agreement covering revised plans with a significantly higher contract price and a provision stating it superseded prior agreements. Petitioner sought payment under both contracts claiming they co-existed which the Construction Industry Arbitration Commission granted by awarding retention fees for both agreements. However the Court of Appeals reversed this decision ruling that the second agreement involving mutually exclusive revised plans constituted an objective novation of the first agreement. The appellate court consequently ordered petitioner to reimburse respondent for the excess payments received under the extinguished first contract.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the first agreement was novated by the second agreement.

2. Whether the Court of Appeals correctly ordered the reimbursement of excess payments based on solutio indebiti.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the first agreement was novated. Under Article 1292 of the Civil Code novation occurs when there is an essential change in the object of the contract or when the new obligation is incompatible with the old one. Here the second agreement involved a revised electrical plan that was substantially different from and could not be simultaneously implemented with the original plan constituting an essential change in the subject matter. Hence the second agreement expressly and objectively novated the first agreement rendering the latter extinguished.

2. YES, the reimbursement was correct. Under the principle of solutio indebiti and the rule against unjust enrichment a party who receives payment for work not actually performed must return the excess to the payor. Here petitioner received full payment for the first agreement despite only accomplishing a small fraction of the work before it was superseded by the second agreement. Hence the appellate court correctly ordered the return of the overpayment as allowing petitioner to collect on both contracts would result in unjust enrichment.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the present Petition for Review on Certiorari is hereby DENIED for lack of merit, and the Decision dated January 31, 2013 of the Court of Appeals (10th Division) in CA-G.R. SP No. 125889 is hereby AFFIRMED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: An Information must state the acts or omissions constituting the offense with sufficient particularity to apprise the accused of the nature and cause of the accusation such that a conviction cannot be based on facts not alleged therein even if proven during trial. Consequently an accused charged with rape through force and intimidation cannot be convicted of child abuse under Republic Act No 7610 based on evidence of monetary inducement or coercion if such specific elements of exploitation were not alleged in the Information as this violates the right to due process.
digest.facts: Accused-appellant a pastor was charged with three counts of Rape in relation to RA 7610 for having carnal knowledge of the minor victim AAA on three separate occasions alleging the acts were committed against her will and consent. The prosecution established that during the first incident the accused threatened to kill the victim and used his moral ascendancy to rape her but for the subsequent incidents the evidence showed the sexual acts occurred without force but were facilitated by monetary allowance and material support. The Regional Trial Court convicted him of Rape for the first incident and Child Abuse under RA 7610 for the subsequent incidents ruling that consent is immaterial for minors a decision affirmed by the Court of Appeals which held that the sexual adventures constituted sexual assault punishable under the special law.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the accused-appellant is guilty beyond reasonable doubt of Rape for the first incident.

2. Whether the accused-appellant may be convicted of Child Abuse under Section 5(b) of RA 7610 for the subsequent incidents despite the Information charging Rape under the Revised Penal Code.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the accused is guilty of Rape for the first incident. Under Article 266-A of the Revised Penal Code rape is committed through force, threat, or intimidation which includes the moral ascendancy that compels the victim to submit. Here the accused was a pastor exercising moral ascendancy over the minor victim and employed threats against her life to achieve his carnal desires thereby satisfying the elements of the crime. Hence the conviction for the first count of Rape is affirmed.

2. NO, the accused cannot be convicted of Child Abuse for the subsequent incidents. Under the constitutional right to be informed of the nature and cause of accusation and Rule 110 of the Rules of Court an accused cannot be convicted of a crime unless its elements are charged in the Information or necessarily included therein. Here while the evidence pointed to sexual abuse through inducement or material support under Section 5(b) of RA 7610 the Information only alleged force and intimidation characteristic of Rape under the Revised Penal Code without mentioning the specific elements of exploitation or monetary consideration required for the special offense. Hence the accused must be acquitted of the remaining charges because the elements proved were not charged in the Information.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, in view of the foregoing, the appeal is hereby PARTLY GRANTED. Judgment is hereby rendered as follows: a. In Criminal Case Nos. 3596 and 3599, Accused-appellant Freddie Sernadilla is ACQUITTED. The Decision dated June 17, 2011 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CR-HC No. 31721 which affirmed the Regional Trial Court of Baler, Aurora, Branch 96, is hereby REVERSED and SET ASIDE. b. In Criminal Case No. 3600, the Decision dated June 17, 2011 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CR-HC No. 31721 is AFFIRMED with MODIFICATION. Accused-appellant Freddie Sernadilla is found GUILTY beyond reasonable doubt of the crime of Rape under Article 266-A(1) in relation to Article 266-B of the Revised Penal Code, for which he is sentenced to suffer the penalty of reclusion perpetua. Accused-appellant is also ORDERED to pay the victim, AAA, P75,000.00 as civil indemnity, P75,000.00 as moral damages, and P75,000.00 as exemplary damages. Legal interest at the rate of six percent (6%) per annum is imposed on the monetary awards from the finality of this Decision until fully paid. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Possession in forcible entry cases may be acquired not only through material occupation but also through juridical acts to which the law gives the force of acts of possession such as the execution of public instruments or the issuance of a free patent. Consequently a party presenting a Torrens title derived from a free patent coupled with tax declarations and official government reports confirming long-term occupation establishes a superior right of possession over a party relying merely on self-serving affidavits.
digest.facts: Petitioners filed a complaint for forcible entry alleging that they were the registered owners of a property covered by an Original Certificate of Title issued via free patent in 1984 and had been in possession since 1945 until respondents entered through force and intimidation in 2005. Respondents countered that the property was part of their ancestral domain and submitted Sinumpaang Salaysay or affidavits from relatives to claim they had actual possession. The Municipal Circuit Trial Court ruled in favor of petitioners finding that their title and tax declarations proved possession a decision which the Regional Trial Court affirmed in toto. However the Court of Appeals reversed the lower courts ruling that petitioners failed to prove prior physical possession and gave greater weight to the respondents affidavits.
digest.issue: Whether the petitioners proved their prior physical possession of the subject property by a preponderance of evidence.
digest.ruling: YES, the petitioners proved their prior physical possession. Under established jurisprudence possession can be acquired by juridical acts such as the grant of a free patent and the registration of title which enjoy the presumption of regularity regarding the grantees compliance with possession requirements. Here petitioners presented their Torrens title tax declarations and official government reports from the Bureau of Lands confirming their predecessors actual occupation since 1945 which constituted stronger evidence than the self-serving and partial affidavits presented by respondents. Hence the appellate court erred in disregarding the petitioners documentary evidence of possession and the trial courts decision ordering respondents to vacate is reinstated.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, premises considered, the petition is hereby GRANTED. Accordingly, the July 23, 2015 Decision and June 30, 2016 Resolution of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 107195 are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. The October 27, 2008 Decision in Civil Case No. CV-08-5917 and January 6, 2009 Order of the Regional Trial Court of Calapan Branch 40, which affirmed the March 25, 2008 Decision of the Municipal Circuit Trial Court of San Teodoro-Baco-Puerto Galera, are hereby REINSTATED in Civil Case No. 338. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine:
Prescription is a ground for dismissal that may be raised at any stage but the party invoking it for the first time on appeal must prove that the bar is clearly and satisfactorily apparent on the record either in the allegations of the complaint or established by the evidence. Consequently a defense of prescription raised belatedly on appeal is properly rejected when the determination of the applicable prescriptive period requires the resolution of factual issues such as the validity of a contract or the presence of laches which are not apparent from the pleadings alone.

The relation of an agent to the principal is fiduciary in nature such that the agent is estopped from acquiring or asserting a title adverse to that of the principal regarding the property subject of the agency. Consequently a mortgagee who is contractually appointed as the mortgagors attorney-in-fact and purchases the mortgaged property at a tax sale to protect the security interest acts as an administrator and holds the title in constructive trust for the mortgagor preventing the mortgagee from claiming ownership after the loan is fully paid.
digest.facts: Spouses Tad-y obtained loans from PNB secured by a real estate mortgage but failed to pay real property taxes on two lots which led to a tax delinquency sale where PNB purchased the properties as the sole bidder to protect its interest. Years later the spouses availed of a loan restructuring program and fully paid their obligations but PNB refused to release the two lots claiming it had acquired absolute ownership through the auction sale which prompted the spouses to file a suit for breach of contract and reconveyance. The Regional Trial Court ruled in favor of the spouses declaring that PNBs purchase inured to their benefit as their attorney-in-fact under the mortgage stipulations. The Court of Appeals affirmed the decision and ruled that PNB could not raise the defense of prescription for the first time on appeal as it was not apparent from the pleadings.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the Court of Appeals erred in refusing to dismiss the complaint on the ground of prescription raised for the first time on appeal.

2. Whether PNBs acquisition of the subject properties at the tax delinquency sale inured to the benefit of the respondents creating a constructive trust.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the dismissal was properly denied. Under established jurisprudence a party invoking prescription for the first time on appeal must prove that the bar is clearly and satisfactorily apparent on the record or the allegations of the complaint. Here the applicable statute of limitations was not apparent because the complaint raised factual issues regarding the validity of the tax sale and the existence of a constructive trust which required the presentation of evidence during trial. Hence the Court of Appeals correctly refused to pass upon the defense of prescription which involves matters of fact not raised in the lower court.

2. YES, a constructive trust was created. Under Articles 1456 and 1877 of the Civil Code and the principles of agency an agent is prohibited from acquiring title adverse to the principal and any property acquired in breach of this fiduciary duty is held in constructive trust. Here the mortgage contract appointed PNB as attorney-in-fact to perform acts of administration and its purchase of the lots to preserve its security interest constituted an act of administration on behalf of the spouses rather than an act of dominion. Hence PNB is estopped from claiming ownership and must reconvey the properties to the spouses who have fully paid their loans.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the present petition is hereby DENIED. The April 16, 2013 Decision and the September 4, 2014 Resolution of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV No. 01412 are AFFIRMED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Just compensation must be valued at the time of taking and the applicable administrative order for valuation is determined by the date the claim folder was received by the Land Bank of the Philippines specifically limiting the application of Republic Act No 9700 and Administrative Order No 1 Series of 2010 to cases where the claim folder was received on or subsequent to July 1 2009. Consequently a court commits grave abuse of discretion when it applies the presumptive date of taking under the 2010 issuance to a property acquired in 2002 governed by Republic Act No 6657 and Administrative Order No 5 Series of 1998 as the remedy for the diminution of value due to delay is the imposition of legal interest rather than an arbitrary adjustment of the reckoning date for production values.
digest.facts: Spouses Cortez voluntarily offered their coconut land for agrarian reform acquisition in 2000 which led to the transfer of title to the Republic in 2002 and a valuation by the Land Bank of the Philippines at P106,542.98 based on DAR Administrative Order No 5 Series of 1998 which the spouses rejected. The Regional Trial Court acting as a Special Agrarian Court fixed the just compensation at P397,958.41 by utilizing the formula under the 1998 issuance but modifying the reckoning date for production data to June 30 2009 pursuant to Administrative Order No 1 Series of 2010 to update the value and avoid interest payment. The Court of Appeals affirmed the trial courts decision prompting the Land Bank to file a petition arguing that the 2010 issuance and its presumptive date of taking do not apply to acquisitions where the claim folder was received in 2001.
digest.issue: Whether the Regional Trial Court correctly applied the reckoning date under DAR Administrative Order No 1 Series of 2010 to determine the just compensation of property acquired in 2002.
digest.ruling: NO, the Regional Trial Court erred in applying the 2010 issuance. Under established jurisprudence and the transitory provisions of the relevant administrative orders just compensation must be valued at the time of taking and claims folders received prior to July 1 2009 must be valued in accordance with Section 17 of Republic Act No 6657 prior to its amendment by Republic Act No 9700. Here the claim folder was received in 2001 and the property was taken in 2002 placing it squarely under the coverage of DAR Administrative Order No 5 Series of 1998 rather than the 2010 issuance which applies only to prospective cases. Hence the appellate courts affirmation of the trial courts deviation from the mandatory formula and reckoning period constitutes reversible error and the case is remanded for recomputation with the imposition of legal interest to address the delay.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, premises considered, the Petition for Review on Certiorari dated January 17, 2014 filed by petitioner Land Bank of the Philippines is PARTIALLY GRANTED. Accordingly, the Decision dated July 9, 2013 and the Resolution dated December 16, 2013 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 123233 are ANNULLED and SET ASIDE. Agrarian Case No. 07-02 is hereby REMANDED to the Regional Trial Court of Legazpi City, Branch 3, for reception of evidence to determine with utmost dispatch the just compensation due to respondent spouses Lydia and Carlos Cortez in accordance with the guidelines set forth in this Decision. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: The authority to represent the People in criminal proceedings before the Court of Appeals or Supreme Court is vested solely in the Solicitor General and a judgment granting a demurrer to evidence constitutes an acquittal that is final and unappealable under the principle of double jeopardy. Consequently a private party lacks the legal standing to file a petition for certiorari challenging a judgment of acquittal without the conformity of the Solicitor General especially when the petition merely attacks the trial courts appreciation of evidence rather than alleging a deprivation of due process.
digest.facts: Petitioner administrator filed criminal cases for carnapping against respondent regarding unreturned vehicles which resulted in the Regional Trial Court granting respondents demurrer to evidence due to insufficiency of prosecution evidence. Petitioner filed a petition for certiorari with the Court of Appeals without the conformity of the Office of the Solicitor General which the appellate court dismissed for failure to acquire jurisdiction over the respondents person despite his filing of a comment. Petitioner appealed to the Supreme Court arguing that the appellate court acquired jurisdiction through respondents voluntary appearance while respondent maintained that the petition was defective for lack of the Solicitor Generals participation.
digest.issue: Whether the petition for certiorari challenging the grant of the demurrer to evidence may prosper despite the absence of the Office of the Solicitor General.
digest.ruling: NO, the petition must be denied. Under Section 21 Article III of the Constitution and relevant procedural rules a grant of demurrer to evidence operates as a valid acquittal which bars any further prosecution for the same offense and may only be challenged by the Solicitor General on the ground of grave abuse of discretion amounting to lack of due process. Here the petitioner filed the action without the Solicitor Generals authority and sought to review the trial courts evaluation of evidence which is prohibited as it would place the respondent in double jeopardy. Hence the petition is dismissed because the private complainant has no standing to question the acquittal and the judgment is final and executory.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the petition is DENIED.

digest.doctrine: Under the Implementing Rules and Regulations of Presidential Decree No 1594 a contractor cannot recover payment for extra works based on quantum meruit if the works were commenced without the mandatory prior approval of the proper government authority and over the objections of the agency. Consequently a contractor who proceeds with additional works based merely on letter requests assumes the risk of disapproval and is not entitled to compensation beyond the approved amount as the principle of quantum meruit does not apply where the contractor acted in bad faith or contrary to express regulations.
digest.facts: Petitioner Estomo was awarded a contract by respondent Civil Service Commission CSC Region X for the construction of the third floor of its building and subsequently claimed payment for the contract balance and various extra works totaling a significant sum. While the CSC admitted the existence of extra works it disputed the amount claiming only a portion was formally approved and tendered a lower sum via escrow deposit after deducting taxes retention money and deficiencies. The Regional Trial Court ruled in favor of petitioner ordering the CSC to pay the full outstanding balance with interest but the Court of Appeals reversed this decision declaring the CSCs obligation extinguished by the release of the escrow deposit and ruling that petitioner was not entitled to the unapproved extra works under the principle of quantum meruit.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the petitioner is entitled to payment for extra works in the amount claimed based on the principle of quantum meruit.

2. Whether the petitioner is entitled to the release of the retention money withheld by the respondent.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, the petitioner is not entitled to the full claim for extra works. Under the Implementing Rules and Regulations of Presidential Decree No 1594 extra works require prior approval by the authorized official and payment cannot be collected on the basis of letter requests alone. Here the petitioner proceeded with the additional works despite the absence of approval and over the objections of the respondent distinguishing this case from instances where quantum meruit was applied due to implied authorization or good faith. Hence the petitioner is limited to the amount of extra works actually approved by the respondent as he assumed the risk of disapproval.

2. YES, the petitioner is entitled to the release of the retention money. Under the relevant rules retention money serves as security for uncorrected defects and third-party liabilities which purpose is effectively served when the agency already deducts a specific amount for identified deficiencies. Here the respondent deducted a sum for deficiencies discovered by the city engineers which covered the same purpose as the retention money while simultaneously enjoying the use of the building since 1997. Hence the retention money must be released to the petitioner to prevent unjust enrichment in favor of the government.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the Petition for Review on Certiorari is PARTIALLY GRANTED. The Decision dated August 31, 2018 and the Resolution dated July 19, 2019 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV No. 04284-MIN are AFFIRMED with MODIFICATION. (See full text for full disposition)

digest.doctrine: The constitutional right to speedy disposition of cases extends to administrative proceedings and requires the Office of the Ombudsman to resolve complaints within reasonable periods prescribed by its own procedural rules and the complexities of the case. Consequently a delay of almost eight years in resolving an administrative case without sufficient justification regarding the complexity of evidence or issues constitutes inordinate delay that warrants the dismissal of the complaint for violation of the respondents constitutional rights.
digest.facts: Respondent filed a complaint in 2008 against petitioner former mayor and her husband for grave misconduct and dishonesty alleging misappropriation of public funds through checks issued for goods and services. Despite the parties submitting their position papers by December 2008 the Office of the Ombudsman rendered its decision finding petitioner liable only on November 2, 2016 which was nearly eight years later. The Court of Appeals affirmed the Ombudsmans decision and rejected petitioners claim of inordinate delay ruling that she failed to prove the delay was vexatious. Petitioner appealed arguing that the unexplained eight-year delay violated her constitutional right to the speedy disposition of her case.
digest.issue: Whether the Office of the Ombudsman violated the petitioners right to the speedy disposition of her case due to the delay in resolving the administrative complaint.
digest.ruling: YES, the delay violated her constitutional right. Under Section 16 Article III of the Constitution and the guidelines in Cagang v Sandiganbayan the Ombudsman must resolve cases within reasonable periods and the prosecution bears the burden of justifying delays beyond the prescribed timeframes. Here the Ombudsman took almost eight years to resolve a straightforward administrative case involving non-voluminous evidence without offering any valid justification for the hiatus violating its own procedural rules which mandate prompt adjudication. Hence the Supreme Court reversed the appellate courts decision and dismissed the administrative complaint due to the inordinate delay.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, premises considered, the January 30, 2018 Decision and June 6, 2018 Resolution of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 151397, which affirmed the November 2, 2016 Decision and March 1, 2017 Order of the Office of the Ombudsman in OMB-L-A-08-0022-A, are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. Accordingly, the administrative complaint for grave misconduct and serious dishonesty against petitioner Joan V. Alarilla is hereby DISMISSED for violation of her Constitutional right to speedy disposition of cases. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Rule 18.03 of the Code of Professional Responsibility mandates that a lawyer shall not neglect a legal matter entrusted to him while Rule 18.04 requires the lawyer to keep the client informed of the status of the case to protect the clients interest with utmost diligence. Consequently a lawyer who fails to file an answer within the reglementary period or fails to timely notify a client of an adverse resolution resulting in the loss of the right to appeal is administratively liable for negligence although the penalty may be mitigated by the absence of bad faith.
digest.facts: Complainant engaged respondent Esplana for an unlawful detainer case where Esplana filed the Answer eight days late resulting in it being expunged and an adverse decision by the Municipal Trial Court which was affirmed by the Regional Trial Court. On further appeal respondent Checa-Hinojosa represented the complainant but after the Court of Appeals denied their petition for review and subsequent motion for reconsideration she failed to inform the complainant of the denial until the period to appeal to the Supreme Court had already lapsed. The Integrated Bar of the Philippines found both lawyers negligent and recommended a reprimand for both considering it was their first offense and they allegedly acted in good faith.
digest.issue:
1. Whether respondent Esplana is administratively liable for negligence in failing to file the Answer on time.

2. Whether respondent Checa-Hinojosa is administratively liable for failure to inform the complainant of the Court of Appeals resolution.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, respondent Esplana is administratively liable. Rule 18.03 of the Code of Professional Responsibility states that a lawyer shall not neglect a legal matter entrusted to him and his negligence in connection therewith shall render him liable. Here respondent Esplana failed to file the Answer on time but the Court found that he exerted efforts to communicate with the client whose physical unavailability caused the delay effectively negating bad faith. Hence the Court affirmed the penalty of reprimand finding that suspension was too harsh given the mitigating circumstances.

2. YES, respondent Checa-Hinojosa is administratively liable. Under Rules 18.03 and 18.04 of the Code of Professional Responsibility a lawyer has a fiduciary duty to serve the client with competence and diligence and to keep the client informed of the case status to allow for timely remedies. Here respondent Checa-Hinojosa failed to inform the complainant of the appellate courts resolution which foreclosed the remedy of appeal and she could not validly shift the blame to her support staff for this oversight. Hence the Court modified the penalty to a one-month suspension as her negligence directly resulted in the finality of the adverse judgment.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, premises considered, judgment is hereby rendered as follows: 1. Atty. Toradio R. Esplana is hereby found GUILTY of violating Rule 18.03 of the Code of Professional Responsibility and is REPRIMANDED with STERN WARNING that a repetition of the same or similar offense in the future shall be dealt with severely. 2. Atty. Mary Grace A. Checa-Hinojosa is hereby found GUILTY of violating Rules 18.03 and 18.04 of the Code of Professional Responsibility and is SUSPENDED from the practice of law for a period of one (1) month with STERN WARNING that a repetition of similar acts shall be dealt with more severely. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Section 85 and Section 86 of the Government Auditing Code require the existence of a prior sufficient appropriation certified by the proper accounting official before any contract involving the expenditure of public funds is entered into otherwise the contract is void and the officer entering into it is liable for the resulting damage. Consequently a public officer who approves the payment of price escalation based on a contract clause that lacks specific funding certification and fails to verify the propriety of the claim despite the lapse of time and lack of required government approvals commits malversation and graft through gross inexcusable negligence.
digest.facts: Petitioner Sarion as Municipal Mayor entered into a contract for the construction of a public market which provided for price escalation but lacked a specific appropriation for such adjustment at the time of execution. Years later during his second term he approved a disbursement voucher for the price escalation claim of the contractor Markbilt despite the absence of a certificate of availability of funds specifically for the escalation and without securing the required approval from the National Economic and Development Authority and the Government Procurement Policy Board. The Sandiganbayan convicted him of Malversation of Public Funds and violation of Section 3(e) of Republic Act No 3019 finding that his acts constituted gross inexcusable negligence a decision which the Supreme Court affirmed in its main judgment prompting this motion for reconsideration where petitioner insisted on his good faith reliance on subordinates.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the petitioner is guilty of Malversation of Public Funds due to the payment of price escalation without prior appropriation.

2. Whether the petitioner is guilty of violation of Section 3(e) of Republic Act No 3019 for causing undue injury to the government through gross inexcusable negligence.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the petitioner is guilty of Malversation. Under Article 217 of the Revised Penal Code and Presidential Decree No 1445 a public officer is accountable for public funds and must ensure they are disbursed only for intended purposes supported by prior appropriation. Here the petitioner approved the payment for price escalation despite the absence of a specific appropriation and the required certification of availability of funds rendering the expenditure illegal and the contract clause void. Hence the petitioner committed malversation through gross inexcusable negligence by facilitating the illegal release of public funds.

2. YES, the petitioner is guilty of violating Section 3(e) of Republic Act No 3019. Under the law a public officer is liable for causing undue injury to the government through gross inexcusable negligence which includes the failure to observe basic requirements in the disbursement of public funds. Here the petitioner failed to exercise the necessary diligence by approving the disbursement without referring the matter to the proper authorities for the required price escalation approval and instead relied solely on subordinates despite circumstances calling for circumspection. Hence the conviction is affirmed as his failure to observe sufficient diligence resulted in a violation of the law and undue injury to the municipality.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, premises considered, petitioner Tito S. Sarion,'s Motion for Reconsideration is hereby DENIED. Consequently, the Court's Decision dated March 18, 2021 is AFFIRMED. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: The determination of just compensation is a judicial function that must be based on reliable and actual data to ensure the equivalent rendered for the property taken is real substantial full and ample. Consequently a valuation based on a commissioners report that relies on unapproved ordinances and incomparable sales is invalid while a valuation grounded on ocular inspections and actual sales data of similar properties constitutes the proper basis for just compensation.
digest.facts: Petitioner filed a complaint for eminent domain against respondents to acquire agricultural land for a transmission line project which led to the Regional Trial Court appointing commissioners to determine just compensation. The Board of Commissioners submitted conflicting recommendations where two commissioners proposed P60.00 per square meter based on actual sales data while a separate commissioner proposed P300.00 per square meter citing a reclassification ordinance that was not yet implemented. The Regional Trial Court adopted the higher valuation of P300.00 per square meter prompting petitioner to appeal to the Court of Appeals which dismissed the case for failure to file the Appellants Brief on time.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the Court of Appeals erred in dismissing the appeal due to the late filing of the Appellants Brief.

2. Whether the Regional Trial Court correctly determined the just compensation at P300.00 per square meter.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the Court of Appeals erred. Under Section 1 of Rule 50 of the Rules of Court the dismissal of an appeal for failure to file a brief is discretionary and not mandatory allowing courts to relax the rules in the interest of substantial justice. Here the Supreme Court found that strict application of procedural rules would result in the affirmation of a grossly unfair valuation derived from a baseless commissioners report. Hence the appeal is reinstated to prevent a miscarriage of justice and to correct the trial courts erroneous determination of just compensation.

2. NO, the Regional Trial Court erred. Under established jurisprudence just compensation must be ascertained using reliable and actual data rather than conjectures or speculations regarding future development or unapproved reclassifications. Here the trial court relied on a separate commissioners report that cited a non-implemented zoning ordinance and a sale of a distant property while disregarding the joint report that used actual sales data of nearby similar lots. Hence the Supreme Court modified the judgment and set the just compensation at P60.00 per square meter with legal interest.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the Petition for Review on Certiorari dated August 22, 2017 filed by National Grid Corporation of the Philippines (NGCP) is GRANTED. The Resolutions dated October 27, 2016 and May 11, 2017 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV No. 04264-MIN are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. Further, the Decision dated August 5, 2014 of the Regional Trial Court of Iligan City, Branch 3 in Civil Case No. 7365 is MODIFIED as follows (See full text for full disposition).

digest.doctrine: An exclusive distributor does not acquire any proprietary interest in the principal's trademark and cannot register it in his own name unless it has been validly assigned to him because the right to register a trademark must be based on ownership. Consequently a distributor who registers the principal's trademark in bad faith and without authorization acts fraudulently and acquires no rights over the mark necessitating the cancellation of such registration in favor of the actual owner and foreign manufacturer.
digest.facts: Respondent Farling filed petitions to cancel the trademark registrations of petitioner Cymar for the mark FARLIN alleging that Farling is the true owner and prior user while Cymar was merely its Philippine distributor. Farling presented shipping documents and correspondence proving a long-standing distributorship agreement where it exported FARLIN products to Cymar who then fraudulently registered the marks in its own name. The Director General of the Intellectual Property Office ruled in favor of Farling finding Cymar was a mere distributor acting in bad faith a decision affirmed by the Court of Appeals which held that Cymar could not acquire ownership rights over the mark.
digest.issue:
1. Whether Cymar as the first registrant has the right to use and register the FARLIN mark and its derivatives in the Philippines.

2. Whether Farling has standing to oppose Cymar's trademark applications despite not having a prior Philippine registration at the time of Cymar's applications.
digest.ruling:
1. NO, Cymar does not have the right. Under established jurisprudence and trademark laws an exclusive distributor does not acquire any proprietary interest in the principal's trademark and a registration obtained in bad faith is void. Here the evidence confirmed that Cymar was merely the importer and distributor of Farling's products and it fraudulently registered the trademarks in its own name in violation of its fiduciary duty to the principal. Hence the cancellation of Cymar's registrations was proper as it never acquired ownership of the marks.

2. YES, Farling has standing to oppose. Under Section 151 of the Intellectual Property Code a party may oppose a registration if it will be damaged by a mark obtained fraudulently or contrary to the provisions of the law. Here Farling proved that Cymar's applications were filed in bad faith to appropriate the goodwill of Farling's products which established the necessary damage to support the opposition despite Farling's lack of prior local registration. Hence the opposition was correctly granted to protect the rightful owner against fraudulent registration.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the present petitions are hereby DENIED. The assailed Decisions and Resolutions of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 80350, CA-G.R. SP No. 124697, CA-G.R.
