SP No. 124698, and CA-G.R. SP No. 126647 are AFFIRMED. Costs against petitioner Cymar International, Inc. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine:
Article 1235 of the Civil Code provides that when an obligee accepts the performance knowing its incompleteness or irregularity and without expressing any protest or objection the obligation is deemed fully complied with. Consequently the issuance of a certificate of completion indicating a project is 100 percent complete constitutes a waiver of any protest regarding the works entitling the contractor to the full payment of the balance despite non-submission of other documentary requirements.

Under Article 1169 of the Civil Code demand by the creditor shall not be necessary in order that delay may exist when the obligation or the law expressly so declares. Consequently where a construction agreement explicitly provides that failure to complete work on the specified completion dates renders the contractor liable for liquidated damages the contractor incurs in delay automatically upon the lapse of the period without need for a judicial or extrajudicial demand.
digest.facts: Petitioner Southstar Construction and Development Corporation entered into three construction agreements with respondent Philippine Estates Corporation for the development of model houses and phase entries in Iloilo which included stipulations on completion dates and retention money. After Southstar turned over the projects and demanded the balance of the contract price respondent refused payment alleging delay and failure to submit required documents like the sworn statement and guarantee bond. The Regional Trial Court ruled in favor of Southstar ordering payment of the balance but deducting liquidated damages for delay while the Court of Appeals reversed the decision and dismissed the complaint entirely holding that the non-submission of documents under the contract barred Southstar from claiming any payment.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the Court of Appeals erred in ruling that the non-submission of documentary requirements justified the withholding of the entire contract balance.

2. Whether the petitioner is liable for liquidated damages due to delay despite the absence of a demand.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the Court of Appeals erred. Under Article 1235 of the Civil Code acceptance of performance without objection waives irregularities and contract stipulations regarding retention money must be strictly construed to cover only the amount specified. Here the respondent issued a certificate of completion for one project which waived objections and the contract provision regarding the non-submission of documents only authorized the withholding of the ten percent retention money not the entire balance of the contract price. Hence the petitioner is entitled to the payment of the balance subject only to the retention of ten percent for the projects where the documents were not submitted.

2. YES, the petitioner is liable for liquidated damages. Under Article 1169 of the Civil Code demand is not necessary to render the obligor in default when the obligation or the law expressly so declares. Here the construction agreements explicitly provided that failure to complete the work on the designated dates would render the contractor liable for liquidated damages which constitutes an express stipulation dispensing with the need for demand. Hence the petitioner incurred in delay from the lapse of the agreed completion dates until the turnover of the projects and is liable for the corresponding liquidated damages.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, premises considered, the Petition for Review on Certiorari dated August 24, 2015 filed by petitioner Southstar Construction and Development Corporation is PARTIALLY GRANTED. The Decision dated January 22, 2015 and the Resolution dated June 16, 2015 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV No. 101973 are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. The Decision dated May 2, 2013 of the Regional Trial Court of Imus, Cavite, Branch 20 is REINSTATED with the following MODIFICATIONS (See full text for full disposition).

digest.doctrine: To establish a compulsory easement of right of way the owner of the dominant estate must prove that the property is surrounded by other immovables and has no adequate outlet to a public highway among other requisites. Consequently a claimant who fails to present evidence regarding the physical condition and accessibility of other adjacent lots fails to justify the imposition of an easement because the court cannot determine if the proposed route is truly necessary or the least prejudicial to the servient estate.
digest.facts: Spouses Vargas owned a parcel of land referred to as the Outside Lot and subsequently purchased an adjacent lot within the Vista Real Classica subdivision owned by respondent Sta Lucia Realty to obtain access to a public road. When the respondent refused their demand for a right of way citing deed restrictions and the need for a perimeter fence the spouses filed a complaint claiming their property was isolated and the subdivision route was the only adequate outlet. The Regional Trial Court granted the easement holding that it did not constitute an alteration of the subdivision plan but the Court of Appeals reversed the decision and dismissed the complaint because the spouses failed to prove that the proposed route was the least prejudicial and that no other adequate outlets existed through the other surrounding lots.
digest.issue: Whether the petitioners are entitled to a compulsory easement of right of way through the respondents subdivision.
digest.ruling: NO, the petitioners are not entitled to the right of way. Under Articles 649 and 650 of the Civil Code the claimant bears the burden of proving that the dominant estate is surrounded by other immovables without an adequate outlet to a public highway and that the easement is sought at the point least prejudicial to the servient estate. Here the petitioners failed to present any evidence regarding the accessibility or physical condition of the three other lots bordering their property which prevented the court from performing a comparative evaluation to determine if the proposed route through the subdivision was indeed the only adequate outlet or the least prejudicial option. Hence the claim must be denied for failure to establish compliance with the mandatory statutory requisites for a compulsory easement.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the Court DENIES the present petition and AFFIRMS the assailed Decision and Resolution of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV No. 90968. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: Placing security guards on floating status is a valid exercise of management prerogative provided it does not exceed six months otherwise constructive dismissal shall be deemed to have occurred requiring the employer to assign the employee to a specific client rather than issuing a general return-to-work order. Consequently a security guard is constructively dismissed when he remains on floating status for more than six months despite receiving notices to report for immediate posting if such notices fail to identify a specific client or post.
digest.facts: Petitioner security guard was suspended for sleeping on duty and subsequently placed on floating status for over six months prompting him to file a complaint for illegal dismissal while respondents claimed they sent notices to report for work which petitioner allegedly ignored. The Labor Arbiter dismissed the complaint for lack of merit ruling that petitioner failed to comply with the return-to-work notices and the National Labor Relations Commission affirmed this dismissal. The Court of Appeals subsequently dismissed the petition and deemed the case closed and terminated based on a Quitclaim and Release executed by petitioner which supposedly settled the dispute.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the Court of Appeals erred in dismissing the petition based on a quitclaim executed in a different case.

2. Whether the petitioner was constructively dismissed due to his floating status exceeding six months.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the Court of Appeals erred. The Supreme Court held that a quitclaim executed in one case does not automatically extinguish a separate and distinct pending action between the same parties. Here the quitclaim and release relied upon by the appellate court pertained to a different case involving a money claim for a surety bond and not the instant complaint for illegal dismissal regarding the petitioners employment status. Hence the dismissal of the petition based on the settlement of an unrelated case was misplaced.

2. YES, the petitioner was constructively dismissed. Under settled jurisprudence a security guards employer must assign the employee to a specific or particular client within six months of being placed on floating status and a general return-to-work order does not suffice to toll this period. Here the notices sent by respondents merely directed petitioner to report for immediate posting without identifying a specific client or assignment effectively leaving him on floating status beyond the permissible six-month period. Hence the petitioner was illegally dismissed and is entitled to separation pay as reinstatement is no longer feasible due to the lapse of time.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, in view of the foregoing premises, the instant petition is GRANTED. The August 28, 2015 Decision and Resolution dated March 31, 2017 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. SP No. 130704, are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. Accordingly, respondents Gervasio Security and Investigation Agency, Inc./Susan S. Gervasio are ordered to pay petitioner Samsudin T. Hamid: 1. Full backwages and other benefits computed from the date petitioner's employment was illegally terminated until the finality of this Decision; 2. Separation pay computed from the date petitioner commenced employment until the finality of this Decision at the rate of one (1) month's salary for every year of service, with a fraction of a year of at least six (6) months being counted as one (1) whole year; and 3. Attorney's fees equivalent to ten percent (10%) of the total award. 4. Interest of six percent (6%) per annum on all the monetary awards from the finality of this Decision until full payment. The case is REMANDED to the Labor Arbiter to make a detailed computation of the amounts due to petitioner, which must be paid without delay, and for the execution of this Decision. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: The constitutional right to speedy disposition of cases requires the prosecution to justify any delay exceeding reasonable periods by proving that the complexity of issues or volume of evidence made such delay inevitable. Consequently an unexplained delay in the preliminary investigation of a simple case involving a single transaction and minimal records constitutes a violation of the accuseds constitutional rights warranting the dismissal of the charges.
digest.facts: Petitioners former municipal officials were charged regarding the irregularities in the purchase of a garbage truck based on a complaint filed in 2002 which underwent fact-finding until 2011 followed by a formal complaint in 2012 and the eventual filing of Informations in 2014. Petitioners moved to dismiss the case before the Sandiganbayan citing the inordinate delay of over a decade but the anti-graft court denied their motion ruling that the lapse of time alone did not constitute a violation of their rights.
digest.issue: Whether the Sandiganbayan committed grave abuse of discretion in denying the motion to dismiss due to the violation of the right to speedy disposition of cases.
digest.ruling: YES, the Sandiganbayan committed grave abuse of discretion. Under the Constitution and the Cagang guidelines the burden shifts to the prosecution to justify delays beyond the prescribed periods by showing that the case involved complex issues or voluminous evidence. Here the Ombudsman took over two years to resolve the preliminary investigation of a straightforward case involving a single transaction of P380,000.00 without providing any valid justification for the delay. Hence the case is dismissed because the unjustified delay violated the petitioners constitutional right to speedy disposition of cases.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the petition is GRANTED. The Resolutions dated June 7, 2016 and September 6, 2016 of the Sandiganbayan, Third Division, in Criminal Case Nos. SB-15-CRM-0092 and SB-15-CRM-0093 are hereby ANNULLED and SET ASIDE. For violation of their constitutional right to speedy disposition of cases, the charges against petitioners MARIANO MALONES y MALIFICIO and EDNA M. MADARICO are ordered DISMISSED.

digest.doctrine: Section 69 of the Omnibus Election Code strictly limits the grounds for declaring a nuisance candidate to acts that put the election process in mockery cause confusion among voters or demonstrate a lack of bona fide intention to run effectively excluding the lack of financial capacity or nationwide fame as valid grounds since the Constitution only prescribes age citizenship voting and residence qualifications. Consequently the Commission on Elections commits grave abuse of discretion when it declares an aspirant a nuisance candidate solely due to a lack of established nationwide network or political machinery as these are not prerequisites for a bona fide intention to run for public office.
digest.facts: Petitioner filed his Certificate of Candidacy for Vice President in the 2022 elections but faced a petition from the COMELEC to declare him a nuisance candidate based on his alleged lack of genuine intention and nationwide network. The COMELEC First Division cancelled his certificate of candidacy ruling that he failed to prove the capacity to launch a nationwide campaign while the COMELEC En Banc denied his motion for reconsideration for being allegedly defective and filed out of time despite proof of compliance. Petitioner filed a certiorari petition and secured a Temporary Restraining Order from the Supreme Court to stop the enforcement of the resolutions but the COMELEC proceeded to print the ballots without his name rendering his inclusion impossible.
digest.issue:
1. Whether the COMELEC committed grave abuse of discretion in declaring the petitioner a nuisance candidate.

2. Whether the members of the COMELEC are liable for contempt for violating the Temporary Restraining Order.
digest.ruling:
1. YES, the COMELEC committed grave abuse of discretion. Under Section 69 of the Omnibus Election Code nuisance candidates are those who file candidacies to mock the election process cause confusion or lack bona fide intention to run which does not include the lack of a nationwide support network. Here the COMELEC erroneously disqualified the petitioner based on his limited popularity in Northern Mindanao and lack of political machinery which are not qualifications prescribed by the Constitution or the law. Hence the disqualification was invalid although the petition for inclusion in the ballot was denied for being moot due to the completion of pre-election activities.

2. YES, the members of the COMELEC are liable for contempt. Under jurisprudence and the Rules of Court disobedience to a lawful writ or injunctive order constitutes indirect contempt which warrants a penalty or reprimand. Here the COMELEC members proceeded with the printing of ballots excluding the petitioner despite the issuance of a Temporary Restraining Order enjoining the enforcement of the disqualification ruling. Hence the members are guilty of contempt and are severely reprimanded for disregarding the Courts directive.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the Petition for Certiorari filed by Wilson Caritero Amad is DENIED insofar as it has become MOOT and ACADEMIC. Nevertheless, the members of the Commission on Elections are found GUILTY of CONTEMPT of the Supreme Court for their disobedience to the Court's lawful directive, specifically the Temporary Restraining Order dated January 20, 2022. Accordingly, they are REPRIMANDED for this disobedience. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: An affidavit constitutes hearsay evidence without probative value when the affiant is not presented on the witness stand to testify and be subjected to cross-examination by the adverse party. Consequently a conviction anchored primarily on such hearsay evidence and ambiguous admissions in counter-affidavits that are qualified by specific denials fails to overcome the constitutional presumption of innocence and warrants the acquittal of the accused for lack of proof beyond reasonable doubt.
digest.facts: Accused Pimentel and Reyes as municipal mayor and barangay captain respectively were charged with violation of Section 3(e) of Republic Act No 3019 and Malversation for allegedly diverting government construction materials intended for a solar dryer to Pimentels private resort. The prosecution relied mainly on the affidavit-complaint of a former barangay captain who did not testify and the accuseds counter-affidavits which admitted the existence of the complaint as public record but denied the commission of the crime explaining that the materials were moved for safekeeping due to flooding. The Sandiganbayan convicted both accused based on the alleged admissions in their counter-affidavits and the hearsay complaint prompting this appeal where the accused argued the insufficiency of evidence.
digest.issue: Whether the Sandiganbayan erred in convicting the accused based on the affidavit-complaint and their counter-affidavits.
digest.ruling: YES, the Sandiganbayan erred. Under the Rules on Evidence and established jurisprudence an affidavit is merely hearsay evidence when its maker does not take the witness stand and admissions must be clear and categorical to support a conviction. Here the prosecution failed to present the complainant as a witness making her affidavit hearsay while the alleged admissions in the counter-affidavits were qualified by specific denials and insufficient to prove that the materials were misappropriated for personal use. Hence the Supreme Court reversed the conviction and acquitted both accused as the prosecution failed to prove their guilt beyond reasonable doubt.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the appeal is GRANTED. The Decision dated October 4, 2019, and the Resolution dated January 24, 2020, issued by the Sandiganbayan in SB-16-CRM-0479 and SB-16-CRM-0480, are hereby REVERSED and SET ASIDE. Accordingly, accused-appellants Rogelio Maquinano Pimentel and Herminigildo Quico Reyes are ACQUITTED for failure of the prosecution to prove their guilt beyond reasonable doubt. SO ORDERED.

digest.doctrine: In cases of incestuous rape committed by a father against his daughter the element of force or intimidation is substituted by the moral ascendancy and influence exercised by the offender over the victim requiring only proof of carnal knowledge to sustain a conviction. Consequently the failure of the victim to testify regarding the actual use of force or threat does not preclude a conviction for rape where DNA evidence conclusively establishes that the accused fathered the victims child.
digest.facts: Accused-appellant BBB was charged with two counts of rape against his minor daughter AAA but the victim failed to testify during trial due to financial constraints and misinformation regarding DNA costs. The prosecution relied on DNA evidence showing a 99.9999 percent probability that BBB was the father of AAAs child alongside stipulations regarding the testimony of the victims aunt and the victims birth certificate proving her minority. The Regional Trial Court convicted BBB of one count of rape based on the DNA result and circumstantial evidence while acquitting him of the other count. The Court of Appeals affirmed the conviction with modification as to the damages awarded ruling that the DNA evidence conclusively proved carnal knowledge and that moral ascendancy substituted for force.
digest.issue: Whether the accused-appellant is guilty of rape despite the victims failure to testify to prove the element of force or intimidation.
digest.ruling: YES, the accused-appellant is guilty. Under Article 266-A of the Revised Penal Code and established jurisprudence on incestuous rape the moral ascendancy of a father over his daughter substitutes for the element of force or intimidation. Here the DNA evidence conclusively proved that the accused had carnal knowledge of his daughter and his status as her biological father provided the overpowering moral influence that rendered proof of actual force unnecessary. Hence the prosecution successfully established all elements of the crime beyond reasonable doubt despite the absence of the victims testimony.
digest.dispositive: WHEREFORE, the appeal is DISMISSED for lack of merit. The Decision dated November 11, 2019 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CR HC No. 11429 is AFFIRMED with MODIFICATION. Accused-appellant BBB is found GUILTY beyond reasonable doubt of Rape under Article 266-A of the Revised Penal Code, as amended, and is hereby sentenced to suffer the penalty of reclusion perpetua without eligibility for parole. (See full text for full disposition).
